Adult male. Top of tbe bead, back and sides of tbe neck, back, 
and rump grey, barred witb black, tbe bars, especially on tbc lover 
back and rump, being concentric ; a band of blackish featbers across 
tbe mantle, barred witb rufous grey; seapulars, lesser^ median, and 
secondary coverts, and a few of tfce outer secondaries sandy or 

TETRAOHTDiE. 

rufous white, mottled and barred with black, the scapulars and some 

of the median coverts with a white shaft-spot dilated afc the ex


tremity; primaries, primary-coverts, and rest of secondaries dark 

brown, the quills being more or less margined with buff round the 

outer web and tip; upper tail-coverts black, mottled with rufous 

grey and tipped with grey; a sraall patch of black and white 

feathers behind the bare skin surrounding the eye, and a similar 

spot behind the lores; chin, throat, ehest, and middle of breast 

black; throat surrounded by an irregulaiiy marked white band; 

fore part of the neck brownish black, tipped with rufous grey or 

white; sides of the breast and belly black, widely tipped with white; 

sides and flanks like the scapulars ; vent white ; under tail-coverts 

black, widely tipped with white; tail black, slightly mottled with 

rufous towards the base, and tipped with chestnut. Total length 

15*5 inches, wing 6*8, tail 4*8, tarsus 1*4. 

Immature males and females after the first moult cannot be dis


tinguished from the adults, except by the more pointed first primary. 

Adult ferndle. Top of the head, neck, mantle, lower back, rump, 
and upper tail-coverts black, barred with pale rufous yellow, and, 
especially on the three latter, tipped with grey; lesser, median, 
and secondary coverts and scapulars similar to the back, but the 
rufous bars are irregulär and broken up into mottlings; as in the 
male, the scapulars and a few of the coverts have dilated white shaft-
spots at the extremity; quills and primary-coverts as in the male; 
lores, chin, and throat pale rufous and whitish yellow, barred and 
spotted with black; fore part of neck and ehest pale rufous, barred 
with black; breast, belly, and under tail-coverts the same, but 
tipped with white; sides and flanks like the scapulars; vent white; 
tail as in the male, but irregularly barred with rufous ; in very old 
speeimens most of the barrings disappear, and only the bases of the 
outer feathers are finely mottled with pale rufous. Total length 
14-2 inches, wing 6*8, tail 4, tarsus 1*4. 

Hab, Northern F . America, ranging westwards to the east side 
of the Eocky Mountains, eastwards to New England and New York, 
northwards to Alaska, and south to Minnesota.

Aduli male. Differs from adult male of C. canadensis chiefly in 
having the ground-eolour of the back and rump brownish grey 
instead of grey, the tipper tail-coverts tipped with white, and the 
tail-feathers without any chestnut terminal band. Total length 15 
inches, wing 7*2, tail 5*2, tarsus 1*6.

Tetrao canadensis, var. franklinii, Middend. Sibir. Beis., Aves, p. 202,

Canace falcipennis, Tacz. Bull Soc. Zool Fr. i. p. 242 (1876); Bogd. 
Comp. Av. Boss. fasc. i. p. 30 (1884). 
Adult male. General colour above black, barred with greyish and 
sandy buff; top of the head dark grey, indistinctly mottled with 
black; mantle black, tipped with sandy buff; lower back, rump, 
upper tail-coverts, scapulars, and wing-coverts mottled and edged 
with sandy buff, the scapulars, lower back, and rurnp with white 
shaft-spots at the extremity; primaries, primary-coverts, secondaries, 
and the outer wing-coverts with the ground-eolour brown, 
the secondaries narrowly tipped and margined round the outer web 
with white; chin, throat, and cheeks black, a small patch behind 
the eye and the base of the throat mostly white; fore part and sides 
of upper neck black, barred with buff; fore part and sides of lower 
neck dark smoky black, becoming paler on the ehest and middle of 
the belly; rest of underparts smoky black, each feather with a wide 
subterminal white cross bar, gradually changing into heart-shaped 
spots on the sides ancl flanks; vent white; under tail-coverts and 
tail black, widely tipped with white, except the two middle tail-
feathers, which have the extremities mottled with greyish and with 
an irregulär subterminal white spot. Total length 16»3 inches, 
wing 7*2, tail 4*7, tarsus 1*4. 

6. BElTOEAaAPirS. 
Immature male* Still retains, among the scapulars, feathers largely 
barred and mottled with rufous and with buff sliaft-stripes; the 
sides of the neck are mottled and barred with rufous buff; the 
white marks on the feathers of the underparts are nearly all heart-
shaped; and the outer primaries are tipped with buff, and even 
more acute than in the adult. 

Aclult female. Differs from the male in haying the head and neck 
barred with black and buff and tipped with sandy ; mantle black, 
with a subterminal buff bar, and mottled with sandy at the extremity; 
lower back, rump, and Upper tail-coverts mottled witb rufous grey 
and black, tipped with sandy grey, and with a subterminal pale buff 
shaft-spot; chin, throat, and sides of the head more or less mixed 
with white; neck and ehest black, barred with buff; breast greyish 
black, with a wide white subterminal patch to each feather; the 
feathers of the sides, flanks, and under tail-coverts similar, but with 
the basal part thickly mottled with sandy buff; the outer webs of 
the outer tail-feathers more or less margined and mottled with buff. 
Total length 14*7 inehes, wing 7*2, tail 4*3, tarsus 1*4.

Canace obscums, var. obscurus, Baird, Breiu.,fy Ridgw. N. Amer. B. 

iii. p. 422 (1874). 
Adult male. General colonr above smoky black, mottled, especially 
on the low er back, rump, and upper tail-coverts, with grey; wing-
coverts, scapulars, and outer secondaries mottled and irregularly 
barred with brown, most of the median wing-coverts and scapulars 
with terminal white shaft-spots; primaries and rest of secondaries 
brownish black, the latter irregularly margined and tipped with 
whitish; lores, chin, and throat white, spotted with black, cheeks 
smoky black; a dark smoky-blaek band across the sides and fore 
part of the neck; axillaries and most of the nnder wing-coverts 
pure white, a hidden white patch on each aide of the neck; ehest, 
breast, and belly light grey, each feather narrowly margined with 
white; sides like the scapulars ; fianks and under tail-eoverts grey, 
mottled and barred with black, and with white shafts and tips ; tail 
black, widely tipped with dark grey, the band on the middle feathers 
varying in width from 1 to 1*5 inch, and on the outermost feathers 
from 0*5 to 0*8 inch. Total length 19*5 inches, wing 10, tail 6*7, 

tarsus 1*7. 
Immature male. Has the plumage very similar to the female, but 
the feathers of the ehest are not barred with buf!; the outer primaries 
are pointed and mottled with buff towards the tip. 
Adult female. General colour above smoky black, barred, especially 
on the top of the head, mantle, and scapulars, with buif, and 
mottled towards the tips of the scapulars, wing-coverts, rump, and 
Upper tail-coverts with pale sandy buff; quills as in the male, but 
the outer margins of the secondaries have the whitish-buff markings 
coarser and more broken up ; lores, chin, and throat white, spotted 
with black; axillaries and most of the under wing-coverts pure 
white; ehest and upper breast grey, barred with bnff and black 

6 . DENDEAGAPTTS. 
75 

round tho fore part of the neck ; lower breast and belly grey; sides 
and flanks black, barred and mottled with buff, and tipped with 
white like the scapulars ; under tail-coverts similar in markings, but 
greyer ; tail black, with. a wide grey terminal band, fbely mottled 
with black, the middle pair of tail-feathers with irregulär bars 
of buff. Total length 17 inches, wing 8-6, tail 5-9, tarsus 1-6. 

Immature female. Differs only from the adult in the pointed 
shape of the first primaries. 

Young birds have pale shaft-stripes to the feathers of the mantle, 
scapulars, wing-coverts, outer secondaries, and ehest; in a venj 
young Urcl the chin, throat, lower breast, and belly are white, and 
the rest of the underparts are white spotted with black. 

Hab. Eocky Mountains, west to the "Wahsatch, south to New 
Mexico and Arizona, and north to the South Pass.

7. TYMPANTJCHÜS. 
Adult male. General colour above brown, barrod and marked with 
buff and black ; the feathers on the crown mostly clark brown iipped 
with white and somewhat elongatc, forming a short crest; thoso on 
the back of the neck, wing-coverts, scapulars, and secondarios tipped 
with whifcish buff; the neck-tnfts composed of more than ton 
feathers, the longer ones are black, the middle and losser oncs 
creamy white down the middle and margined on their inner webs 
with pale chestnut; quills pale brown, all (except sometimes the 
innermost primaries) toothed or barred with buff; lores and space in 
front of the eye, patch above the ear-coverts, chin, and throat whitish 
buff; a dark brown band from the angle of the gape to the ear-
coverts and a patch of spots of the some colour on the sides of the 
throat; feathers on fore part of neck dark brown, barred with light 
red, and mostly with white shafts and tips; rest of the underparts 
paler brown, barred and fringed with white; axillaries long, and 
pure white like the vent; thighs brownish white; under tail-
coverts brownish black, mottled and very widely tipped with white; 
tail brownish black, narrowly tipped with white, the middle feathers 
mottled and irregularly barred towards the margins of the webs. 
Total length 16*5 inches, wing 9, tail 3*9, tarsus 1*9. 

Adult fernale. Differs from the male in having the neck-tufts 
much reduced in length and the outer as well as the middle tail-
feathers barred with rufous buff. The measurements are usually 
also a trifle less. 

In young speeimens the general colour is brown, blotched with 
black, and barred and mottled with buff; the top of the head is 
chestnut, with a black patch in the middle ; the feathers of the 
mantle, wing-coverts, scapulars, outer secondaries, and tail with 
strongly marked whitish-buff shaft-stripes; chin, throat, and undorparts 
white, the latter barred with dark brown and washed with 
buff or pale rufous on the sides. 

Hab, Prairies of Mississippi Valley, south to Louisiana and Texas, 
west to the middle of Kansas, Nebraska, and Dakota, north to 
Manitoba and Wisconsin, east to Indiana and Kentucky.

Adult male. Kesembles the male of T. americanus, bnt is smaller 
and easily distinguished by having the darker subterminal bars on 
the back treble, i. e. coniposed of a wider brown band in the middle 
and two narrower black bands on each side, whereas in the latter 
bird they are uniform black or have at most only a spot of brown 
on the margin of each web ; the feathers of the ehest have about 
six alternate bars of brown and white and the bars are also much 
narrower. Total length 15 inches, wing 8*3, tail 3*5, tarsus 1*6. 

Adult female. Differs from the male in having the neck-tufts 
much shorter and the longest feathers buff barred with black • all 
the tail-feathers are barred with buff. 

Mab. Eastern border of Great Plains from Nebraska (?), S.W. 
Kansas, S.W. Missouri (?), and western part of Indian Territory fco

Aclult male. Greneral colour above black, very irregularly barrcd,

irregularly barred witk white and the former with white shaft-
stripes ; quills and primary-coverts brown, the seeondaries margin ed 
at the tip with white and mottled on the outer web with buff; 
sides of tbe head, chin, and throat spotted with black and white, 
in some speeimens the former, in some the latter colour predominating; 
a white crescent on tke front of the neck, followed by 
a large black patcb; a lateral raff of elongate white feathers on 
each side of the neck, the shafts produced into long recurved processes 
bearing black fllaments; ehest white, the feathers short and 
scale-like, with skarp-pointed skafts; breast similar, but the tips of 
the shafts are produced beyond the web into black bristles; belly 
black, wkitish on the sides; sides and flanks mottled with black, 
brown, and buff, and with whitish shaft-stripes; under taü-coverta 
black, largely tipped witk white. Tail dark brown, tho basal twotkirds 
of tko featkers mottled witk rufous and irregularly barrod 
witk buff. Total lengtk 28 inches, wing 12*5, tail 12, tarsus 2-2. 

Speeimens after the summer moult are muck more brightly 
coloured; and most o£ tke markings on the new feathers of tho 
iipper parts are warm rufous buff instead of sandy whitish buff as 
in tke old ones. 

Aclult female. Differs from tke male chiefly in having the chin 
and tkroat white, and the fore part of the neck spotted with

Pediocsetes phasianellus campestris, A. O. U. Check-l. p. 176 (1886); 
Bidgw. Man. p. 204 (1887) ; Thompson, P. U.S. Nat. Mus. xiii. 

p. 516 (1891) [S. & W. Manitoba]. 
Adult male. General colour above Sandy grey or greyish claycolour, 
mottled and irregularly barred and blotched with black and 
spotted with white, especially towards the base of the feathers of 
the interscapulary region ; wing-coverts, soapulars, and onter secondaries 
white, spotted at the extremity; quiÜs light brown; rest of 
the secondaries barred and tipped with white; all the primaries 
spotted on the outerweb with. white and the inner ones tipped with 
the same colour ; lores, superciliaiy stripes, cheeks, chin, and throat 
pale buff; cheeks and sometimes the throat spotted with black ; neck 
bnfT, barred and mottled with black; ehest, breast, and sides of 
belly white,each featherwith a concentrie submarginal black band; 
sides and flanks like the scapulars : middle of belly and vent white; 
tarsi smoky white; under tail-coverts mottled with black and sandy 
grey, and barred, mottled, and widely tipped with white; two 
middle pairs of tail-feathers barred and marked with rufous buff 
and black and iipped with white; rest of outer feathers mostly 
white, with the basal part of the outer web mottled with black. 
Total length 15 inches, wing 8*1, tail 5, tarsus 1*7. 

Adult female. Resembles the male, but the tail is a trifle shorter 
and the size somewhat less; generally, too, the barring on the back 
of the neck and upper mantle is stronger and more regulär. Total 
length 14*8 inches, wing 7*7, tail 4*5. 

Hab. TTnited States—north to Manitoba, east to "Wisconsin and 
Northern Illinois, south to New Mexico, and west from Northern 
California west of the Rocky Mountains to Port Yukon, Alaska.

AfJult male. General colour above rufous or grey, but every 
intermediate stage of coloration between the two can be foimd ; top 
of tbe head barred wifch blaek; featbers of tbe short crest mostly 
blaek, tbose of tbe mantle mostly tipped and mixed witb buff and 
barred and marked witb black ; the frilled ruffles on tbe sides of tbe 
neck blaek more or less glossed witb green at tbe tips, in some 
speeimens, bowever, tbey vary to dull ehestnut; feathers of tbe 
interscapnlar region, lower back, rump. and upper tail-eoverts 
fmely yenniculated with black, and witb pale buff, subterminal, 
beart-sbaped or oval spots irregularly edged witb blaek; wing-
coverts and seapulars somewhat similar, but tbe buff markings 
take tbe form of a mesial streak and tbe latter usually baye tbe 
inner web blotcbed witb blaek; quills brown, tbe outer webs of 
tbe middle piimaries mostly buff barred witb brown; tbe secondaries 
narrowly margined witb dirty white and more or less mottled witb 
rufous or sandy along tbe margin of tbe outer web; ear-coverts 
elongate, witb wbitish sbafts and tips; cbin and tbroat and a small 
patcb before and bebind tbe eye buff, most of tbe featbers on tbe 

* Tfais apecies is subjeefc to great elimatic Variation and, as is tbe case witb 
many otber birds» such as Tumix taigoor, has two well-marked phases of 
plumag©, a grey and a rufous. These phases intergrade and every intermediate 
sfaade between the two can be found. The various varieties have been catalogued 
wider no less than four differenfc names, either as species or subspecies, by the 
latest American authors; but as all these varieties are to be found among a 
eeries of speeimeus from New York alone and are therefore not even dependent 
on locality* we eonsider it needless to employ more than one name for all, 
especially as the four recognized ferms grade imperceptibly into one another.

IjaTJEUOITOJS. 

sides of iho tliroat edged with brown, those of the fore part of the 
neck dark brown tipped with white ; breast buff or ruf'ous buff, 
with a subterminal brown bar and white tip to each feather (the 
colour of this bar varies much in different individuals, even from 
the same locality, and is sometimes exceedingly faint, at others 
strongly marked and edged with lines of a deeper colour); sicles like 
the wing-coverts ; flanks and belly widely tipped with white, and 
with dark brown or blackish subterminal bands ; vent white; under 
tail-coverts orange-bnfT or grey. more or less mottled with dusky 
and tipped with white. Tail-feathers rufous, Sandy, or grey, or a 
mixture of all three, barred and mottled with black and with a wide 
subterminal black band edged on either side with grey; in some 
speeimens, usually those with chestnut ruffles, the subterminal 
band is dull chestnut or brownish, in others it is interrupted or 
indistinctly defmed: these are apparently purely individual characters 
and are due ncither to age nor sex. Total length 17 inches, 

wing 7*3, tail 6'5, tarsus 1*6. 
Adult female. Similar to the male but rather smaller and with 
the ruffles usually less developed. 
Youvcj bircls differ chiefly from the adults in having the outer 
secondaries, scapulars, and tail-feathers rufous brown, with rather 
widely placed bars of buff, edged and mottled with dusky; ehin and 
throat white. 
Hab. Same as that of the genus.

T. bonasia. 
(1840) 

Sexes different. 

Tail composed of 16 feathers, bluntly wedge-shaped, the outer 
feathers very little shorter than the central pair. 

Ist primary considerably shorter than tho 2nd, and falls between 
the 7th and 8th; 4th slightly the longest. 

Tarsus half-feathered, shorter than the middle toe and claw. 

A short crest. Axillaries moderately long; barred or mottled 
with black and white. 
Bange. Europe and N. and Central Asia.

Adultmale. General colour above grey, rufous, or some intermediate 
stage; top of the head, Short crest, back and sides of the 
neck, and mantle barred with black; the feathers on the sides of the 
neck rather long, tipped with white and showing some tendency 
towards the formation of a rüffle as in Bonasa; rest of the lower 
back, rump, and upper tail-coverts more or less fmely mottled with 
black and with black shaft-stripes; scapnlars and outer secondaries 
blotched with black, the shorter scapnlars and sometimes the 
secondaries spotted with white at the extremities ,* wing-coverts, 

92 
TETEAOyiB-S. 

mostly with white tips, quills dull blackish brown, the otiter webs 

mottled with rufous or buff; chin and throat blaek, cireumscribed 

by a white line, parting across the forehead and traversing the 

cheeks below the eye; a small white patch behind the eye; ear-

coverts elongate, brown barred with dusky ; front of neck and ehest 

brown or rufous brown, with a subterminal blaek band and white 

tips ; rest of the underparts with dark centres and white margins 

and often, especially on the breast and belly, with a mesial white 

spot, but the feathers on the sides and flanks are generali}* more 

rufous ; vent and tarsi white; eentre pair of tail-feathers brownish 

or reddish grey, indistinctly barred and mottled with blaek and buif 

and narrowly tipped with grey ; outer tail-feathers mottled with grey 

and blaek, with a wide subterminal blaek band and white tip. 

Total length 14 inches, wing 6*5, tail 4*9, tarsus 1*3. 

Aclult female differs chieüy from the male in having the chin and 

throat mostly white and in being slightly smaller. 

Young bircls have the feathers of mantle, scapulars, and wing


eoverts barred and blotehed with blaek and with marked buff sliaft


stripes ; chin and throat white; ehest and upper breast reddish 

brown, blotehed with blaek and mixed with white; rest of under


parts mostly white, but the sides and Hanks are usually strongly 

barred with blaek; all the tail-feathers are greyish brown, or reddish 

grey indistinctly barred and mottled with dusky. 

Hah. Europe and IST. and Central Asia; ranging in the west to 

Scandinavia, and in the east to Kamtschatka, 8aghalien, and Yezo. 

Japan, southwards to K Spain, E". Italy, Transylvania, the Altai 

Mountains, and N. China.

Hybrid between Lyrurus tetrix and Tetrastes bonasia. See p. 58. 

2. Tetrastes griseiventris. 
Tetrastes griseiventris, Menzh. Bull. Mose, lv. pt. i. p. 105, pl. iv. 
(1880) [Perm] ; Reich. $ Schal. J.f. 0.1881, p. 73; Homeijer, MT. 
orn. Ter. Wien, 1883, p. 228. 

Tetrao griseiventris, Seebohm, Ibis, 1884, p. 430, pl. xi.; id. P. Z. S. 
1884, p. 409. 

Adidt male. Easily distinguished from T. bonasia by having no 
white tips to the feathers on tbe sides of tbe neck, and in fact no trace 
of tbe ineipient rüffle: tbe scapulars and wing-coverts also devoid of 
any white markings; tbe chin wbite; tbroafc black, eacb feather tipped 
with dark red and not circumseribed by any white band ; fore part 
of neck and ehest a mixture of rufous and black, barred and tipped 
with grey; rest of tbe underparts grey with indistinet bars of black, 
beeoming very faint on tbe tbigbs ; and tbe black band across tbe 
out er tail-featbers not nearly so well defined and more or less 
mottled witb buff. Total length 14 inebes, wing 6-5, tail 4*7, 
tarsus 1-3. 

Adidt female. Differs from tbe male in having tbe feathers of tbe 
throat black, widely tipped with buff; those of tbe ehest black, 
barred or marked witb rufous and tipped with sandy grey ; and the 
rufous feathers of the sides and flanks with wide irregulär black bars. 

Hah« Eastera Bussia; Government of Perm. 

3. Tetrastes severtzovi. 
Tetrastes 
sewertzowi, Trjev. Mongotia, ii. p. 130, pl. xviii. (1876) 
id. in RowL Orn. Mixe. ii. p. 430, pl. 52 (1877); Dedit. J. f. O. 
1880, pp. 538, 540 [Hoangbo & Koko-nor]. 

Adidt male. Differs chiefty from T. bonasia in having not only 
the mantle, but the whole of the lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts equally distinetly barred with black; on each side of the 
neck a more marked line of elongate, black, white-tipped feathers, 
indicating the ineipient rüffle; the whole of the underparts black, 
barred and tipped with white, the sides, as usual, being mixed 
with rafous; all the outer tail-feathers black, with narrow wide-set 
white bars and tips. Total length 13*5 inebes, wing 6*7, tail 5*3, 
tarsus 1*5. 

Adult female. Differs ehiefly from the female of T. bonasia in the 
same respeets as the male^ from which latter she is distinguished by 
having the chin and throat buff tipped with black, as wreli as by her 
somewhat smaller size. 

Mab, Xansu, Koko-nor, and the Hoangho River.

1. Lerwa lerwa. 
Perdix lerwa, Hodgs. P. Z. Ä 1833, p. 107 [Nepal]; Gray, IS. Ind.

Lerwa nivicola, Hodgs. Madr. J. 1837, p. 301; Gray, Gen. B. p. 61

Hume, Nests # JSggs Lid. B. p. 536 (1873); David # Oustalet, Ois. 
Chine, p. 392 (1877); Hume fy Marsh. Game B. Ind. ii. p. 1, pl. 
(1879); Marshall, Ibis, 1884, p. 423 [Chamba] ; Oates, ed. Humes

p. 11, no. 360(1871). 
Lerwa lerwa, Hartert, Kat. Mus. Senchenh. p. 195 (1891). 
Aditlt male andfemale. Head, neck, and the whole of the upper 
parts black, with narrow cross bars of white, except on the upper 
back and wing-coverts, where they are buff or rufous. The outer 
secondaries, scapulars, and some of the outer seeondary coverts are 
dark rufous towards the extremity, mixed here and there with buff 
and barred and mottled with black. Primaries, primary-eoverts, 
and bastard wing dark brown; the inner primaries narrowly 
tipped and often dotted on the raargin of the outer web with 

1 . LERWA. 101 
white. Inner seeondaries black, irregularly barred, mottled, and 
widely tipped with white. Chest and upper breast rieh chestnut, 
each feather with the basal half margined with white and widely 
barred with black; but these marks are hidden, except when the 
feathers are lifted up. The lower breast, belly, sides, andflanks are 
the same; but the white margins of the feathers extend nearly to 
the extremity, giving these parts a streaked appearance. The 
middle of the belly and thighs are barred with black and whitish 
buff or rufous. The under tail-coverts are chestnut tipped with 
white. Tail-feathers black, barred and mottled with white. Iris 
brown, sometimes reddish. Bill and legs bright coral-red. Total 
length 14 inches, wing 7-5, tail 4-5, tarsus 1*7. 

In younger birds the barrings on the head and upper parts are 
wider and all buff; on the underparts of the neck they are less 
clearly defined than in the adult and gradually merge into the 
ehest, all the feathers of which, like those of the breast, are mottled 
and barred with black nearly to the extremity. 

The chicJc has the upper parts black, mottled and barred with 
rufous buff; the top of the head is covered with blackish down, the 
sides are white, with a black stripe on either side passing below the 
eye ; the underparts are black, with irregulär shaft-stripes and bars 
of buff; all the primaries are mottled on the margin of the outer 
web with whitish, and the terminal parts of the seeondaries are 
black mottled with buff. Bill black ; feet Jlesh-colour. 

Hab, The higher ranges of the Himalayas, and extending north


wards to Moupin and W. Sze-chuen, China.

Tetraophasis 
obscurus, Swinh. P. Z. S. 1871, p. 399; Elliot, Mon.

Adult male. Top and sides of the head dark grey, each feather 
with a rarrow darker shait-stripe; nape, sides of the neck, and 
mantle dull olive-brown, some of the feathers, especially on the 
lower parfcs of the mantle, with a blackibh spot at the end of 
the shaft; rest of the back and rump brownish grey. Outer 
secondaries, scapulars, and wing-coverts olive-brown, each with a 
light terminal band shading into buff on the outer feathers. Primaries 
and rest of secondaries daik brown, the latter tipped and 
slightly margined on the outer web with buff. Chin, throat, and 
fore part of neck dark chestnut, indistiactly margined all round with 
buff. Chest and upper part of breast grey, each feather with a 
black shaft terminating in a black spot; rest of breast and belly 
grey mixed with buff; sides and flanks brown tipped with buff, some 
of the feathers with chestnut blotches on the outer web; under tail-
coverts chestnut, widely tipped with white. Upper tail-coverts and 
centre pair of tail-feathers pale greyish brown, vermiculated with 

black and slightly tipped with white ; second and third pairs more 
widely tipped with white and mixed with black; remaining pairs 
black, with the last fifth white and the basal part slightly mottled

1. Tetraogallus tibetanus. 
TetraogaJlus tibetanus, Gould, P. Z. S. 1853, p. 47 [Tbibet]; id. B. 
Asia, TU. pl. 32 [text] (1853) ; Jerä. B. Ind. iii. p. 554 (lbt>3); 
Gray, List Gallince Brit. Mus. p. 83 (1867); id. Hand-l B. ii. p. 275 
(1870); Hend. fy Ilume, Lahore to Tark. p. 281 (1873) ; Seully, 
Str. F. iv. p. 182 (1870) [Sanju Pass, E. Turkestan]; David # 
Oustal. Ois. Chine, p. 391 (1877) [Moupin]; Prjev. Mongolia, 

ii. p. 127 (1876); id. in Rowley's Örn. Mise, ii/ p. 427 (1877) 
[Kansu, S. Koko-nor and N. Tibetj; Hume fy Marsh. Game B. 
Ind. i. p. 275, pl. (1878); Hume, Str. F. vii. p. 430 (1878) ; Sharp, 
Second Tark. Miss., Aves, p. 123 (1891). 
Oreotetrax tibetana, Radde, J.f. 0.1876, p. 218. 

Adult male and female. Top of the head, nape, and upper part of 
the mantle dark grey, shading into buff and greyish buff on the lower 
parts, and closely vermiculated with fine blackish lines. Feathers 
of the lower back the same, only margined on the sides with 
buff; rump and upper tail-coverts pale rufous, with the black 
vermiculations much farther apart. Lesser, median, and secondary 
coverts, scapulars, and outer secondaries blackish grey, finely vermiculated 
with buff, and widely margined with creamy white, the 
former only on the sides, the laiter all round their margins. Primaries 
and primary-coverts dull greyish brown, the former tipped 
with creamy white, most strongly marked on the innermost feathers. 
Rest of the secondaries like the primaries, but with the last part of 
the outer web white. Lores and ear-coverts white. Sides of the 

3 . TETBAOGALLTJS. 
head, throat, and neck very dark grey ; chin, middlo of throat and 
neck and ehest pure white, the latter divided frora the rest of the 
underparts by a band of dark grey. The breast, belly, sides, flanks, 
and under tail-coverts white, margined with black on the sides, 
exeept some of the lower flank-feathers, which havo only one black 
stripe down the middle. Thighs a mixture of grey and buff. Tail 
blackish, slightly tipped with rufous, the centre pair of featherb 
somewhat vermiculated with rufous. Iris brown or reddish brown. 
Bill orange-red. Legs and feet coral-red. Tarsus provided with a 
strong Munt spur in the male *. Total length 20 inches, wing 10*8, 
tail 6-2, tarsus 2*5. 

Younger speeimens differ from the adults in having the sides of 

the throat and neck black vermiculated with buff, and the whole 

of the ehest buff vermiculated with black, and with usually a few 

white feathers of the adult plumage intermixed. 

In quite young speeimens there is a white superciliary streak 
edged above and below with black ; the wing-coverts and scapulars 
are much more coarsely marked with buff on a black ground than 
in the adult, and each featber, together with those of the upper and 
lewer back, has a buff spot at its extremity : the breast and rest of 
the underparts are whitish buff, without any black streaks; the 
primaries are mottled with buff at the tip, and the terminal part of 
the outer web of the secondaries is margined and mottled with 
white. 

Hab. Thibet, ranging east to the Sanju Pass, E. Turkestan, 
west to ]ULoupin, north to Kansu and Koko-nor, and south to the 
Himalayas.

Megaloperdix himalayerisis, Bogd. Comp. Av. 2mp. Boss. fasc. i. p. 39 

(1884) ; Bleske, Mem. Ac. St Petersb. (7) xxxvi. no. 3, p. 47 
(1888) [Kuli Kalau, Turkestan]. 

Adult male. Top of the head and upper part of the mantle pale 
grey tinged with buff; a large chestnut pateh on either side of the 
nape, produced along the sides of the head as far as the eye; rest of 
the upper parts blackish grey, finely vermiculated with buff, the 
feathers of the lower back, rump, lesser, median, and secondary 
coverts and the scapulars edged on either side with buff, washed 

3 . TETRAOGALLTTS. 
with chestnut on the median and seeondary coveris. Primaries 

with the basal two-thirds white and the rest blackish grey, iinely 

mottled with rufous buff at the tips of the inner quill«; primary-

coverts blackish grey ; secondaries dark grey, with the outcr web 

vermiculatcd with buff, and asmall white paich at the base next the 

shaft. Lores, supereiliary stripes, sides of the head and neck, cliin, 

throat, and fore part of the neck white, the latter tcrminatecl by a 

dark chestnut band, which also margins it 
laterally. Chest and 

upper breast white, with wide blaek transverso bars, less marked or 

absent on the latter *. Eest of the undorparts blackish grey, iinely 

vermiculated with buff; fcathers of the sides and rlanks purer grey, 

margined with chestnut and buff, often fringod externally with black. 

Under tail-covexts white. Centre pairs of tail-feathers rufous, 

thickly mottled with black, outer pairs with chestnut ends and 

the rest of the inner web and subterminal portion of the outer 

blackish f. Iris dark brown. Bill pale horny or slaty, dark at the 

point ; cere and scale over nostril orange ; naked patch behind the 

eye yellow. Legs and feet yellowish red or orange. Tarsi provided 

with a pair of stout blunt spurs. Total length 25*5 inches, wing 

12-6, tail 7-8, tarsns 2-8. 

Aclult female. Scarcely differs in plumage from the male, but the 

spurs are absent, and generally the fcathers on the front part of the 

forehead and above the eye are buff barred with grey. Total length 

22'5 inches, wing 10*8, tail 6*8, tarsus 2-5. 

In younger exampltsWiQ chestnut patches on either side of the 

nape are more or less united, the upper part of the mantle is usually 

buff, and the outer primaries are pointcd and mottled with rufous 

buff at the extremities. 

In a cJdclc the whole of the npper parts are buff, mottled and 
blotched with black; all the feathers of the mantle, wing-coverts, 
and scapulars have a pale stripe down the terminal part of the 
shaft, dilated into a triangulär white spot at the extremity. Chest 
and breast rusty, widely tipped with white, eclged internally with 
black ; breast similar, but less rusty; tail rufous buff, barred • and 
mottled with black.

Ad tat male and fem die. DifFer from T. caspius in having the 
sides of the neck and the mantle grey, like the top of the head, the 
latter rather paler on the lower parts and separated from the rest 
of the back by a blackish band ; the rest of the iipper parts darker, 
and the edges of the wing-coverts and feathers of the lower back 
and rump margined with white, never chestnut; no white on the 
basal part of the secondaries; the chin and middle of the throat 
and neck white^ the lateral feathers of the two latter with black 
shafts and terminal black dots; the feathers of the lower part of 
the ehest with a pair of white terminal spots, one on each side of 
the shaft, and edged internally with black ; the breast and sides 
white, the belly white rnixed with blackish grey; the flanks and 
thighs blackish, finely vermiculated here and there with buff. The 
primaries with much less white on the basal parts, and the outer 
tail-feathers grey, blackish towards the extremity, and shading into 
whitish on the basal part of the inner webs. Bill blackish; legs 
and feet orange (in skin). Total length 23 inches, wing 10*9, tail 
6-8, tarsus 2-4. 

A younger male with the outer primaries pointed does not otherwise 
differ in plumage from the adult.

Adult male and female. Resemble 0. chulcar, the only tangible 
differences being that in the present species the lores are black 
instead of white (though it must be remarked that in some speeimens 
of O. chulcar the small spot of black feathers is sometimes present 
below the nasal opening), and the ear-coverts are a mixture of black 
and buff instead of chestnut. The throat-space circumscribed by 
the black "band is pure white, while as a rale in G. chulcar it is 
more or less suffused with buff. 

Male. Total length 15 inches, wing 6-6, tail 3*6, tarsus 1*8. 
Female. Total length 13*6 inches, wing 6-2, tail 3*4, tarsus 1*7. 
Hab. Mountains of Europe : Eastern Pyrenees, Alps, Carpathians, 

Apennines, and Balkans, also Sicily. [It is doubtful if this bird is 
the species found in Greece.]

(1891). * 

After a careful examination of a very large series of bireb ranging 
from the Grecian Archipelago to Kaigan in the north of China, 

4 . CAOCABIS. 115 
am satisfied that it is irapossible to distinguish moro than ono 
subspecies of 0. savatilis, and that all tlie paler and darkor raoes, 
which from time to time have been elevated to the rank oi spocies 
under a number o£ names, are merely climatic variations of ono 
and the same bird. 

The ^ ränge of this subspecies is very extensive and varied, 
for it is found in localities from sea-level to an elevation of at 
least 16,000 feet, and apparently nourislies quite as well in the 
most desert country as it does in the well-watered and cultivatod 
hüls. It is scarcely surprising that these physical surroundings 
should largely affeet the Chukar, both in size and colour, but 
between the extremes of size and colour it is easy to select from 
the series of specimens before me a number of birds showing a 
complete gradation between the two. 

The lightest coloured bird in the whole of our series is from 
Bushire, while somewhat darker specimens come from Bagdad, 
Shiraz, Afghanistan, Sindh, Ladak, &c., and the darkest are from 
the Grecian islands, Cyprus, Asia Minor, and the Himalayas, and 
other parts where the Vegetation is plentiful. Chinese specimens 
from Kaigan and the Pankow Pass have the upper parts of the 
body of a more reddish tint (pubeseens, Swinhoe), but they scarcely 
differ from the paler forms from Khusan, N. Afghanistan, and 
several other localities. 

Adult male and female. Porehead and sides of the head grey, 

shading into dull vinous in the middle and on the nape; back and 

sides of the neck and Upper part of the mantle usually grey or 

brownish grey, shading into dull vinous on the lower part of the 

mantle, and to greyish drab or grey on the lower back, rump, 

and upper tail-coverts. The inner and longer scapulars and wing-

coverts are greyish drab; the outer scapulars are bluish grey, widely 

margined all round with dull vinaceous red. Quills brown, tho 

subterminal part of the outer web of the primaries (except tho first) 

and of the inner secondaries buff. A black band across tho front 

of the forehead passes backwards on either side to tho eye, behind 

which it is eontinued down the sides of the throat, meeting its fellow 

on the front of the neck; a black patch on the chin and at either 

angle of the gape; ear-coverts chestnut; superciliary stripe, which 

commences above the eye, lores, cheeks, and throat white or whitish 

buff. Chest and breast grey, washed more or less with isabelline 

and vinous on the sides. JBelly, vent, and under tail-coverts bright 

buff. JFeathers of the sides and nanks grey at the base, buff in the 

middle, and dark chestnut at the extremity, the colours being 

divided from one another by two transversa black bars. Two 

middle pairs of tail-feathers drab-grey; outer pairs the same, but 

with the terminal half dark chestnut. Iris yellow, orange, or 

reddish brown. Bill crimson to coral-red, often dusky on the 

eulmen. Legs and feet coral-pink to deep red. The tarsus is 

generally provided with a stout, short, knob-Hke spur in the male. 

Male. Total length 14*6 inches, wing 6*7, tail 3-9, tarsus 1/9. 

lemale. Total length 13*4 inches, wing 6-5$ tail 3*8, tarsus 1"8. 

The above description and measurements are taken from Hima


 PHASIA:NID2E. 

layan specimens; the desert varieties have the upper parts washed 
with different shades of isabelline and the underparts paler. 

Younger specimens which have not quite completed their first 
moult still retain some of the outer secondaries and primaries of the 
firsfc plumage ; these have the outer webs irregularly notched with 
buff, edgecl with black, and aro minutely dotted with the latter 
colour; otherwise the plumage is similar to that of the adult. 
Bill brownish" black. Legs and feet orange-red. 

A quite young bircl has the general colour of the upper parts 
sandy brown, the mantle and wing-coverts have a buff spot at the 
extreniity of each feather, and the outer webs of the quills are 
notched and mottled with buff. The tail is sandy, finely mottled 
with buff and dusky. The underparts are whitish, most of the ehestand 
breast-feathers with paler Spots at the extremities of the shafts. 

Hab. Eanging in the west to the lonian Islands [and perhaps 
found on the mainland of Greece], in the east to China, in the 
north to Mongolia and Turkestan, and in the south to the Persian 
Gulf and apparently to Aden (0. arenarius, Hume). Island of 
St. Helena [introduced].

Caccabis rufa, var. australis,Tm£r. Jfos, 1889, p. 28 [Gran Canary]. 

Adult male and female. Differ chiefly from Ö. saocatüis in the 
following particulars :—The white superciliary stripes commence 
behind the nostril, and are more or less distinctly joined across the 
forehead. In addition to the black line which circumscribes the 
throat, the feathers of the ehest and the sides and back of the neck 
are margined on either side with black, the former very widely, the 
latter more narrowly. The flank-feathers have the basal pari pale 
grey, followed first by a narrow white, and then a narrow black 
band, and terminated by a wider one of dark chestnut. The outer 
tail-feathers are dark chestnut almost to the base. The whole 
colouring is also somewhat warmer. The male bird is provided 
with one or sometimes two pairs of blunt wart-like spurs, which 
are apparently not developed in the female. ISTaked skin round the 
eye red. Bill, legs, and feet bright coral-red. 

Male. Total length 13-6 inches, wing 6*2, tail 3*7, tarsus 1/7. 

Female. Total length 13 inches, wing 6, tail 3-6, tarsus 1*6. 

In yoimger birds the black band surrounding the throat is 
absent, there is a patch of black-edged feathers on the ehest, the 
outer primaries have the subterminal buff part of the outer web 
toothed with blackish brown, and the outer seeondaries are sandy 
brown with irregulär buff black-edged bars. Some oi the wing-
coverts, too, are sandy brown, blotched on inner web with blackish, 
and with pale buff patches or stripes down the shaffc. 

Hab. S.W. Europe: ranging in the north to Belgium and 
Switzerland, in the south to Madeira, the Azores, and Gran Canary 
Island, and in the w$£b to South and Central Italy; also to Elba, 
Corsica, and the Balearie Islands. Great Britain [introduced]. It is 

not known to oeeur in F.W. Africa.

Adult male and female. Lores, top of the head, and nape black,

tbe genns. A wide white superciliary stripe, wbich commences 
behind the lores and in front of tbe eye, is continued backwards 
on the sides of the head and shades into the neck. A blaek line 
below the eye ending in a pateh above the angle of the gape; a 
black spot on the chin and one on either side at the base of the 
lower mandible. Ear-coverts black, fringed with buff; the white 
cheeks and throat are surrounded by a wide blaek band terminating 
on either side behind the ear-coverts and continued down the 
middle of the neck. The feathers of the ear-coverts, throat, and

and upper breast grey, margined with isabelline, some of the 
feathers with a small black spot on one or both webs near the 
extremity of the margin. Middle of the lower breast and belly, 
thighs, and under tail-eoverts buff. Feathers of the sides and rlanks 
slate-grey, with the terminal part white crossed by two narrow 

black bars, the outer subterminal and the inner dividing the grey 
from the white. The tail-feathers are dark grey, shading" into 
blackish towards the extremity and tipped with buff, the two middle 
pairs are also nnely mottled, especially towards the edge of the 
webs, with buff and dusky.

Adult male. Top of the head and nape dull grey, most of the 
feathers fringed with buff in freshly moulted speeimens. The sides 
and the greater part of the back of the neck white barred with 
grey. Upper part of the mantle vinous isabelline, faintly barred 
with grey, and shading into isabelline on the rest of the Upper 
parts• the low er back, rump, and Upper tail-coverts have a row of 
V-shaped black Spots along the shaffc of each feather. Scapulars, 
median and secondary coverts finely mottled with buff, and the 
inner webs of the former are also vermiculated with black. Primaries 
and secondaries brown, the fest primary uniform, the 
remainder barred and washed on the basal half of onter web with 
rufous buff, and with whitish buff on the terminal portion ; secondaries 
mottled on the outer and somewhat on the inner web with 
buff. A black band across the forehead eontinued in a superciliary 
stripe down either side of the head. A white band from the nostrils 
to the eye eontinued behind the eye across the ear-coverts, and 
ending in a small vinous patch on the side of the neck. Chin 
whitish; cheeks, throat, and fore part of the neck grey. Ohest 
and breast delicate vinous buff; belly white, with rufous margins to 
the feathers ; yent white, under tail-coverts buff. Peathers of the 
sides and üanks vinous chestnut on the outer web, vinous fawn or 
whitish on the inner, and margined on either side with black. 
Centre pair of tail-feathers rufous buff mottled with dusky; outer 
pairs chestnut, more or less tipped with the same. Iris orange-
brown ; bill bright orange; legs and feefc greenish yellow. Total 
length 9-5 inches, wing 5*2, tau 2*4, tarsus 1*2. 

Adult female. Differs from the male in having the general eolour 
of the top of the head and upper parts uniform darker isabelline, 
irregularly barred all over with faint rufous-buff bars; the wings 
more coar&ely marked, and the inner webs of the scapulars blotched 
with black; the forehead, rest of the head, throat, sides and fore 
part of the neck whitish, marked and barred with dusky grey; 
and the rest of the underparts darker isabelline, clouded all over 
with dusky and vermiculated with blackish on the feathers of the 

sides and flanks. Iris orange - brown; bül brown ; legs and 
feet dusky yellow. Total length 9-5 inches, wing 4*9, tail 2-3, 
tarsus 1*15.

the sbaft. 

Hab. S.W. Asia, extending in tbe west to tbe Enphrates Valley, 
in tbe east to N.W. India, in tbe north to Transcaspia, and in tbe 
sontb to Aden.

Anmioperdix heyi, Goidd, B. Asia, vii. pl. 2 (1851); Adams, Ibis,

Perdix flavirostris {Rüpp. MS.), Heugl Orn. N.O.-Afr. iii. p. 914 
(1873). 

Aäult male. DifFers from the male of A. bonhami in having the 
general colour of the upper parts much paler. The top of the head 
is vinous grey, and shades gradually into uniform vinous fawn on 
the neck and back and pale isabelline on the wings, rump, and 
upper tail-coverts, which are also barred and vermiculated with 
dusky grey. The secondaries rufous buff, mottled with blackish 
grey. A white band across the forehead joining the white band 
which passes from the nostrils to the eye, and is continued behind 
over the ear-coverts. Pore part of the cheek dark chestnut; chin 
and middle of the throat rufous chestnut, rest and the head and 
throat dull vinous grey. The rest of the underparts are the same 
as in the male of A. bonhami. Total length 9-5 inches, wing 5, 
tail 2-5, tarsus 1*25. 

Adult female. Is not to be distinguished from the female of 

A. bonhami. 
Hab. Both sides of the Red Sea, extending north to the Dead 
Sea, and westwards to Egypt and Nubia, about as far south as 20° 
of N. latitude, and eastwards to Muscat, Persian Gulf.

6. MLUTCOLINTO. 
Type. 

Francolinus, Steph. in Shaw's Gen. Zool xi. pt. ii.

Chaetopus, Sioains. Classif. B. ii. p. 344 (1837) .. F. bicalcaratus.

(1852) F. pondicerianus. 
Perdicideus, Heine, J.f. 0. 1860, p. 198 F. lathami. 

Sexes usually similar or nearly siinilar, but in a few species quite 

different. 
Tail of 14 feathers and about half the length of the wing. 
Ist primary varies in length between the 7th and lOth; 4th to 

the 6th subequal and longest. 
Tarsus without spurs, or with one or more pairs. 
Throat covered with feathers. 

Range. Africa, Cyprus, and S.W. Asia. 
In F. squamatus and Fm schuetti the Ist primary is slightly shorter 
than the lOth, so that the character of the wing is somewhat 
Pheasant-like, and in these two instances may be considered in 
some degree to break down; but the length of the tail at once 
distinguishes these birds as Francolins.

p. 85 (1844) : id. Icon. ined. in Brit. Äs/nos. 630-2 : Bonap. C. B, 
xliii. p. 414 (1856). 
Francolinus tristriatus, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 882 (1856) [Cyprus]; 
Bree, Ibis, 1863, p. 115. 
Francolinus henrici, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 882 (1856) [Sindkl. 
Francolinus asiae, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 882 (1856) TAsia Minor]; 

Bree, Ibis, 1863, p. 115. 
Choetopus francolinus, Blasius, List B. Furope, p. 18 (1862). 
Francolinus francolinus, Grant, Ibis, 1892, p. 38. 

Adidt male. Top of the head blackish brown, each feather edged 
with buff; an oblong white patch situated behind the eye Covers 
the hinder part of the cheek and ear-coverts; rest of head, chin, 
and throat blaok ; a wide dark chestnut ring surrounds the neck. 
Upper back black, each feather with one or more pairs of white 
oeelli; middle back, lesser and median wing-coverts, and scapulars 
blackish brown, edged with buff, and with a submarginal tawny 
or buff band on each web. Lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts black, with narrow transverse white bars. Primarius and 
secondaries and their coverts dark brown, with rows of tawny-buff 
«pots on both webs. Whole ehest, breast, and belly black; a few 
feathers on the sides of the breast, belly, and flanks with a subterminal 
pair of white oeelli. Thighs and vent rufous, tipped with 
buff; under tail-coverts dark chestnut. Centre pair of tail-feathers 
black, barred with white like the upper tail-coverts; rest of tail-
feathers with the terminal third black, and the remainder barred 
with white. Bill black; a small blunt spur on each tarsus ; legs and 
toes orange. Iris brown. Total length 13 inches, wing 6, tail 35, 
tarsus 1*7 (speeimens from India). Total length 13*8 inches, wing 6'9, 
tail 4, tarsus 1*9 (speeimens from Cyprus, Asia Minor, <fcc). 

Adult female. G-eneral plumage of the upper parts like that of the 
male, but the upper back resembles the middle back and wing-
coverts, and the general tone of the lower back, rump, and upper 
tail-coverts is browner. The sides of the face are buff, dotted with 
black; the ear-coverts blackish brown • chin and throat white; the 
chestnut collar is conflned to the nape ,* front and sides of the throat 
and rest of underparts white mixed with buff, with Y-shaped black 
bars, which vary greaÜy in intensity, being quite faint in some 
(? very old) speeimens, while in the majority they are very clearly 
defmed, and divide the extremity of each feather into paired white 

134 
PHASIAHIDJS. 

ocelli. Iris brown. Bill, upper mandible dusky horny, lower pale 

flcshy; lcgs and feet brownish red. Total length 12*6 inches, 

wing 5-9, tail 3-5, tarsus 1-6 (Indian specimens). Total length 

13-8 inches, wing 6% tail 3-9, tarsus 1-9 (Cyprus &c. speeimens). 

Immature male has the larger part of the feathers of breast and 

bolly ornamented with a subterminal pair of white ocelli. 

In still youoiger specimens tbe whole of tbe feathers of the under


parts, with the exception of a few in the middle of the ehest and 

breast, have a subterminal pair of white ocelli; while the flanks are 

buff or white, with large V-shaped black bars ; the chestnut eollar 

is narrow and incomplete. and the throat is whitish buff mixed with 

black. 

In a quite young bird the plumage is like that of the f emale, and the 

the chestnut eollar is only indicated by a few rufous feathers on nape. 

It is to be remarked that Indian specimens, although absolutely 

identical in plumage with those from Cyprus, 
Asia Minor, and 

Persia, are considerably smaller in size. 

Indian specimens: wing 5*7-6 inches. 

Cyprus &c. specimens : wing 6*6-6*9 inches. 

Hab. From Cyprus, Palestine, and Asia Minor, through Persia 

eastwards to Northern and Central India, Assam, Cachar, Tipperah, 

and Manipur. (Apparently extinet in Sicily.)

p. 539 (1878); mime, Str. F. iii. p. 171 (1875) [Upper Pegul;

Adiät male. Differs from the male of F. jjictus in having tho 
crown of the head surrounded by a band o£ rnfoiis buff; the scapulars 
are chestnut or chestnut and blaek spotted with white; the buff 
spots and bars on the primaiics and secondaries much reduced in 
size; the centre pair of tail-feathers have the last third uniform 
blaek like the outer pairs ; the lores and superciliary stripe black ; 
a black band from the gape, which rnns down the side of the throat 
and surrounding the ear-coverts joins the superciliary; the rest of 
the sides of the face, chin, and throat pure white; and the under 
fail-eorerts rufous buff. Iris dark brown; bill black; legs dusky 
orange. Total length 12-6 inches, wing 5*5, tail 2-8, tarsus 1-6. 

The iuimafrtre male resembles the adult female, but the scapulars 
are mixed with chestnut and the feathers of the ehest and upper 
breast are partly ocellated like those of the adult male. 

- Mull femah. Differs from the male in having the Upper back, 
scapulars, and wing-coverts black, margined with brownish and 
with shorfc trani&verse bar^ and spots ol buff; the scapulars not 
conspicuously mixed with chestnut, though most of them have a 
chestnut stripe down the outer half of the shaft; the lower back, 
nirap, and upper tail-coverts blaek, tipped with brownish buff and 
barred with pale buff; the sides of the head washed with rufous 
buff; and the underparts whitish buff, barred with black. Total 
length 12*8 inches, wing 5-6, tail 3, tarsus 1-5. 
In the immature female the rufous-buff band surrounding the 
crown is not developed. The teather^ of the neck, ehest, and upper 
back have wide buff shaft-stripes, and the black bars on the underparts 
are broken and irregulär. 

Hab. Indo-Chinese countries; Burma, Siam, Cochin China,Hainan, 
and 8. China. Not found in Tenasserim or the Malay Peninsula. 
Madagascar?, Eeunion, and Mauritius [introduced].

Adidt male. Top of the liead olive-grey, shading into grey on the

dotted or marked with biack and with white shafts; iower back, 
rump, and upper tail-coverts olive-brown, with paler margin•> and 
markings. Primaries, primary-coverts, and becondaries dark brown, 
the middle part of the outer webs of the primaries margiiied with 
white; the outer webs of the secondaries margiaed with ehestnut 
and buff, and in the outer ones barred and marked with che^tnut; 
a black band commences on the lores, and passing through the eye 
circumscribes the top of the head, dividing it from the grey rheek, 
ear-eoverts, and sides of the neck. Chin, throat, and front of neck 
black. Chest and breast black, each feather with a white lieartshaped 
subterminal spot. Sides and flanks olive-brown, with white 
blaek-edged shaffc-stripes. Belly and under tail-coverts whiti^h fiiiff, 
the latter more or less spotted and barred with black. Centn? t?iilfeathers 
like the upper tail-coverts; three outer pair-s blackisli brown» 
marked with rufous and tipped with white. Total lengtli 11/ inches, 
wing 5-6, tau 2-7, tarsus 1*7


Adult feniale differs from the male in having the whole groimd-* 

colour of the top of the head and upper parts olive-brown, faintly 

and irregularly barred with rufous buff and black, many of the 

scapulars and wing-coverts blotched with Hack; and the chesfe


and breast-feathers are wideiy margined oufeide the black with 

brown. Total length 9#5 inches^ wing 5*4, tau 2-4, tarsus I-CL 

Young birds resemble the female, but the chin and throat are 

white; the general colour of the upper parts is nraeh more uniform ; 

the scapulars, secondaries, lesser and median coverts are mostly dull 

ohestmit; the scapulars and coverts each with an oval or irregulär 

black blotch, edged internally with buff at the inner web. The 

feathers on the underpaxts are whitish, with a wide black xnazgin 

on each side. Nestlings have the top of the head, back, and rump 

deep chesfcnut; no white shafte to the feathers of the upper parte, 

but most of the scapulars and lesser and median coverte have a 

white triangulär dofc at the extremity of the shaft; ofherwise the 

plumage is much the same as the above.

142 PHASIANIDiE. 

Acluli male and female. Forehead rufous ; top of the head umbre


brown; neck whitish grey with narrow black bars; back, rump, 

scapulars, and wing-coverts a mixture of cbestnut and brown, barred 

with. buff and mostly with white shafts, some of the scapulars with 

the ground-colour of the inner web blackish brown; upper tail-

coverts brown barred with buff; primaries and secondaries brownish 

grey, the basal part of the outer web of the outer primaries and 

uearly the whole of the outer web of the inner primaries and second


aries barred andmottled with ruf ous. Superciliary stripe and eheeks 

rufous buff; ear-coverts chestnut-brown; lores whitish ; a band of 

feathers from the gape to the back of the eye cdged with black; 

centre of chin and throat rufous buff, margined all round by first 

an indistinct black and then a pale buff band, the black band 

forming a patch at the base of the throat; ehest a mixture of buff 

and rufous, with narrow somewhat irregulär blackish bars ; rest of 

the underparts pale buff, with irregulär wavy transverse lines of 

black, some of the feathers on the sides spotted with chestnut; 

centre of belly ofien uniform buff; centre pair of tail-feathers like 

the upper tail-coverts, outer pairs chestnut, shading into black 

towards the extremity, and tipped with greyish buff: iris dark 

brown; bill horny brown, pale rlesh below; legs and feet dull red. 

A sharp pair of spurs in the male. Total length 12*5 inches, wing 

5*8, tail 3m5, tarsus 1*6. 

The immature mal es and females differ only from the adult in 

having the throat white, the upper part of the outer webs of the 

outer primaries marked with buff, and no spurs.

Adult male. Top of the head and ear-coverts chestnut-brown, 
rest of the head and nape rufous buff, usually paler on the chin and 
throat and in some speeimens white; neck, ehest, and rost of underparts 
white, shading into buff on the belly, flanks, and under tau


144 
PHASIANIDiE. 

covcrts, and widely barred with black. Some of the flank-feathers 
are "blotchcd on the outer web with chestmit; rest of the upper 
parts, scapulars, and wing-eoverts (except the greater primary-
coverts) a mixture of chestmit and bufT, with wide bars of black or 
dark grey, intorruptod on ihe back, rump, and scapulars by rather 
wide buff shaft-stripes ; primaries, primary-coverts, and secondaries 
greyish black, the latter barred with rufous on the outer web; tail 
rufous buff, barred with greyish black. In some specimens the bars 
on the under tail-coverts are obsolete and in others nearly so. Iris 
light hazel-brown ; bill dark ashy horny, yellow at gape;" tarsi and 
feet dark bright yellow; a well-developecl pair of spurs. Tota 

length 11 inehes, wing 5-5, tail 3. tarsus 1*5. 
Adiät female. DifFers from the male in having a black superciliary 
streak passing down the side of the neck, a second commencing on 
the lores passes along the side of the throat and joining that from 
the othcr side eompletely circumscribes the throat with a black 
line; neck and ehest dull chestnut, mixecl with grey and with white 
shafts; the rest of the upper parts sometimes greyer, with the bars 
and markings less regulär : iris bright hazel; bill dusky, basal part 
chrome-yellow; tarsi and feet bright ehrome. ISTo spurs. 
Immature male has the black superciliary and malar stripes of 
the female partially developed, the outer webs of the primaries are 
narrowly margined and marked with buff; otherwise the plumage is 
the same as that of the adult male. 
In a still younger bird the plumage is nearly like the females, 
but the ehest is mixed with the white and black barred feathers of 
the adult. 
In quite youiuj eocamples the shaft-streaks on the upper parts are 
stronger than in the adults; there are no traces of black lines on 
the sides of the head ; the chin and throat are whitish, and the rest 
of the underparts are more or less barred and spotted with blaek. 
Hab. East, South, and South-west Africa.

7. Eraacoliiras scMegeli 
Francolinus schlegelii, Seugl J.f. O. 1863, p. 275 [Bongo], 1864, 
p. 271 [Djur and Kosanga R.]; id. JPeterm. Geogr. Mitth. 1869, 
p. 4155 id. Orn. N.O.-Aß; ii. p. 898, pl. xxx. (1873) j Schaech, 
Mmn. Soc. Zool. Fr. iv. p. 379 (1891) [part.]; Grant, Ibis, 1892, 
p. 41. 
? Francolinus buckleyi (Shelley), Grant, Ibis, 1892, p. 41 [Accra], 
Aäult male. Top of the head and back of the neck as far as the 
nape reddish brown ; ear-coverts blackish brown; rest of the head 
and neck buff, palest on the throat and darkest on the nape. Back 
and scapulars light red mixed with brownish grey, with whitish or 
buff shaft-streaks edged with black and irregulär narrow transverse 
black markings across the webs. Scapulars have a large blackish-
brown patch covering the middle third of the inner web. Shoulders 
and wing-coverts light red. Rump and upper tail-coverts buff, 
irregularly barred and vermiculated with blackish grey. Primaries 
brownish grey; secondaries with the outer web light red, the inner 
brownish grey. Taii light red. Chest, breast, belly, and flanks 
white, with transverse bars of black, some of the latter with light 
red and chestnnt black-edged spots on the outer webs. Thighs and 
vent white. Under tail-coverts pale buff, with a few wide-set, 
very narrow blackish bars. A pair of sharp spurs on the tarsi. 
Hab. Bongo, Equatorial Africa, and perhaps Accra on the West 
Coast. 
In Captain Shelley's collection there are two female specimens 
which were obtained by him at Accra in 1872 and may belong to 
the present species. They differ from the female of F. coqui in 
having the black lines over the eye and round the throat almost 
obsolete, the greater part of the basal two-thirds of the inner 
primaries and secondaries chestnnt, and the general tone of the top 
of the head and upper parts duH grey, with only narrow bars of 
rufous buff here and there. Possibly these birds may represent 
a distinct species, but in the absence of male specimens it is impossible 
to say. Shonld the Accra bird prove new, the species may 
stand as Francolinus bwkhyi, a MS. name given by Captain Shelley, 
who believes his birds to be distinct.

ÄcUU male. Top of the hcad, ear-coverts, back, wings, rump,

^tc^wZi s/iß/ö. Top of the head umber-brown, with black bases and 
centres; neck surrounded by a eollar of dark chestnut feathers, 
widely edged with white on either web. Upper back, scapulars, and 
wing-coverts chestnut, shading into uraber-brown in tlio middle of 
each feather, and with a wide white shaft-stripc narrowly margined 
with black; some of the longer scapulars nearly black on the 
terminal half of the inner web. Lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts urnber-brown. Primaries and secondaries brownish black, 
the outer webs of the inner primaries with the basal half chestnut 
and the secondaries with the outer web edged with buff. A narrow 
black, followed by a wider white, superoiliary stripe; a narrow 
black line from the base of the nostril to the eye, and continued 
behind the eye above the ear-coverts, which are brown; rest of the sides 
of the head white, the feathers of the fore part of the cheek tipped 
with black and the hinder with chestnut« Chin and throat white. 
Chest buff, with dark chestnut shaft-stripes, widening out into a club-
shaped spot at the extremity of each feather; rest of the underparts 
buff with pale shai'ts and fincly clouded and pencilled with 
greyish-black except on the middle of the belly and vent. Contre 
pair of tail-feathers warm brown, outer pairs nearly black, washed 
with chestnut towards the base. Iris hazel. Legs and feet red; a 
long sharp spur on each tarsus. Total length 12 inches, wing 6*5, 
tail 3*8, tarsus 1*7. 
Immature males resemble the adult female, but are provided with 
a well-developed spur on each tarsus. 
Adult female. Differs from the male only in having the middle 
back, scapulars, and wing-coverts covered with wavy narrow bars 
of bufT and lines of black; the lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts mottled with black and whitish buff. Iris hazel. Legs red. 
Hab. South Africa: on the east from the Marikwa R. and the 
Transvaal to the Zambesi and westwards to the north of Damara


land.

16. Francolinus uluensis. (Plate IY.) 
Francolinus 
uluensis, Grant, Ibis, 1892, p. 44 [ülu Coimtry, East 
Africa]; Sharpe, Ibis, 1802, p. 551. 

It is somewhat doubtful whether two spccimens collected by 

152 
PHASIANIDÄ 

Mr. F. J. Jackson, at Machako's, in the Hin Conntry, should be included 
in F. gutturalis or not. One would certainly expect to find 
them distinct from the Abyssinian birds, and on comparing them 
with tjpical speeimens from Abyssinia the differences, although few, 
seem to justify my sepaxating them nnder the above name. Both 
speeimens are males with fully-developed spurs, and they differ 
from F. gutturalis in the following particulars:—On the side of 
the neck, between the continuations of the rufous-bufl superciliary 
and cheek stripes, and behind the ear-coverts, lies a well-marked 
triangulär patch, an inch or more in length, of white feathers with 
black" tips. There is no trace of this in F. gutturalis, but it is 
equally distinct in F. africanus from S. Afriea. Again, the feathers 
of the breast and belly, instead of having black shaft-stripes, are 
covered with irregulär arch-shaped black bars, which give these 
parts an ocellated appearance much as in F. africanus. The tarsus 
is longer than in F. gutturalis, 1*6 as against 1*4. Total length 
12 inches, wing 6-5, tail 2*9, tarsus 1*6. 

Sab. East Afriea : Flu Conntry. 

a. $ 
ad, sk. Machako's, Ulu Conntry, Feb. F. J. Jackson, Esq. [P.]. 
(Type of the species.)

the middle of the back of the neck, widening at the base of the 
neck into a somewhat enlarged triangulär patch of black and white 
feathers. A second pair of bands of black and white feathers 
arising elose to the former, just above the angle of the gape, bound 
the chin and throat and unite at the base of the latter, where they 

6 . FRATTCOLINTTS. 
155 

form a patch of white feathers edged and spotted with black. Rost 
of the sides of the face and neck rust-colour, as also tho outcr part 
of tlie chin and throat, centre part white, liest of tho uppor parts 
umber-brown, blotched on one or both wobs with black, barred 
with buff, and with buff shaft-stripes. Primaries and secondarios 
and their coverts light chestnut, mottled with brown at the tips. 
Chest and breast light chestnut, with buff shaft-stripes, and höre and 
there irregularly barred or spotted with blackish. Belly buff, 
blotched on one or both webs with chestnut; sides, flanks, thighs, 
and under tail-coverts buff, barred with brown and blotched höre 
and there with chestnut. Tail brownish black, tippod with light 
brown and barred narrowly with buff. Tarsi with or without 
small blunt spurs. Total length 13 inches, wing 6-Q, tau 2-6,

21. Francolinus gariepensis. 
Francolinusgariepensis,Smith,IIIZooLS.Afr.pls. 83 [ c? ] & 84 [ § ] 
(1849) [Caledon & Vaal Es.]; Gray, List Gall B. iii. p. 33 
(1844); id. Gen. B. iii. p. 505 (184G); id. List Gallium Brit Mus. 

p. 50 (1867); Layard, B. 8. Afr. p. 272 (1807); Gray, Hanä-l. B. 
ii. p. 2Q5, no. 9657 (1870); Fi/nsoh 8> Hartl. Vby. Ost-Afr. p. 582 
(1870) [part.] ; Ayres, Ibis, 1878, p. 282 [Transvaal] ; Sharpe, in 
Layard's B. 8. Afr. p. 599 (1884) [part.]; Ayres, Um, 1880, 
p. 292 [Potchefstroom, Limpopo R.]; Grant, Ibis, 1890, p. 347;

Ibis, 1892, p. 45. 
Choetopus gariepensis, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 882 (1856). 

Adult male and female. Top of the head and nape black, each 
feather margined with rufous; rest of the upper parts umber-brown 
or greyish brown, naost of the feathers blotched on one or both 
webs with deep chestnut and black, barred with buff, and with buff 
shaft-stripes edged externally with black. From bebind the nostrils 
arise a pair of superciliary stripes of mixed black and white feathers, 
which pass along the sides of the neck, widely apart from one 
another and never uniting at the back of the head as in F. levaillanti. 
A seeond pair of white and black bands arise behind the gape, and 
Surround the white chin and throat. Sides of the face rufous buff. 

156 PHASIANIDJS. 

Feathors of the fore part of the neck rust-colour, paler towards the 
shaft, and with a black subterminal mark on either web. Chest and 
rest of Widerparts bright buff. All the f eathers (exeept those of the 
middlc of tho belly and vent, which are uniform, and the linder tau-
coverts, which are barred with black) are heavily blotched on one or 
both webs with dark chestnut, and dotted or margined with black 
near the extremity; some of the long flank-feathers are also barred 
with black on the outer web. The primaries and primary-eoyerts are 
chestnut mottled with brown at the extremity ; secondaries paler 
and barred with brown. Tail blackish brown, barred with buS 
and tipped with pale buff. In most the male examx)les possess f airlycleveloped 
spurs and the females clo not; but there are exeeptions, 
such as a female with a moclerately-developed spur on the leffc leg 
and none on the right, while a male, which is apparently perfectly 

adult, has the spurs represented by a mere rudimentary pair of 
knobs on the tarsi. Iris hazel; bill dusky yellow at the base; 
tarsi and feet dusky yellow. Total length 13*5 inches, wing 6*83 
tail 3*1, tarsus 1*6.

27. Francoliiras griseostnatus. 
Francolinus 
griseostnatus, Grant, Ibis, 1890, p. 349, pl. x, [Quanza

Acliilt male. Top of the head greyish brown; lores, cheeks, ear-
coverts, superciliary stripes, and sides of throat reddish white, paler 
in front of and behind the eye. Feathers of the back of the neck,

the scapulars and outer secondaries are also irregularly vermiculated 
and barred with black. Wing-coverts, lower back, rump, and upper 
tail-coverts umber-brown finely vermiculated with dusky brown and

inner webs, vermiculated and irregularly banded on both webs with 
black. Chin and middle of throat white. Feathers of the front of 
the neck and upper ehest rufous chestnut, widely edged with whitish 
grey. Breast, belly, thighs, and under tail-coverts with wide dull 
rufous shaft-stripes, slightly vermiculated on the flanks with black. 
Tail rufous chestnut, the middle feathers pale buff on the edges of 
webs, and all transversely vermiculated with black, though on the 
outer feathers this is confined to the extremity. Under surface of 
wings silver-grey, vermiculated with very dull rufous buff. A pair 
of long sharp spurs on the tarsi. Bill dark brown5 the tip, basal 
part, and lower mandible yellow. Legs andfeet yellow ; spurs dark 
brown. Total length 12*5 inches, wing 6*3, tail 3-2, tarsus 1*7.

chestnut and with a wide raquet-shaped black shaft-stripe, within 
which, along the shaft itself, is a clear line of buff sueeeeded by a 
detached subterminal V-shaped spot of the same colour: fianks 
and under tail-coverts buff, with wide black shaft-stripes. Tail 
black, barred and clouded with rufous buff. The male has two pairs 
of spurs, the second (upper) pair being rauch shorter and less pointed,

Adult male and female. Top of the head reddish brown; forehead 
and a patch between the angle of the gape and the cheek 
black; ear-coverts pale brown. Superciliary stripes, cheeks, sides 
of the throat, and back of the neck white with black shaft-stripes. 
^lantle rufous brown, each feather widely margined with whitish 
buff; back, scapnlars, and wing-coverts like the mantle, but the pale 
buff edges are very irregulär and most of the feathers are also 
longitudinally or transversely barred with buff. Lower back, rump, 
and npper tail-coverts umber-brown, darker along the shafts. 
Primaries buff, darker towards the base of the inner web, brown 
along the shaft, and mottled with the same colour at the extremity; 
the basal part of the outer web of the outer primaries (where the 
web widens) and the whole of the outer web of the inner primaries 
is barred with dark brown : this gives the basal part of the wing, 
when closed, a marked barred appearance peculiar to F. clappertoni 
and the allied species. Secondaries reddish brown, barred transversely 
on the outer webs with buff, edged externally with dark 
brown, and on the inner webs obliquely and irregularly with rufous, 
Chin, throat, and front of neck white. Chest and rest of the underparts 
creamy buff, with wide blackish-brown club-shaped shaft-
stripes to each feather• some of the flank-feathers are also blotched 
with deep chestnut. Tail brown, with irregulär wavy bars of buff 
edged externally with darker brown. The male is armed with two 
pairs of spurs, the upper pair being shorter and biunter. Eoth 
mandibles blackish brown, yellowish at the base. Naked skin 
round eye, legs and feet red. Total length 14 inches, wing 7*4, 
tau 3-1, tarsus 2-3. 

Hdb. Central Africa: Kordofan, Darfur, Bornu.

Immatiire male. Above ashy brown, spotted and dotted with

Top of the head dark brown, with a little space on the forehead 
blaek, behind which there is a narrow white band, which is prolonged

Ear-coverts reddish brown; sides of the head, neck, and underparts

not. Ter. Brem. vii. p. 118 (1881) [Mahagi, Albert Nyanza]; Shelley,

Achdt male and female. Lores and front of the head black, shading

and buff, the shafts are reddish brown, and most of the feathers 
have a wide black shaft-patch becoming pointed at the extremity, 
this is most marked on the scapulars, which, with the wing-coverts

marked with buff. Primaries and secondaries dark brown, the 
former toothed on the outer web with buff and irregularly barred

with buff and often with a lanceolate buff patch within the black : 
breast and belly the same, but the terminal portion of the black is 
circumscribed by the buff, and forms an irregulär oval or round

13-5 inches, wing 6*8, tail 3*2, tarsus 2*2. 

The younger male, with only one pair of blunt spurs developed, 
has the upper parts and wing-coverts more spotted and barred with 
buff than the older males.

6. FEANCOLINTTS. 
Sharpe, in Gates" Matabele L. p. 323 (1881) [Makalapsi R.l; 
Sharps'8 ed. Layard's B. S. Afr. p. 592 (1884) ; Ayres, Ibis, 188(3, 

p. 292 [Limpopo R.]; Schaeck, Mem. Soc. Zool. Fr. iv. p. 345

Perdix leckoho, Smith, Rep. Evp. Öentr. Afr. p. 54 (1836). 
Ckoatopus natalensis, JBonap. C. JR. xlii. p. 882 (1856). 


Adult male a>iä female. Eeathers of the lores and forehoad a 
rnixture of black and whitish buff; restof the upperparts likethose 
of F. icterorhynchus, but only the feathers of the neck are black 
Irregularly margined with white, and none of the rump-feathors 
have black shaft-stripes. The ear-coverfcs are pale brown, the rest 
of the sides of the face, chin, and throat white, each feather with a 
subterminal round black spot. Chest, breast, and belly vary greatly 
in the arrangement of the markings in different individuals. In 
some specimens the ground-colour is pale buff, with a black shaft-
stripe on the basal two-thirds of each feather, and outside it a black 
band parallel to the margin, in others the feathers are tolerably 
evenly barred with V-shaped black bars, and between these two 
extremes every intermediate arrangement can be found. These 
diii'erences have apparently nothing to do with age or sex. The 
flanks, thighs, and under tail-coverts buff, barred with brownish 
black. Primaries and secondaries brown, the former speckled with 
buff on the outer web, and sometimes also slightly on the inner, the 
latter irregularly barred and vermiculated with buff on both webs. 

Tail dark brown, with irregulär wavy bars of buff and black. The 
male is provided with one or two pairs of spurs, when the seeond 
pair are present they are small and blunt. One female specimen 
has a blunt spur developed on the left tarsus, the others have none. 
Iris dark hazel; bill and legs coral-red. 


Male. Total length 13-5 inches, wing 7*2, tail 3*8, tarsus 1*9. 
Female. Total length 12 inches, wing 6*3, tail 3, tarsus 1*8. 
Immature birds have the black patches on the feathers of the 

upper parts much more strongly developed than the adults, and 
narrow white shaft-streaks to the feathers of the mantle, chest, and 
scapulars; the breast and belly are widely barred and mottled with 
brownish black.

In younger male speeimens the heart-shaped Spots on the ehest 

and rest of underparts are browner, and many of those on the breast 

are mottled with rufous buff. 

In a still younger speeimen the underparts generaüy resemble 

those of the female, but are paler, and most of the feathers of the 

ehest, breast, and flanks are mottled with black, and here and there 

margined with buff, like those of the adult male. The base of the 

throat and front of the neck resemble the adults, but the ground


colour of the feathers is pale rufous buff instand of white. The 

chin and rest of the throat are pale rufous burr.

but differs in having the underparts a dull orange-briek eolour;

tail 3*7, tarsus 1*9.

flanks with the whole of the middle of the feathers brown, and only 
the sides buff, vermiculated with dark brown. TJnder tail-coverts 
dark brown, with or without buff margins. Tail blackish brown, 
irregularly barred and mottled with rufous buff. Iris dark reddish 
brown. Bill and feet orange. The male is provided with one or 
two pairs of spurs, the lower pair long and sharp, and the upper, 
when present, short; the female has none. 

Male. Total length 13*5 inches, wing 7'3, tau 3-5, tarsus 2-1. 

Female. Total length 12*5 inches, wing 6-6, tail 3, tarsus 1*9.

Adult male. Upper surface resembles that of F. squamatus, to 
which species it is very closely allied, but differs in haying the 
feathers of the neck and mantle more widely margined, and with 
grey instead of white; none of the scapiüars barred with buff; the 
chest and rest of the underparts like the mantle, but the brown of 
the middle part is not so dark and merges gradually into the grey 
margins. Iris brown; bill and legs coral-red. Total length 13 
inches, wing 6*9, tail 3*4, tarsus 2*1. 

Adult female. Differs from the male in having the margins of 
the feathers on the middle of the breast and beEy pale buff instead 
of dull grey. Total length 12-5 inches, wing 6-6, tail 3-2, 
tarsus 1*9.

the upper parts the shaft-stripes are wider, and most of the 
feathers of the lower back and scapulars are barred and spotted 
with black.

breast and belly mach less conspicuously edged with chestnut, and 
the tarsi without spurs. Total length 12 inches, wing ß<83 tail 3

Adidt male andfemale. Lores whitish, edged and sometimes tipped

whitish-buff #shafts. Back and sides of the neck brown, each

shading into grey towards the margins, and each with a mode 
rately wide white shaft-stripe, widest at the extremity; the outer 
soapxdars, rump, and upper tail-coverta are also finely vermiculated

brown, the outer primaries with the outer web margined with buff

PHASIANIDJE. 

and with a large patch of the same colour on the outer half of the 
inner web, secondaries thickly vermiculated with buff on the outer 
web and on the tip of the inner. Ear-coverts brown ; feathers on 
the sides of the face white, with brown shafts. Chest, breast, and 
thighs dull brown, with very wide white shaft-stripes extending 
nearly halfway to the base of the feathers, so that white is the pTedominating 
eoJour of tho chest and breast. Belly, sides, and flanks 
similarly coloured; but the brown parts are mostly duH reddish 
chestnut, and the basal half is edged on either web with pure white» 
linder tail-coverts buff, dotted on the sides with black. Tail rufous 
"buff, thickly vermicnlated with black. Iris brown. Legs reddish. 
dusky; bill dusky, gape reddish ; naked skin round the eyes, ehin5 
and throat searlet, shading inth yellow on the neck. Male with a 
sharp pair of spurs, often supplemented by a second rudimentary 
blunt pair.
