8 . EHIZOTHERA. 
183 

scapizlars, rump, and upper tail-coverts, which aro vermiculated 
with pale buff and black. More of the primaries (about seven) 
have the large buff patch on tbe inner web; and all the feathers 
of the ehest and nnderparts have the basal two thirds inostly dark 
chestnut, while the shaft-stripe is little more than a moderately 
large white triangulär spot situated at the extremity of cach 
feather. 

Younger spemnens have the scapnlars, seeondaries, rump, upper 
tail-coverts, and tail barred with buff edged with black; primaries 
blotehed and mottled with buff to the extremities.

Adult male. Top of the head rieh brown; back of the neck grey, 
broaclly edged on one or botb webs with black, and irregularly 
barred herc and there with pale buff and rust; middle feathers of 
tlio upper back reddish brown, largely blotcbed on eitber web with 
black and with one or two oblique wavy rust-coloured bars, those 
on the sides have a wide pale buff shaft-stripe and the outer web 
greyish vermiculated with buff and dusky and partially edged with 
chestnut and black. Lower back, rump, and npper tail-coverts grey 
mottled with pale buff, and some have black spots at the end of the 
shaft. The scapnlars and outer secondaries are chestnut vermiculated 
with buff and dusky, and margined round the extremity with 
black ofton tipped with buff. The primaries, secondaries, and 
primary-coverts are brown, with irregulär bars of rufous buff on the 
outor web, the outer secondaries being also washed with rufous 
towards the extremities. Eest of the wing-coverts buff mottled 
with grey or black, and with a large buff-coloured patch at the 
extremity. Eest of the head, chin, throat, and upperside of the 

neck rusty chestnut; the edges of the superciliary stripe and ear-
coverts and a narrow line of feathers from the nostril to the gape 
blackish. Eest of the neck and ehest grey, shading into rufous-
buff on the breast and rest of underparts. Tail reddish brown 
with wavy transverse bars of buff and black. Iris light brown. 
Bill black. Eeet reddish grey or white. Tarsi provided with a 
pair of short stout spurs. Total length 14*6 inches, wing 7*7, tail 
3*5, tarsus 2'2. 

An immature male has the lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts bright buff clouded with dusky, as in the adult female, and 
the feathers of the ehest are rufous buff, mixed with grey towards 
the shaft- otherwise the plumage is much the same as in the 
adult* 

A quhe young male resembles the female in general plumage, but 
the feathers all round the neck have buff shaft-stripes and the 
chin, throat, and cheeks, middle of the belly, and thighs are 
whitish. 

Adult female. Differs from the adult male in having the neck and 
check rufous chestnut, and the lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts buff without much grey. Iris reddish brown. Bill black. 
Feet pale flesh-colour or whitish. Tarsi provided with a short 
stout pair of spurs. Total length 13*6 inches, wing 7*7, tail 3*3, 

tarsus 2*1. 
Hab. Same as that of genus.

9. PERDIX. 
Tvüe 
Perdix, Brisson, Orn. i. p. 219 (1760) F. perdix.

Tail of 16-18 feathers, subequal, tho outer pair being only a 
little shorter than the middle, whieh are rather more than half the 
length of the wing. 

The Ist primary falls between 7th and 8th, and the 4th is rather 
the longest. 
Tarsus, without spurs, equals the middle toe and claw. 

Range. Palsearctic region.

widely barred with black.

feathers (except at the extremity) mostly

Padüx MßpaHieiiHS, Eeiehenow, Ber. Aüg. Deutsch, orn. Ges. 17th 
Marcb, IBM, p«5 [Corunna]. 
Muli male. Top of the bead and nape brown. Most of tbe 
tetfafiors with s narrow rafons-bnff sbaft-stripe somewbat dilated 

188 PHASTANIJXas. 

and tipped with black at the extremity; back and sides of the 
neck brownish. grey, sbading into brownish buff on the back, rump, 
and upper tail-coverts, and closely marked with narrow wavy 
black cross-bars and lines; the feathers of the back nsually with 
ill-defined subterminal chestnut cross-bars, which become strong 
and well-marked on tho rump and upper tail-coverts. Outer 
secondaries, scapulars, lesser, median, and secondary coverts 
brownish buff, paler towards the cxtremities, thickly vermieulated 
with black, with a chestnul blotch on either web, and well-defined 
pale buff shaft-stripes. Primaries, primary-coverts, and rest of 
socondaries dark brown, with rather wide-set buff cross-bars on 
both webs, though in the latter they are less regulär mä. more 
broken. Forehead, lores, superciliary stripes, cheeks, chin, throat, 
and front of neck dull rufous ; ear-eoverts rather browner. Chest 
and breast pale grey, finely vermieulated with black Hnes; below a 
wide horseshoe-shaped dark chestnut patch edged above with pale 
rufous or white. Belly and thighs whitish, vermieulated with 
black on the upper parts. Under tail-coverts dirty buff, vermieulated 
with black. Sides and ilanks the same, with narrow buff 
shaft-stripes and wide subterminal chestnut cross-bars. Centre 
pair of tail-feathers closely mottled with rufous buff and black, 
somewhat paler towards the margins, second pair the same, but more 
rufous towards the shaft, remainder of the feathers chestnut tipped 
with buff. Iris dark brown. Bill blackish brown. Legs and feet 
bluish grey. Total length 12-6 inches, wing 6-2, tail 3*5, tarsus 1*7. 

The young male after the first monlt resembles the adult, but 
the general colouring of the pluinage is perhaps not quite so rieh. 
The legs and feet yellowish brown, and the first primary is pointed 
instead of round. 

Adult female, Differs from the male in the following points:— 
The sides of the neck are brownish, each feather with a narrow buff 
shaft, somewhat dilated towards the extremity; the lesser and 
median wing-coverts and the scapulars have the ground-colour of 
the feathers mostly black with wide-set transverse buff bars; and 
the horseshoe mark on the breast is recluced to a few chestnut 
spots on either side, or sometimes entirely absent. (In a harren 
female there is a very large horseshoe mark ; and the wing-coverts 
have one web of each feather like that of the male, and the othor 
with normal buff bars.) Total length 12*3 inches, wing 6, tail 3*2, 
tarsus 1*65. 

The young female after the first moult resembles the adult, but 
the horseshoe mark on the lower breast is large and well-marked 
in the great majority of speeimens, and it is the exception to find 
young birds in which it is rudimentary or absent. Legs and feet 
yellowish brown. 

In quite young birds the whole of the Upper parts and the chest 
and breast are"brownish buff, and each feather of the mantle, chest, 
and breast has a buff or whitish black-edged shaft-stripe. The 
adult plumage first makes its appearance on the sides of the chest 
and breast, and on the sides, fianks, rump, and upper tail-coverts; 

9. PERBIX. 
189» 

while at the same time the whole tau, the inner primaiy <md 
seccmdary quills, and the lesser and median wing-covort* are 'rc~ 
newed. Legs and feet yellowish brown. 

Hab. Europe and Western and Central Asia: ranging wostwarda 
to NTorway and the British Isles; eastwards to the Barabinska 
bteppe and Altai Mountains; southwards to tho vallcy of the 
Bouro, Naples, the Caucasus, Asia Minor, and North Persia.

montana, of wlrich th.e synonymy is added in the fooinote * :— 

*• Perdix montana, Briss* Orn. i. p. 224, pl. xxi. %. 2 (1760); Lath. Ind. 
Orn. ii. p. 646 (1790); Sechst Mal Deutscht, iii. p. ,554 (1793); FMM* 

N. Dict. d'Hist JSTat. xxv. p. 226 (1817); Sieph, in Shaw*® Gm. ZooL xL 
p. 344 (1819) ; Vieitt. TaßL Ffacyel. MSth. I p. 210, pl. 94. %. 1 (1823); 
Vieilk Faun. Frang. p. 250, pl. 108. %. 2 (1828); Namm. Wa£„ Vm. 
Deutschi. Ti. p. 482 (1833); Jauhert 4" Lapomm. Rieh. Orn. p. 421 
(1859). 
La Perdrix de Monlagne, Buff. Eist. Nat Ois. ii. p. 419 (1771) ; JJFJMbent. 
Pl.Enlii.pl. 42. no. 136; Olphe-Galliard, iaim. Orn. Eumpe 0&s. 
fasc. xxxix. p. 26 (1886); Allem, Ornis, 1886, p. 416 [Kusfcaadji, 
Eumania]. 

Tetvao montana, Gm. S. N. I pt. ii. p. 758 (1788). 
Perdix torquata et P. varia, Bechst Nat. DeutscM. iii. p. 55S (17931 


9 . PERDIX. 
193 

In the most extreme form of this variety the whole head and 
neck are> du^rust-red, and the rest of the plumage dark ehestmit, 
except the thighs and lower part of the belly and vent, which are 
white, the pnmanes, which are brown, the secondaries and longer 
scapulars, which are irregularly margined with whitish or buff, 
finely vermiculated with black, and the wing-coverts and scapularsi 
which have irregulär whitish shaft-stripes dilated at the cxtremity 
of the secondary eoverts into a whitish pateh dotted with black. 

In a second specimen the plumage is as above, but the primaries 
are mottled, especially on the outer web, with rufous white, and 
most of the lesser and median eoverts have a small white patch at 
the extremity. 

Two other speeimens combine all the characters of the abovo, but 

all the feathers of the back, wing-coverts, scapulars, outer second


aries, and üanks are tipped with white, mottled with black. 

A fifth resembles these two last speeimens, bnt also approaches 

the typical P. perdix in the plumage of the top and back of the 

head, the back and sides of the neck, and the mantle (but theso parts 

are greyer than usual), and of the lower back, rump, and upper tail-

coverts (though the ground-colour is dirty white instead of brownish 

buff). On the underparts the chestnut horseshoe mark is enormously 

developed, while the flanks and sides are almost normal. The tail 

is unlike that of any other, having the basal portion of the outer web 

white, slightly mottled with black. 

On the whole, this bird, with the exception of its tail, is exactly 

intermediate between a typical specimen of the variety P. montana 

and P. perdix, though the parts of the plumage which resemble the 

latter are paler than usual. 

P. montana is said to be confined to the mountains of Lorraine, 
but I have seen speeimens of this variety, which are still preserved 
in private collections, that were shot some years ag*o in Northumberland, 
and are in every way identical with birds from Lorraine. 
Several examples are also preserved in the Kewcastle Museum. 
There can be no doubt that it is merely a strongly-marked variety 
of P. perdix^ and not a distinet speeies : and I think anyone who 
takes the trouble to examine the five speeimens which I havo described 
above, and sees the gradual transition they display between 
typical P. perdix and typical P. montana, can only arrive at the 
same conclusion.

b c. Ad. sk. France. Eiocour Coli. 
d Ad. sk. Zogny, Jan. Kiocour Coli 
e * Ad. st. Mountains of Lorraine. Dr. R. ß. Sharpe [P.].

Starna cinerea, var. peregriana, Tsehusi u. De la Torre, Ornis, 1888? 

p. 250 [Silesia]. 
This is a smaller migratory race of P perclicc, perfectly similar 
in plnmage, and differing only in its somewhat smaller size, and in 
having yeEow legs and feet and apparently also a yellow bül in the 
adult. Total length 9 inches, wing 5-9, tau 3*1, tarsus 1*4.

Adult male. Tho general colour abovo resembles that of P. perdu\ 
but is paler, and the colour of the back and siclcs of tho neck and 
npper back is greyer, while the subterminal chestnut eross-bars on 
the back^ are darker and as strongly defined as on tho rump and

forehead between the nostrils; ear-coverts brown, tipped with 
whitish; below the eye a whitish patch narrowly odged beneatk 
with black ; forehead, lores, wide superciliary stripos, and tho fore 
part of tbe cheeks rnfous buff; feathers on the sides of tho chin 
and throat similar in colour but considerably elongated, and with 
dark shaf ts; niiddle of chin and throat paler; bind part of tho 
cheeks and sides of the neck grey; sides of the ehest and breast 
grey, fiaely vermiculated with black, middle bright buff, followed by 
a large black horseshoe-shaped patch ; belly, thighs, and nnder tail-
coverts whitish; sides and flanks dirty white, each with a subterminal 
chestnut cross-bar. Two middle pairs of tail-feathers and 

the terminal part of the third pair whitish, with wavy bars and 
vermiculations of black; remainder of the feathers chestnut, uiore 
or less tipped with white, and with an ill-defmed darker chestnut 
subterminal band. Total length 11*5 inches, wing 6, tail 3*5, 
tarsns 1*5. 

A young male has the sides and back of the neck and mantle 
brownisb white, with spots and shaft-stripes of whitish; the upper 
parts are more coarsely marked than in tho adult, and tho black 
horseshoe mark much reduced. 

Adult female. Appears to differ from the malo in having tho 
black horseshoe much reduced or absent, and there is much ]oss 
bright buff on the ehest and breast; there is also a chestnut patch 
on the cbeek below the eye. Total length 11 inches, wing 5-ß, tail 3, 
tarsus 1-4.

Ädiät male and female. Differ from P. liodgsonice in having no

one b M from Ladak is somewhat intermediate. This species is 
also somewhat smaller.

afaorter than the longest*

Adult male. Top of the head reddish brown, a line of "black 
feathers down the centre with buff shaft-stripes: back of the neck 
and mantle dull reddish brown, with whitish shaft-stripes widely 
edged on either side with. black. Scapulars, inner median and 
secondary coverts, and outer secondaries the same, but with the 
terminal half of most of the feathers barred on the inner or both 
webs with rufous buff edged with black. Lesser and outer median 
wing-coverts chestnut (sometimes margined with grey and with 
grey shaft-stripes). Lower back, rump, and upper taü-coverts 

black mixed with reddish brown and tipped with olive-brown, each 
feather with a longitudinal white shaft-stripe and transverse bars 
of rufous or buff on both webs. Primaries, prima ry-coverts, and 
secondaries blackish brown, more or less mottled and edged with 
pale rufous on the outer web. The superciliary stripes, which are 
continued down the sides of the neck, and two stripes which commence 
at the gape and bound the sides of the throat pure white; 

11 . PERDICUXA. 197 
otherwise the rest of the head, chin, and throat are black. Sidcs 
of the neck, ehest, and breast grey ; front of the neck and middle 
of the ehest chestnut; middle of the breast and belly black, each 
feather with a large round or oval white spot near the extremity. 
Sides and ffanks chestnut, with white black-cdged shaft-stripes. 
Tail black, with reddish-white cross-bars. Iris brown. Legs and 
feet greyish black. Bill black, bluish towards the base. Total 
length 10 inches, wing 5*1, tail 2-7, tarsus 1*3. 

^ Adultfemale. Top of the head black fringed with olive-brown, a 
line of feathers with buff shaft-stripes running down the centre of 
the head; the whole of the upper parts black tipped with warm 
olive-brown, and each feather with a whitish or buff shaft-stripe 
and transversely barred on both webs with rufous buff. Quills like 
those of the male. Chin and throat buff; ear-coverts brown ; rest 
of the head rufous buff dotted with black. Best of the underparts 
buff or rufous buff; the feathers of the neck, ehest, breast, belly, 
and under tail-coverts each with two black lines, parallel with one 
another and with the margin of the feather; sides and flanks barred 
with black. Tail black, with buff cross-bars. Total length 9*6 
inches, wing 5*1, tail 2-7, tarsus 1*3. 

Hab. Same as that of the genus.

11. PEEDICULA. Ty?e 
Perdicula, Hodgs. Beng. Sport Mag. ix, p. 344 (1837) .. P. asiatica. 
Tail with 12 feathers; rather feeble, but mueh stiffer than the 
upper tail-coverts and less than half the length of the wing. 
Ist primary intermediate in length between the 7th and 9th; 4th 
slightly longest. 
Tarsus equal to the middle toe and claw; a pair of blunt spurs in 
the male. 
Axillaries short. 
Bange. Peninsula of India and Ceylon.

(Males.)

not barred with rufous buff ._. asiatica, p. 198. 
b. Throat dull brick-red; inner webs of primaries 
barred with rufous buff argoondah, p. 200. 
JB. Chest and breast not barred with black and 
white. {Females.)

Adult male. Top of tbe bead and nape brown, the feathers on tbe 
sides tipped with black; back, rump, and upper tail-coverts eartby 
brown, with narrow, wavy, transverse black barg; most of tbe 
featbers of tbe mantle with pale buif shafts, and those of tbe lower 
back and rump with buf cross-bars, but in very old examples the 
buff markings are almost or entirely absent; most of tbe wing-
coverts and scapulars bave bufF shaft-stripes and cross-bars, and ar$ 

11 . PEEDICÜXA. 
largely barred and blotched towards the extrenüty with black; the 
fiight-feathers are dark browu, barred 011 the outer web with rufous 
buff-—except the first primary, which is uniform brown, and tho 
outer secondaries, which are barred on both webs. Porehead, lores 
and superciliary stripe, chin, and throat rufous ohestnut, the superciliary 
stripe and tbe two latter edged above with a yellowish-white 
band; ear-coverts dark brown, separated from the chestnut supercilium 
by a narrow white band; rest of the underparts white, 
regularly barred with black. Thighs, vent, and under tail-eoverts 
pale chestnut; tail brown, with rufous-buff cross-bars edged with 
black. Bill black or dusky; iris hazel; legs and feet orange; tarsi 
with a pair of blunt spurs. Total length 6*4 inches, wing 3'3, 
tail 1*5, tarsus 0*95. 

In imrnature males the shaft-streaks on the feathers of the mantle 
are usually wider; the rufous chestnut of the lores and superciliary 
stripes is ill-defined, while on the chin and throat it is mixed with 
white and the shafts of the feathers are white; the rest of the 
underparts are mixed with vinaceous-buff feathers with narrow 
white shaft-stripes, and the long barred flank-feathers are vinaceous 
buff barred with black. 

In a quite young male the only trace of rufous chestnut is on the 
chin; the ehest and rest of the underparts are dull vinaceous buff, 
and most of the feathers have white shaft-streaks. 

Adultfemale. Differs from the adult male in having no buff shaft-
streaks or bars on the feathers of the back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts (in some speeimens there are very slight traces of buff on 
the upper tail-coverts) ; the wing-coverts much less bar red with 
buff and blotched with black, and the fore part of the neck, ehest, 
breast, and belly uniform vinaceous buff. 

In imrnature females the feathers of the mantle and many of those 
on the underparts have white shafts; the wing-coverts are rnore 
barred with buff and blotched with black; the rufous-chestnut 
superciliary stripe and throat of the adult are more or less feebly 
developed, and the ehest and sides of the breast are sometimes 
faintly and narrowly barred with blackish. 

Hab, India and Ceylon.

11 . PERDICULA. 
201 

Perdicula argoondah, Layard, Ann. Mag. N. IL (2) xiv. p. 107 
(1854) [Ceylon] ; Hume, Nests $ E. Ind. B. p. 545 (1873); id. 
Str. F. vii. p. 159 (1878) [Distribution]; Davidson §• Wend. Str. 

F. vii. p. 87 (1878) [Deccan]; Hume $ Marsh. Game B. Ind, ii. 
p. 117, pl. (1879); Butl Cat. B. Sind etc. p. 55 (1879); id. Cat. 
B. S. Bombay, p. 69 (1880); id. Str. F. ix. p. 423 (1880) [Bombay] ; 
Szoinh. 8^ Barn. Ibis, 1885, p. 131 [Central India]; Oates, ed. Eume's 
Wests $ E. Ind. B. iii. p. 441 (1890). 
Coturnixargoonda, Newton, Ibis, 1861, p. 116 [Mauritius, introduced]. 
Perdicula asiatica, Jerd. {nee Lath.) B. Ind. iii. p. 583 (1863); Ball, 
Str. F. ii. p. 427 (1874) [Chota Nagpur ?]; Butler, Str. F. iv. p. 7 
(1876) [N. Quzerat]; Fairb, Str. F. iv. p. 262 (1876) [Ahmed


nagar and Deccan generally]. 
Coturnix (Perdicula) argoondah, Gray, List Gallin® Brit. Mws.p. 62 

(1867); id. Hand4. B. ii. p. 269 (1870). 
Kock Bush-Quail, Hume $ Marsh. Game B. ii. p. 117 (1879). 
Perdicula argoonda, Davidson, Str. F. x. p. 317 (1882) [W. Knandeisli]; 
Taylor, Str. F. x. p. 465 (1887) [Manzeerabad, Mysore]. 

Adult male. Differs from the adult male of P. asiatica in having 
the feathers of the upper parts, especially the back of the head, 
nape, and mantle, transversely barred with buff and black or grey 
edged on either side with black; the primariea and secondaries are 
barred on both webs with rufous buff; the forehead, lores, and 
supercüiary stripe, and the chin and throat dull brick-red, not 
margined above by a white band. Iris dark brown; bill horny 
brown above, lavender-blue below; legs and feet orange-red; tarsi 
armed with blunt spurs. Total length 6-5 inches, wing 3*3, tail 1*7, 
tarsus 1. 

Immature finales have the Upper parts vinaceous brown with 
irregulär wavy black lines and narrow burr" shaft-stripes edged on 
either side with black: as age increases each shaft-stripe becomes 
constricted into four or flve isolated buff patches; these spread 
transversely and eventually become united with other pale spots 
situated on the margins of the feather. Thus withont any moult 
taking place the feathers become transversely barred with buff: as in 
the adult. 

A very young male has the whole of the underparts buff, washed 
with vinaceous and indistinctly barred with black. 

Adult female. Has the whole of the upper parts dull vinaceous, 
with some faint indications of dusky cross-lines and buff marks; 
the flight-feathers barred on the outer and mottled on the inner 
web with rufous buff; the middle of the chin, throat, and belly 
whitish, and the rest of the underparts dull vinaceous. 

Immature females have the upper parts more or less distinctly 
barred and mottled with buff and black. 
Mab, India; ? Ceylon; Mauritius (introduced).

12. MICROPEEDJf. \, 
Type. 
Microperdix, Gouldy B. As. TU. pl. üi. (1862)., M. erythrorhyncha. 

Tail of 10 feathers, fairly developed, rounded, and rather more 

than half the length of the wing. 
Ist primary equal in length to the 10th; 6th slightly longest. 
Tarsi without spurs, and equal to the middle toe and claw. 

Bange. Peninsula of India and Manipur.

12 . M1CB0PEEDIX.

1. Microperdix erythrorhyncha. 
Coturnix erythrorhyncha, Sykes, P. Z. S. 1832, p. 153 [Valley of 
Karli, N. Konkan]; Grayx III Ind. Zool. ii. pl. 44. %. 2 (1834); 
Sykes, Trans. Zool SOG. ii. p. 16, pl. i. (1841); Grat/, List of B. 
pt. iii. Gall p. 40 (1844); id. Gen. B. iii. p. 507 (1846). 
Perdix erythrorhyncha, Blyth, J. A. S. Beng. xi. p. 808 (1842) 
[Southern India]. 
Perdicula erythrorhyncha, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 881 (1856); Jerd. 

B. Ind. iii. p. 584 (18G3); Bulger, B. Z. S. 1866, p. 571 [Wellington, 
Nilghiris] ; Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 160; Blanf. Ibis, 1867, p. 464 
[SirouchaJ; Elwes, Ibis, 1870, p. 528 [Cardanium Hills, Travancore]; 
Fairb. Str. F. v. p. 409 (1877) [Kokaikänal, Palanai Hills]: 
Davidson Sf Wend. Str. F. vii. p. 87 (1878) [Sholapur, Poona, 
Satara Hills]. 
Microperdix erythrorhyncha, Gould, B. Asia, vii. pl. 3 (1862) ; 
Hume, Nests % F. Ind. B. p. 548 (1873); Fairb. Str. F. iv. p. 262 
(1876) [Khandala, Mahableshwar, &c.]. 

Coturnix 
(Microperdix) erythrorhyncha, Gray, Bist Gallium Brit. 
» Mus. p. 02 (1867); id. Hand-l B. ii. p. 269 (1870). 
Microperdix erythrorhynchus, HumefyMarsh. Game B. Ind. ii. p. 123, 
pl. (1879); Butler, Str. F. ix. p. 423 (1880) [Bombay]; id. Cat. 

B. S. Bombay, p. 69 (1880); Davison, Str. F. x. p. 411 (1883) 
[Nilghiris, Wynaad, Mysore]; Terry, Str. F. x. p. 479 (1887) 
[Palanai Hills] ; Oates, ed. Humes Nests & B. Ind. B. iii. p. 442 
(1890). 
Adult male. Top of the head black, except the middle of the 
occiput, which, like tbe nape and rest of the upper parts, is earthy 
brown; a white band between the eyes is continued backwards 
down each side of the head and forms a U-shaped white mark; the 
feathers of the back, rump, and upper iail-coverts have a rounded 
black subterminal Spot narrowly circumscribed with bu££; the wing-
coverts and scapulars, which are rather warmer brown than the 
back, have narrow white shaft-stripes, buh2 cross-bars, and are 
mostly blotched with black near the extremity of the inner web; 
night-feathers blackish, the outer four (primaries) margined and the 
rest barred and mottled with rufous buff. Porehead, lores, superciliary 
stripe, sides of face, feathers round the gape and on the chin 
black; ear-coverts dark brown; throat white, irregularly margined 
below with black; neck and ehest greyish brown, washed with 
rufous and gradually shading into rufous ehestnut on the rest of the 
underparts; the feathers of the neck and ehest are usually more or 
less spotted with black like those of the back, but on the sides, flanks, 
and under tail coverts the spots are very much larger and edged 
with whitish. Tail black, with narrow buff or pale rufous bars. 
Iris brown; bill, legs, and feet rieh red. Tarsi without spurs. 
Total length 7 inches, wing 3-4, tail 1*9, tarsus 1. 

In immature males the forehead, superciliary stripes, sides of the 
head, chin, and throat are white washed with rufous, and some of 
the feathers of the mantle and ehest have pale buff shaft-stripes; 
otherwise the plumage resembles fchat of the adult. 

Adult female. Like the adult male, but the forehead, lores, superciliary 
stripe, sides of the head, chin, and throat are dull rufous 

204 
PHASIANIDJS. 

chestnut, and the crown of the head is almost entirely brown, with 

only a few black spots on the sides. 
In immature females the crown is mostly black, as In the male. 
Hab. South-western hills of the Indian Peninsula, ranging north 

to Bombay and south to the Cardamum Hills.

2. Microperdix blewitti 
Perdicula erythrorhyncha, Ball (nee Sykes), Str. F. ii. p. 428 (1874) 
[Chota Nagpur and Satpura Hills]. 
Microperdix blewitti, Hume, Str. Fl ii. p. 512 (1874) [Kaipur]; 
Ball, Str. F. iii. p. 294 (1875); id. Str. F. vii. p. 225 (1878) ; 
Hume 8f Marsh. Game B. Ind. ii. p. 130, pl. (1879). 
Adult male. Closely resembles the male of M. erythrorhyncha, 
from which it can only be distinguished by having the white band 
between the eyes nearly twice as wide and the black forehead much 
narrower, the ehest greyer, and the underparts paler. It is also 
somewhat smaller. Total length 6*8 inches, wing 3*1, tail l-ßt 
tarsus 0'95. 
Adult female. Somewhat paler than the female of M. evythr%rhyncha, 
especially on the forehead, lores, superciliary stripes, chrnr 
throat, and underparts, which are pale dnll brick-colonr.

13 . AEBOKICOLA. 
205 

Adult male. Whole of the Upper parts dark grey ; top of the hoad, 
nape, back, rump, and upper tail-coverts tipped and barred with 
black; wing-coverts the same, but mostly blotcbed with black 011 
the subterminal part of the inner web; flight-feathers blacldsh, 
barred with pale buff on the outer web, except the first primary, 
which is narrowly margined with buff on the outer web, and the 
last secondaries, which are barred on both ; forehead, lores, superciliary 
stripe, chin, and throat dark chestnut; a white stripe from 
the gape to the eye and continued behind to the dark grey ear-
coverts; neck and upper parts of ehest grey, shading into tawny 
buff on the breast and belly, each feather with a black shaft-stripe 
and those of the breast and belly with a wide black subterminal 
cross-bar ; under tail-coverts black, tipped and spotted on each web 
with white; tail mottled and barred with dark grey and black. 
Total length 6*5 inches, wing 3*4, tail 2, tarsus 1*05. 

In immature males the last secondaries are black, more widely 
barred with tawny buff; otherwise the plumage is as above. 

Adult female. JDiffers from the adult male in having none of the 
dark chestnut markings on the head, chin, and throat, the two 
latter being white or whitish grey and the breast and belly buff 
instead of tawny. 

An immature female has the last secondaries marked like those of 
the immature male, but is otherwise similar to the above. 
Hab. Eastern Manipur hüls.

Under this title a speeimen in the Military Library at Manilla is briefly 
characterized as follows:—" Head greenish black ; breast yinous red, streaked 
with black; sides pale red with black spots." This description is so vague 
that it is inipossible to form a deeided opinion on it, but probably the bird 
represents a distinct species of this genus, inhabiting Luzon.

ArboripMla torqueola, Gray, Cht Hodgson, p. 127 (1846); Hume, 
Ne*& % Eggs Ind. B. p. 544 (1873) ; id. Str. F. iL p. 449 (1874). 
Arboricola torqueola. Blyth, I. As. Soe. Beng. xviii. p. 819 (1849) ; 

id. Cot. B. Mm. As. Soc. p. 252 (1849) ; id. J. As. Soc. Beng. xxiv. 

p. 276 (1857) [Simla and Mussooree Hills, Sikhim]; Adams, 
JP.Z.& 1858, p. 503; Irby, Ibis, 1861, p. 236 [Kumaon]; Jerd. 
B. Ind. ii. p. 577 (1864); Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 159; v. Pete. Ibis, 
1868, p. 321 [Koteghur]; Beavan, Ibis, 1868, p. 385 J~Darjeeling, 
Südbim,80OOft/|; Bulger, Ibis, 1869, p. 170 [Mts. Tongloo and 
208 PHASIAKTID2B. 

Tendong, Sikhim]; MarshaU, Ibis, 1884, p. 423 [Chamba]; Grant, 
10M, 1892, p. 392. _ „ 
Hyloperdix torqueola, Sundevall, Tent. p. 116 (1872); Nichols. ed. 
SundevaWs Tent p. 203 (1889). 
Arboricola torqueolus, Hume, Str. F. viii. p. 111 (1879); ScuUy, 
Str. F. viii. p. 349 (1879) [Nepal]; JELumefy Marsh. Game B. iL 

p. 69, pl. (1879). 
Äclult male. Top of the head bright chestnut, shading into rusty 
red oii the lorcs. Peathers of the nape partly rust-red and partly 
white, with a wide black band down the middle. Upper back 
olive-brown, fringed and barred with black ; lower back, rump, and 
upper tail-coverts the same, but each feather ornamented in addition 
with a triangulär or heart-shaped black patch situated near the 
extremity. Lesser and median wing-coyerts and scapulars pale 
olive-brown, widely margined on the sides with chestnut; the 
latter and some of the median eoverts with a subterminal black 
patch and tipped with chestnut. Primaries and their eoverts 
brownish black, slightly margined with rust-colour at the extremity. 
Secondaries the same, but with the outer half of the outer web 
chestnut shading into buff at the extrenrity and dotted here and 
there with blackish brown ; secondary coyerts with the whole outer 
web chestnut and the inner blackish brown. Ear-coverts bright 
rust-red; superciliary stripe, sides of the face, chin, and throat 
black (in some specimens the superciliary stripe is edged superiorly 
and the throat-feathers narrowly margined with white); a narrow 
white band, commencing at the base of the lower mandible, borders 
the sides of the chin and throat; behind the ear-coverts, on the side 
of the neck, lies a patch of rust-coloured feathers spotted with black; 
fore part and rest of the sides of the neck black, narrowly margined 
with white and divided from the grey ehest by a wide white band. 
Middle of breast and belly white; feathers of the sides and flanks 
grey, widely margined on either web with chestnut and ornamented 
by a narrow white shaft-stripe or spot. Thighs and shorter under 
tail-coverts a mixture of olive-grey and buff, barred with black and 
spotted occasionally with white; longer under tail-coverts black 
tipped with white. Tail-feathers olive-brown, irregularly marked 
with black aad with an ill-defined subterminal black bar. Bill 
black; orbital skin crimson; iris brown or reddish brown; legs 
and feet pale violet or nesh-eolour. Total length 11*8 inches, 
wing 6, tail 2-7, tarsus 1*7. 

Toung males have a white spot at the extremity of the grey 
chest-feathers • the sides and flanks also have white spots and are 
almost devoid of chestnut margins; and the outer webs of the 
primaries are margined with rufous buff. Orbital skin blue-grey, 
tinged with red. 

Adult femccle. Differs from the male in having the top of the 
head brown or olive-brown, each feather with a black shaft-stripe; 
the wing-coverts more or less mottled with black; the ear-coverts 
olive-brown; the superciliary stripes, sides of the face, chin, throat, 
and neck rust-coloured or rufous buff, each feather with a terminal 
black spot; a rust-red band separating the neck and ehest, which is 

13 . AKBORICOLA. 
2Qü 
brownish grey tinged with rusfcy, and the sides and flanks with 
subterminal white spots and blotches. 

Toung females have a white spot at the extremity of the feathers 
of the ehest as well as the underparts, and the outer webs and tips 
of the primariea and secondaries are mottled with rufous buff. 

Hab. Outer ranges of the Himalayas from Ohamba and the Ravi 
to the eastern border of Sikhim and possibly the Naga Hills. Ranging 
from 5000-14,000 feet.

2. Arboricola atrogularis. 
Arboricola atrogularis, Blyth, J. As. SOG. xviii. p. 819 (1849) [Assam, 
Sylhetl; id. Cat. B. Mus. As. Soc. p. 253 (1849); id. J. AB. SOC. 
Beng. xxiv. p. 276 (1856); Jerd. B. Ind. ii. p. 579 (1864) [Tipperah 
and Chittagong]; Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 159; Hume, Str. F. 

v. p. 44 (1877) j Anderson, Yumian, ii. Birds, p. 673 (1878) [Kachin 
Hills]; Hume $> Marsh. Game B. ii. p. 79, pl. (1879); Hume, 
Str. F. viii. p. 111 (1879); id. Str. F. xi. p. 306 (1888); Grant, 
Ibis, 1892, p. 393. * 
Perdix atrogularis, Gray, List Gallince Brit. Mus. p. 58 (1867); id. 

Hand-l B. ii. p. 267, no. 9695 (1870). 

Arborophila atrogularis, Hume, Str. F. ii. p. 449 (1874). 

Arboricola atrigularis, Oates, ed. Hume's Wests fy Fggs, iii. p. 439 

(1890). 

Adult male and female. Feathers of the top of the head olive-
brown, shading into grey or white on the lores, each with a black 
VOL. XSII. ' * 

210 PHASIANIM. 

spot at the extremity ; nape and back of the neck rufous buff, also 
spotted with black at the extremity. Back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts olive-brown, fringed and barred with black; the subterminal 
bars on the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts wider than the 
rest, sometimes forming a triangulär black spot. Lesser and median 
wing-coverts light olivo-bro wn, with wide-set narrow wavy black 
lines and shaft~blotch.es or spots of black. Basal half of the scapulars 
dull chestnut mottled with black, the outer half ornamented 
by bands of pale olive-bufT, black, and chestnut. Primaries and 
secondaries and their coverts similar to those of A. torqueola. 
Ear-coverts buff. Superciliary stripe black, edged superiorly with 
white, a wide white triangulär patch of white commencing at the 
base of the lower mandible. Chin and throat black; front of 
neck black, margined with white; ehest grey; middle of breast 
and belly white; feathers of the sides and flanks grey edged with 
olive-brown and eaeh with an oval white spot on the shaft near the 
extremity. Under tail-coverts black, irregularly barred with 
brownish buff and widely tipped with white. Tail olive-brown* 
barred and mottled with black. Bill black; iris brown; orbital 
and gular skin intense red; legs and feet orange-red. 

Male. Total length 10 inches, wing 5-6, tail 2-2, tarsus 1*7* 
Female. Total length 9 inches, wing 5, tail 2, tarsus 1*5. 
In what appears to be a rather less mature male from Dibrughur 


most of the breast-feathers have the basal two-thirds irregularly 
barred with black. 

Rah. N.E. India, ranging from Sudiya in Eastern Assam to the 
Ehasia and Garo Hills, southwards through Cachar, Sylhet, Tipperah, 
Hill Tipperah, Manipur, amd Chittagong; als© found in the 
Eachin Hills, east of Bhamo.

3. Arboricola ar&ens. 

Arboricola ardens, Stgan, Bull Orn. G. no. ii. p. vi (1892); id. Ibis, 
1893, pp. 56, 436, pl. xii. [Liuwowan, Hainan]. 

Adult male (type). Most nearly allied to A. atrogularis and 

A. crudigularis, but differing widely from both as well as from all 
other members of the genus in having an orange-scarlet patch of 
feathers on the fore part of the neck and middle of the ehest. The 
13 . AEBORICOLV. 
texture of this patch of brightly-coloured feathers rcscmbles sputi 
glass, tho vanes being rather stiff, hair-like, and shining. It 
reminds one strongly, both as regards colour and texture, of a 
similar patch met with in some of the Horned Pheasants, such 
as Tragopan satyra or T. melanocephala. The same orangc-red 
extends in a less degree round the sides of the neck, and the breast 
and belly are faintly washed with the same colour. Total length 
8 inches, wing 4-8, tau 1-75, tarsus 1-3. 

Hdb. Mountains of Hainau. 

4. Arboricola crudigularis. 
Oreoperdix crudigularis, Swinhoe, Ibis, 1864, p. 426 [Formosa], 1865,

Arboricola crudigularis, Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 160; Grant, Ibis, 1892, 

p. 393. 
Adult male and female. DifTers from A. atrogularis in having the 
nape and back of the neck mixed with chestnut; the barring on the 
lipper parts wider and darker ; the chin, upper part of the throat, 
cheeks, ear-coverts, and front of the neck white ; and the lower part 
of the throat black. Bill black ; iris olive-brown; bare skin round 
the eye purplish flesh-colour; legs orange-red. 

Male. Total length 9*5 inches, wing 5-5, tail 2'2, tarsus 1-55. 
Female. Total length 9*3 inches, wing 5*3, tail 2*1, tarsus 1*55.

the back, rump, and Upper tail-coverts devoid of black bars, though

Adult male and female. Besemble A. intermedia, but differ in 

having the feathers of the chin and throat rust-red, eaeh with 

a terminal black spot as in the female of A. torqueola. The 

fore part of the neck uniform rust-red, or very nearly so, and 

bordered below by a black band. In most of the large series of 

/ 

13 . AUBOEICOLA. 
specimens from Mooleyit this black band is absent; but in some 

belonging to each sex it is represented by intermittent black spots 

at the extremities of some of the rust-red neck-feathers at the base 

of the neck, while in onefemale specimen it is as strongly developod 

as in any from Sikhim. The Tenasserim birds have received the 

name of A. ückelli, and are said to be « distinctly and constanüy 

larger than the Himalayan"; but this is not the ease, and it 

is impossible to consider them even subspecifically distiuct. 

Male. Total length 11 inches, wing 5-6, tail 2-3, tarsus 1-7. 

Female. Total length 10*5 inches, wing 5*4, tail 2*1, tarsus 1-5. 

Hab. Lower outer ranges of the Himalajas, from Kumaon through 

Nepal and Sikhim as fax east as the Daphla Hills north of the 

Darrung Dist.; also occurs in the higher ranges of Tenasserim, on 

Mooleyit.

Adiät male and female. Differ from the male of A. torqueola in 
having the top of the head, lores, space in front of the eye, and nape 
dark chestnut; the back and sides of the neck rust-red, shading into 
chestnut towards the back, with a black spot at the extremity 
of most of the feathers ; the feathers of the back, rump, and npper 
tail-coverts only fringed with blackish; the edges to the lesser and 
median wing-coverts and scapulars not so wide and much paler; a 
grey superciliary stripe commencing above the middle of the eye 
and dividing the top of the head and nape from the back and sides 
of the neck; cheeks and ear-coverts rust-red, spotted with black; 
the chin, throat, and upper half of the fore neck uniform rust-red, 
bounded by a white and then a black band ; the ehest rieh chestnut; 
and the middle of the breast and belly grey.

Javan Partridge, Brown, lll. Zool. p. 40, pl. 17 (1776); Lath. Gen.

EncycL Meth. i. p. 211, pl. 96. %. 1 (1791); Temm. Fig. et 
Galt iii. pp. 404 & 732 (1815) ; Vieill. N. Biet. d'Hist. Nat. xxv. 


p. 225 (1817) ; Steph. in Shaivs Gen. Zool. xi. p. 355 (1819); 
Temm. Fl Col v. pl. 34 [no. 148] (1823); Zess. Traite d'Om. 
p. 506 (1831); Gray, List Gallince Brit. Mus. p. 59 (1867); id.

Arborophila javanica, Gray, List Galt. B. iii. p. 38 (1844) * Nicholson, 

Ibis, 1882, p. 69 [Preanger Regendes]. 
Arboricola javanica, Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 159 • Grant, Ibis, 1892, 

p. 396. 
Peloperdix javanica, Meyer, Vog.-Skel. pt. xi. pl. ci. (1886). 
Adult male and feinöle. Top of the head reddish brown, shading 

13 . ARB0BICOLA. 
215 

into rust-colour on the forehead and lores. A black band of 

feathers commences behind either nostril, and surrounding the oycs 

unite with one another at the back of the crown ; thence the 

united bands pass down the middle of the back of the neck, dividing 

a rust-red patch of feathers on the nape, and are finally lost in the 

black band which surrouuds the base of the neck. A second less 

regulär black band Grosses the base of the throat (in some specimens 

it is continued towards the chin) and bounds the rust-red patch on 

the nape, and passing widely down the side of the neck joins the one 

round the base of the neck. Chin, upper part of throat, cheeks, ear-

coverts, and front of neck rust-coloured, the latter iisually rnore or 

less spotted with black. Back, rump, and upper tail-coverts dark 

grey, barred and fringed with black Wing-coverts and scapulars 

as in A. torqueola, but the chestnut margins to the latter are less 

defined and the sub terminal black patch es are wider. Chest grey. 

Breast, belly, sides, Üanks, and under tail-coverts chestnut. Tail 

black, barred with grey. Iris dark grey ; bill black ; feet red. 

Male. Total length 11 inches, wing 5*6, tail 2m2, tarsus 1*8. 

Female. Total length 10 inches, wing 5*4, tail 2, tarsus 1'8. 

A quite young bird has the scapulars reddish brown, each with a 
small white spot at the extremity of the shaft; the chin and throat 
are white and the chest brown; otherwise the plumage is much the 
same as that of the adult.

Arboricola rubrirostris, Grant, Ibis} 1892, p. 396. 

Adult male. Head, throat, and neck black; a small white patch on 
the lores and chin; a line of white spots along each side of the 
crown, and also along the sides of the throat. The feathers giving 
this appearance are very curious, being naked shafts supporting a 
white plume at the extremity. Back and rest of Upper parts rieh 
olive-brown, barred and fringed with black, the terminal half of 

216 
FHASIANIDJE. 

the scapulars is paler olive-brown, with a wide terminal black bar. 
Primaries and their coverts brownisb black; secondaries, tbeir 
coverts, and some of tbe outer median coverts tbe same, but margined 
on the out er web with pale olive- or rufous-brown. Chest 
olive-brown, intersperscd with similar white shaft-plumes to those 
of the crown and throat, and giviug this part an irregulär spotted 
appearance. Upper breast and sides of lower breast and belly 
white, with a large round black spot near the extremity of each 
feather; middle of lower breast and belly white; sides, flanks, and 
under tail-coverts black, with narrow wide-set white bars• thighs 
olive-brown, fringed with white. Tail olive-brown, barred and 
mottled with black. Iris brown ; bill coral-red ; legs and feet reddish 
brown. Total length 9*6 inches, wing 5-2, tail 1*7, tarsus 1-75.

Adult male and female. Eorehead, lores, and wide snperciliary 
stripes, which are continned backwards down the sides of the neck, 
buff; top of the head either olive-brown tipped with black, or black 
barred with brown towards the base * ; middle of the back and sides 
of the neck black ; feathers round the base of the neck buff-olive, 
with a black triangulär spot at the extremity of each; back, rump, 
and upper tail-coverts olive-brown, fringed and barred with black; 
lesser and median wing-coverts and scapulars a mixture of reddish 
chestnut and pale olive, fringed at the extremity and often mottled 
more or less with black • many of the median wing-coverts with a 
large black patch in the middle, reaching from the base nearly to the 
extremity of the feathers, and most of the scapulars with a large 

* The same peculiarly shaped feathers, with naked shafts and only a tuft of 
vanes at tbeir extremity, already mentioned in the description of A. rubrirostris, 
are founcl in numbers among the feathers on the top of the head in this species, 
but owing to their being black are less conepieuous.

ßubterminal transverse black spot and tipped with chestnut. Primaries 
and their coverts blackish brown, mixed with rufous buff at 
the tips ; inner seeondaries the same, margined witb reddish ochie 
on the outer web; onter seeondaries and secondary coverts reddish 
ochre, the inner wehs of the former more or less mottled with black, 
and of the latter mostly black. A black band commenecs behind 
the nostril, surrounds the eye, and passes over the ear-coverts into 
the black patch on the side of the neck. Chin, throat, cheeks, and 
ear-coverts pale buff; front of the neck with scattered lines of buffcoloured 
feathers with black extremities, between whieh can be seen 
the bright red skin of the throat. Chest brownish ochre, more or 
less barred with black at the base; breast paler; belly white, edged 
with brownish bufT; sides and flank-feathers black and brownish 
buff, each with a large subterminal white blotch partially or wholly 
bordered with black. Under tail-coverts brownish buff, with a large 
black bar near the extremity. Tail-feathers olive-brown, mottled 
with black. Bill black; iris deep brown ; orbital patch and gular 
skin (thinly covered with tracts of feathers) bright red; legs and 
feet red, varying from dull coral to pale bright red, pinker or even 
orange in young birds.

14. Arboricola orientalis. 
Perdix orientalis, Horsf. Trans. Zinn. Soc. xiii. p. 184 (1822) 
[Java]. 
Oriental Quail, Latli. Gen. Hist. viii. p. 322 (1823). 
Perdix personata, Horsf. Zool. Res. pl. 61 (1824); Gray, in Griff. 
Anim. Kingä. iii. p. 53 (1829); id. List Gallina Brit. Mus. p. 59 
(1867) [part]. 
Tropicoperdix personata, Blyth, J. As. Soc. Beng. xxviii. p. 415 
(1859). 
Arboricola personata, Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 159. 
Arboricola orientalis, Grämt, Ibis, 1892, p. 397. 


Adult. Lores and superciliary stripe white ; top of the head and 
back of the neck blaekish brown; back, rump, and upper tail-eoverts 
rieh dark brown, each feather fringed with blaekish at the extremity, 
those of the rump with a pale greyish-brown subterminal band. 
Lesser and outer median wing-coverts and scapulars dark brown, 
shading into dark olive-brown towards the extremity of the outer 
web ; a black blotch is situated near the extremity of each feather, 
bordered externally with rufous, fringed with black. Inner median 
coverts the same, but widely bordered with dull orange-red. Primaries 
and their coverts dark brown; secondaries and their coverts 
the same, margined with rufous on the outer web, the outer secondaries 
are also widely tipped with dull orange-red fringed with 
black, like the inner median coverts, and have a small oblong black 
spot on the shaft near the extremity. A dark brown band commences 
behind the nostril, surrounds the eye, and passing above the 
ear-coverts is continued down the side of the neck. Chin, throat, 
cheeks, and ear-coverts white; the front of the neck, as in A. brunneo


jpectus, is thinly covered with feathers of the same colour. Chest 

13 . ARBORICOLA. 
2VJ 
and sides of breast brownish grey, eacli feathor black or mottlcd 
with black towards the base; middlo of breast and bolly whitish; 
sides and flanks grey, sornewhat irregularly and widely barrod with 
white and blaek, and tinged and fringed with rufous buff at tho 
extremity ; under tail-coverts black, tipped with white. Tail clark 
brown. Iris pale reddish yellow ; legs and foet the same; bill appears 
to have been reddish brown, and the orbital and gular skin scarlet. 
Total length 11 inches, wing 5*9, tail 2-5, tarsus 1-8. 

Hab. Mountains of East Java.

Arborophila chloropus, Hume, Str. F. ii. p. 449 (1874). 
Peloperdix chloropus, Hume, Str. F. iii. p. 176 (1878). 


Adult male and female. Top of the head, middle of the nape, and 
back of the neck rieh brown; upper back the same, each feather 
with a submarginal black line and irregulär black bars either 
roughly followiug the shape of the feather or crossing transversely. 
Power back, rump, and upper tail-coverts also rieh brown, fringed, 
barred, and dotted with black and rufous or buff; most of the wing-
coverts and scapiüars the same, with a rather large buff or buff and 
rust-coloured patch near the extremity, and an oblong buff spot or 
streak at the extremity of the shaft. Primaries and their coverts 
blackish brown, edged with rufous buff near the extremity of the 
outer web. Inner secondaries the same, margined and mottled on 
the outer web with rufous buff; outer secondaiies like the scapulars. 
Peathers of the lores and superciliary stripe white, edged with 
black, or with one web blaek, and continued backwards in a buff 
black-edged band bordering the crown and brown middle of the 
nape. Chin white • throat and sides of face white, with a black spot 
at the extremity of each feather• front and sides of the neck rustcolour 
and similarly spotted. Chest brown, barred with black, some 
of the feathers shading into brownish buff towards the extremities. 
(In one speeimen the upper half of the chest is uniform brown and 
not barred with black.) Middle of the breast rust-red, shading into 
pale buff or white on the belly ; sides and flanks and under tail-
coverts buff and brownish, irregularly marked.and barred with black. 
A large hidden patch of pure white downy feathers on either side. 
Tail reddish brown, irregularly barred and mottled with black. Iris 
dark hazel-brown ; bill dusky red at base, remainder greenish; eyelids 
and orbital skin purplish; legs and feet pale green. 

Male. Total length 12 inches, wing 6-2, tail 2*9, tarsus 1*6. 
Female. Total length 10*3 inches, wing 5*9, tail 2*6, tarsus 1*5. 
Hat. Prom the hüls north of Tonghoo and the Pegu Yoma south


wards along the lower slopes of the Tenasserim Hills as far south as 
the latitude of Tavoy. Also recorded from Cochin China.

Adultmale andfemale. Differ from A. chloropus in having all the

neck white, spotted with black; the upper half of ehest chestnut, the 
lower half, sides, and fianks buff, widely barred with blackish brown; 
these bars are rather less sharply defined on the lower ehest of the 
female. Iris brown; bill black; feet dull yellowish green.

Aduli male and female. Top of the head bright chestnut, shading 
into clear rufous chestnut on the lores and back of the neck. Upper 
back black, each feather with a white submarginal line, within 
which is a second white line, either following the shape of the 
feather, or merely represented by a white shaft-stripe; lower back, 
rump, and upper tail-coverts black, each feather with a bright rustcoloured 
submarginal line widened and pointed towards the extremity 
of the feather. Lesser and median wing-coverts and scapulars 
olive-brown, with a round black spot at the extremity of the 
feathers. Primaries and their coverts blackish brown, with light 
rufous-buff margins ; secondaries the same, with the outer half of 
the out er web margined and mottled with rufous buff. A short 
black stripe passing from behind the eye across the top of the ear-
coverts ; rest of the face, chin, and throat pale rufous buff. Neck, 
ehest, and rest of underparts clear rufous chestnut; some of the 
flank-feathers and under tail-coverts with a round black spot near 
the extremity; sides black, barred with white or buff. Tau black, 
the two middle pairs of feathers with rufous-buff bands irregularly 
following the shape of the feather. Male with a pair of spurs, or 
sometimes two situated close together. Iris deep brown; bill black; 
legs and feet pale dirty green. 

Male. Total length 11*8 inches, wing 5*7, tail 2*5, tarsus 1*8. 
Female. Total length 10*7 inches, wing 5-3, tail 2-3, tarsus 1*6. 
Hab. S. Tenasserim and Malay Peninsula.

Specimens from Sumatra.and Java are on the whole less brightly 
coloured than Malayan birds, especially on the underparts; and 
the ehest and sides of the breast even in perfectly adult specimens 
have the basal half of the feathers irregularly barred and marked 
with black; the black feathers of the mantle, instead of being 
ornamented with a white submarginal band, are irregularly barred 
with yellowish white.

and nape. Total length 10*4 inches, wing 5*3, tail 2*2, tarsus 1*75.

Adult male. Fore part of the head, superciliary stripes, lores, 
ckeeks, ear-coverts, chin, throat, and neck black. A tufb of long 
stiff, black, hair-like shafts situated in the middle of the forehead. 
A white band across the top of the head between the eyes separates 
the black fore part from the long hairy maroon crest which Covers 
the hinder part of the head. Back of the neck, back, rump, and 
upper tail-coverts rieh green glossed with steel-bluo. Primaries 
and secondaries and their eoverts dark brown, and, the primaries 
especially, mottled on the outer web with rufous buff; scapulars 
and rest of the wing-coverts maroon, glossed with purple and blue. 
Rest of the underparts black, the ehest and breast glossed with 
blue. Tail and the longer Upper tail-coverts black. Bill black, 
scarlet at the base, nakcd skin round the eye, legs, and feet scarlet. 
Iris slaty grey. Total length 10*8 inches, wing 5-5, tail 2-3, 
tareus 1'7. 

Adult female. The whole head is blackish grey; the frontal tuft 
of bristles is well developed as in the male, but the occipital crest 
is only moderate. The neck, back, rump, upper tail-coverts, ehest, 
and breast are bright grass-green, shading into greyish green on 
the belly and under tail-coverts. Primaries, secondaries, and their 
eoverts as in the male; scapulars, lesser and median wing-coverts 
chestnut, edged with maroon slightly glossed with purple. Tail 
black. The bill is black and the iris is brown, otherwise the soft 
parts are like those of the male. Total length 10*5 inches, wing o-2, 
tail 2-3, tarsus 1*6. 

An immature female resembles the adult, but the extremities of 
the scapulars and wing-coverts are tipped with rufous buff. 
Hab. Malay Peninsula from South Tenasserim southwards, 
exten ding into Siam, Sumatra, Java, and Borneo.

1. Coturnix coturnix, J ad. II. C. japonica, 5 ad.* 
Perhaps no spccies of Game Birds have been more confused, and 
their changes of plumage less understood, tban the Common Quail 
(Coturnix coturnix) and its near ally the Japanese Quail 

(0. japonica); and I am pleased to say that I have now at last 
discovered definite and well-marked characters by which both the 
males and females of these two species may be readily distinguished, 
while the intermediate forms are, as I shall presently show, 
undoubtedly the results of interbreeding. 
Coturnix japonica is the resident bird found in Japan and China, 
and sometimes occurs in N.E. India and Burmah, as there are 

* These woodcuts as well as the following remarks are reproduced froin 
Ann. Mag. N. H. 1892, x. pp. 169-171. 
18 . COTUBNIX. 231 
specimens of this spccies in the British Museum obtained in Bootan 

and Karen-nee. The male is characterized by the uniform clull 

brick-red throat without any trace of a black band down the 

iniddle, and the female by having the feathers on the chin and 

sides of the throat elongate and lanceolate and of much the samo 

strueture as those found in Perdiv barbata. 

The typical form of Goturnix coturnix, commonly known as the 
migratory Quail of Europe, has the throat pure white, the male 
having a black anchor-shaped mark down the middle, while in the 
female the feathers on the sides of the throat aro short and rounded, 
never elongate as in the female of 0. japonica. This bird rauges 
over an enormous area, practieally the whole of the Ethiopian and 
Palaearctic Kegions, extending in the sonth to South Africa and in 
the east to China and Japan. In the islands surrounding the Afriean 
coast, namely Mauritius, Madagascar, the Coinoro Islands, the 
Cape-Verd Islands, the Canaries, Madeira, and the Azores, and also 
in the southern part of Africa sonth of about 15° S. lat., a resident 
snbspecies of G. coturnix, known as G* capensis, is found, which is 
distinguished from the typical form by its somewhat smaller size 
and by having the throat of the male bright rufous-ehestnut with a 
black anchor-shaped mark down the middle. In Japan and China 
the migratory Quail ((7. coturnix), as already pointed out, inhabits the 
same tract of cotmtry during the breeding-season as G. japonica, and 
there cannot be the slightest doubt that the two species frcquently 
interbreed, with the result that all sorts of intermediate hybrids 
are produced. These intermediate plumages are most noticeable 
among the male hybrids. Eor instance, some have the dull brick-
red throat of (7. japonica and the black anchor-shaped mark of 

G. coturnix, others have only the upper two-thirds of the throat 
dnll red and the lower third white, while again a third lot have in 
addition a black band down the centre of the red part, and all 
kinds of intermediate stages between these three examples may be 
found. These hybrids are, so far as I know. generally only found 
in Mongolia, China, and Japan, though there is one speeimen in 
the very large series of the British Museum said to have been 
obtained in Bootan. Equally also, though of secondary importance, 
G. coturnix interbreeds freely with the red-throated resident race 
(C. cajpeyids) in Sonth Africa and the islands surrounding the 
coast, and the resnlts are seen in the many male birds from South 
Africa and Sonthern Enrope &c. in which the white parte on the 
sides of the head and throat are more or less sufTused with the 
bright rufous-ehestnut of the resident bird. 
The females of conrse are not to be distinguished. I may acld 
that Indian examples of G. coturnix are, generally speaking, very 
pure bred and seldom show any trace of rufous on the sides of the 
head and throat.

Atlitlt htale. Top of the head black, all the featbers tipped with 
brw n or reddish brown, a -white or pale buff stripe down tbe 
middle of tbe head ; featbers of tbe mantle sandy or reddisb brown, 
each with a wide buff black-edged shaft-stripe tapering to a point, 
and with a wide black bar or blotcb on one or botb webs. Tbe 
scapulars and featbers of tbe back, rump, and upper tail-coverts 
are very^iimlar to tbe mantle, but tbe ground-eolour is generally 
black with narrow -y-shaped transyerse bars of dirty or reddisb 
white, and tbe fehaft-stripes are wider and confmed to a line of 
featbers down each side of the spine, forming a regulär pattern* 
The Icsser, median, and secondary coverts are sandy brown, with 
vcry narrow sbaft-btripes and transversa bars of buff edged witb 
black. Primaries, primary-coverts, and secondaries blackisb 
brow n, the former barred and mottled on tbe outer web, tbe latter 
on botb, witb buff. Lores and superciliary stripe white, a reddish 
or bluckihb-brown band commences bebind the upper angle of tbe 
nostril and passes tbrough tbe eye over tbe ear-coverts ; a black or 
sometimes reddish-blaek band extends backwards to bebind tbe 
eye from the angle of the gape; a black angle-shaped mark * 
commences on the ehin and passes down the middle of the throat, 
the arms «Irving upwards to the ear-coverts. Tbe remaining portions 
of the sides of the head, ehin, and throat are white, and usually 
separated from the ehest by an ill-defined band of black and rustcoioured 
spots. Chest rufous buff, with white shafts, shading into 
whitish buff on the rest of the underparts; sides and flanks reddish 
boff, spotted with black, and with wide white black-edged shaft-
stripes. Tail-feathers black, tipped with whitish and barred with 
buff. Total length Cr 7 inches, wing 4*2, tail 1-5, tarsus 1. 

Yoimg males resemble the adult female, but the chest has only 
a few black spots. 

Adult female. Differs from the adult male in having no black 
band down the middle of the throat, only the arms of the anchor-
shaped mark bedng somewhat imperfectly represented, and the chest 
is more or less thickly spotted with black. 

Hab. Europe, Asia (except the south-west corner, Siam, &c), 
Afriea. 

* In söme specimens the middle black band is very mucb wider tban in 
otbera, and eovers a large part of the throat These are apparently very old 
»peüimens.

A curious variety or seml-melanistic form of G. coturnix occurs 
in Spain in the marshy neighbourhood of Valencia. In tbe male 
the general colonr of the Upper parts is black, with narrow buff or 
rufous cross-bars ; the pattern formed by the Wide golden-buff shaft-
streaks on the feathers of the mantle and on either side of the body 
is normal; the greater part of the sides of the head, chin, and 
throat are black, interspersed here and there with a white feather ; 
the chest-feathers are mottled with black, and the feathers of the 
sides and flanks are black, dotted with rufous, and with a wide 
white shaft-stripe down the middle of each. In the female all the 
underparts are suffused with dirty brown. 
a7 b. (J 2 ad«s^- Valencia, Oct. (H. Smtnders). Tweeddale Coli. 

Subsp. a. Coturnix capensis.

Adult male. DifTers from the adult male of O. coturnix in ha/ring 
the lores, sides of the head, chin, and throat bright rufous chestnut, 
the ehest washed with the same. Total length 6-3 Inches, wing 
3*9-4, tail 1-4, tarsus 1*1. 


Acliät female. The plumage does not difier from that of C. coturnix. 
Younger males resemble the adult, but the black band down the 
micldle of the throat is indistinctly represented or absent. 


Hab. South Africa, south of about 15° S. lat., Mauritius, 
Madagascar, Comoro Islands, Cape Verd Islands, Canaries, Madeira, 
and Azores.

Coturnix ussuriensis, Bogd. Comp. Av. Imp. Boss, fasc. i. p. 45 (1884) 
[Amoor & Lake Baikal]. » 
Adult male. Differs from the male of O. coturnix cbiefly in 
baving the lores, sides of the bead, chin, and throat uniform dull 
brick-red, without a trace of the black anchor-shaped mark; the 
margins of the flank-feathers mostly rufous and much less spotted 
with black. Total length 5*7 inches, wing 3*9, tail 1*2, tarsus 1*05. 
Adult female. Differs from the female of C. coturnix in having 
the fea^hers of the chin and throat elongate and lanceolate, 
especially those on the sides of the latter, which aro usually margined 
on the outer web with rufous; the margins of the ehest, 
flank- 
and side-feathers mostly rufous, much less spotted with black. 
Toung males have the elongate throat-feathers like those of the 

240 
PHASIANTD-a!. 

adult female, and the middle of the throat is suffused with duH 

brick-red ; as the short rounded feathers of the adult are moulted 

the elongate feathers disappear ; otherwise .the plumage re&embles 

that of the adult male. 

Hab. Japan, Manchuria, S.E. Mongolia, and China, as far south 

as Canton. Specimens have also been obtained 
in Bhootan and 

Karen-nee.

AcluU male. Differs from the male of C. coturnix chiefly in having 
the black pattern on the throat and neck more strongly marked; a 
large blaek patch covering the middle of the ehest and breast; the 
feathers of the sides and flanks black, widely margined on the sides 
with white or buff, and the outer webs of the primaries uniform 
brown, never barred and marked with rufous or buff. Iris brown ; 
bill dark horny ; legs and feet pale flesh. Total length 5 inches, 
wing 3*5, tail 1*2, tarsus 1*05. 

Adultfemcüe is very similar to the female of C. coturnix, but may 
be at once distinguished by having no buff or rufous bars or

crucijrera, lleugl Vor/. JS.O.-Afr. p. 51, no. 533 (1856);

Atlult male. Differs chiefty from the maleof G. cotumix in having 
the general eolour of the Upper parts, including the wing-eoverts, 
blacki&h brown; the primaries uniform brown, never barred with 
rufous or buff; the black pattern on the throat more strongly 
marked; the geaeral eolour of the sides of the neck and rest of the 
Widerparts light chestnut; a large blaek pateh in the middle of the 
ehest and breast as in G. coromandeliea, and the feathers of the sides 
and lanks blaek down the middle. Iris rieh brown; bill black ; 
legs and feefc salmon-eolour. Total length 6 inches, wing 3*7, 
tau 1-3, tarsus 1. 

Atlult female. Differs from the female of G. cotumiw in the much 
darker eolour of Upper parts* in having the outer webs of the 
primaries uniform and the underparts rufous buff or dull chestnut, 
washed wlth dusky on the ehest, most of the feathers with a pale 
dark-edged ßhaft-stripe, and the feathers of the sides mottled and 
barred with blaek and buff. 

Mab. Africa, south of about 15° X. lai, recently obtained at

5. Coturnix pectoralis. 
Austral Partridge, Lath. Gen. Bist. viii. p. 303 (1823). 

Coturnix pectoralis, Goidd, P. Z. 8. 1837, p. 8 [X. S. Wales]; id. 
j$i/n. B. Austr. text & pl. fig*. 1 (1837-8); Gray, List of B. pt, iii.

Synoicus australis, Ramsay, Ibis, 1865, p. 86 [Port Denison]. 

Aclult male, Upper parts as in tlie male of O. coturnix, but 
somewhat darker, especially on the wing-coverts; superciliary 
stiipes, sides of head, chin, throat, and fore part of neck uniform 
dull briek-red, with out any black markings; a black patch in the 
middle of the ehest; feathers on the sides of the ehest, breast, and 
belly white, with a black stripe down the shaft; sides and flanks 
very similar to those of C. coturnix. The outer webs of the 
primaries aro uniform brown, not barred and marked with bufF. 
Iris hazel; bill black; legs and feet pearly yinous white. Total 
length 7 inches, wing 4-1, tail 1*5, tarsus *9. 

Aclult female. Upper parts darker than in the female of G. 
coturnix; sicles of the head and throat whitish buff dotted with 
black; feathers of the ehest and breast with a black curved submarginal 
bar on either side of the shaft, not conüuent at the 
extremity, but separated by a wide buff isthmus ; sides of the belly 
with longitudinal lines and spots of black. Bill olive. 

In younrjer male speeimens the sides of the face and throat are 
paler, the black patch on the breast is not developed, and the outer 
edge of the outer web of the primaries is slightly mottled with buff. 

Hab. Australia; Tasmania.

Coturnix novao zealandia% Quoy §• Öfwm. Foy. AstroL, Zool. i. p. 242,

p. 507 (1846); Ellman, Zool. 1861, p. 74G8; Banst, Ibis, 1862. 
p. 102; Gray, Ibis, 1862, p. 233 [N. & S. Islands] ; id. List Gallince 
Brit. Mus. p. 61 (1867); Ilaast, J.f. 0.1868, p. 243; Gray, Ilaud-L 
B. ii. p. 268 (1870); Finsch, J. f. 0.1870, p. 334; Button, Ibis, 
1870, p. 398 [Auckland ; rare]; Potts, Tr. N. Zeal. Inst. ii. an. 
viii. p. 66 (1870), iiL art. xi. p. 92 (1871); Button, Cat. B. A\ 
Zeal. p. 22 (1871); Finsch, J.f. 0. 1872, p. 168; Potts, Trans. A.

(1873); Finsch, J.f. 0.1874, pp. 172,193;ttkarpe,App. Voi/. Ereb. 
$ Terr., Birds, pp. 10, 27, pl. 8 (1875); Buller, Man. B. N. ZeaL 
p. 43, pl. xix. (1882); id. Bist. B. N. ZeaL i. p. 225, pl. xxiii.

pp. 168,173 (1892). 
Adult male. Very similar to 0. pectoralis in general appearance, 
faut the general colour of the upper parts is warmer and more intermixed 
with rufous buff; the sides of the head, chin, and throat only 
are brigliter brick-colour, and there is a blaek band, as it were the 
arm of the anchor-mark, on eaeh side of the throat, while the foro 
part of the neck resembles the ehest and middle of the breast, 
which, in what appears to be a very old male, are mostly black 
with irregulär buff spots and markings near the extremity of the 
margin, while in another adult male specialen these parts are black, 
irregularly barred and tipped with whitish buff. The rest of the 
nnderparts are rauch more thickly marked with black. Iris hazel; 
bill black; legs and feet pale nesh-brown. Total length 7*6 inches, 
wing 4*6, tail 1*8, tarsus 1. 

Adult female. The upper parts resemble those of the male; on 

the linder surface the plumage is similar to that of the adult femalo 

of Ö. pectoralis, but the black bars on the feathers of the ehest and 

breast are confluent, or very nearly so, and 
form W-shaped 

markings; on the rest of the underparts the black markings are 

stronger and more numerous.

Younger indes resemblo the females, but the throat resembles 
fhat of the male adalt, and the black markings on the underparts 
are nmch wider and more completely fused in the median line, 
assuming a V-shaped form. 

Hab. New Zealand (said to be nearly extinct).

SYNCECUS. r-
Type. 
Synoicus, Gould, JB. Austr. v. pl. 89, or pt. xii. (1843) .. S. australis. 
Svnaecus, Aqass. Index Universalis, p. 358 (18413) S. australis. 
Synoecus, Mull. P. Z. S. 1869, p. 280 S. australis. 
Ist primary is about equal to the 4th and somewhat shorter than 
the 3rd, whieh is the longest. 
Tail composed of 10 (rarely 12) feathers, feeble, rounded; outer 
feathers miich shorter than the middle pair, whieh are less than 
half the length of the wing. 

Axillaries short, grey. 
Tarsus without spurs. 
Hange. Australia, New Guinea, Timor, and Plores. 

Key to the Sjpeäes. 

A. 
Sides of the crown not mostly black ; Upper parts not 
blotched with black, or with the black markings 
present in the form of moderate bars; shaft-stripes 
narrower, confined to the shaft itself. (Males.) 
a. Chin and throat dirty white. 
australis, p. 247. 
b. Chin and throat dull rufous 
raalteni, p. '249. 
B. 
Sides of the crown black or mostly black; upper 
parts coarsely blotched with black; shaft-stripes 
wider than the shafts themaelvea. (Females.) 
c. Chest pale rufous buff, barred all over with black. australis, p. 247. 
d. 
Chest pale, dull rufous, with black bars nearly 
obsolete raalteni, p. 249. 
The common Australian Swamp-Quail (Syncems australis) has 
been divided by Gould into no less than four species, whieh are 
apparently founded on differences of age or sex. As he has not 
given comparative diagnoses, it is impossible to see from his deseriptions 
in what partieulars his supposed species dirTer. He was himself 
aware that his distinetions were weak and far from satisfactory,

24 8 
PHASMTDiE. 

Synoecus cervinus, Sharpe, J. Zinn. Soc. xiii. p. 504 (1877) [S.E. 
New Guinea]; Forbes, P. Z. S. 1878;pp. 121, 127 [Cape York & 
Booby Is.J; id. Voy. ChalL, JSirds, pp. 84, 92 (lb80) j Salmd. 
Om. Pap. iii. p. 254 (1882) [Pole Is.]. 

Adult male. In very old examples—that is, inbirds of ihres ycars 

old or more (S. sordidus, Gould)—most of tlie markings on the upper 

and underparts disappear, and there is a general tendency to 

uniformity of colour in the plumage. The feathers of the Upper 

parts are reddish brown on the sides, and dull grey down the middle, 

with only a few fine mottlings of black; while the white shafts so 

conspicuous in younger examples are searcely apparent; on the 

imderparts the buff feathers are grey down the middle, and the 

V-shaped black bars are nearly obsolete; the superciliary stripes 

and sides of the head and throat are dnll grey; the outer webs of 

the quills indistinetly mottled with rufous, and the tail-feathers 

uniform 
grey. 

I n birds of the second year (typical J3. australis) the upper parts 

are mottled with black and barred with rufous, and the narrow 

white shafts of the feathers are clearly marked; the outer webs of 

the quills thickly mottled with rufous ; the superciliary stripes, 

sides of the head, and throat pale vinaceous white ; the feathers of 

the underparts burT, each with a series of V-shäped cross-bars ; and 

the tail-feathers black, barred with buff. Total 
length about 7*5 

inches, wing 3-5-4-2, tau 1*7-2-0, tarsus 0*9. 

A quiu young male has most of the plumage of the upper parts 

like that of the adult female, but on the sides of the mantle 

numerous feathers of the second year (or JS, australis stage of 

plumage) are moulting in. 

Adult female differs from the male in having the black markings 

and patches on the upper and underparts much coarser ; the centres 

of the feathers are not grey, and the shaft-stripes, which are much 

wider than in the male, are pale buff. 

Hat. South-eastern New Guinea, Australia, Tasmania.

2. Syncecus raalteni. 

Perdix raaltenii, Müll. <$• Sohl. Land-en Volkenk. p. 158 (1839-44); 

Gray, Gen. B. iii. p. 506 (1846) ; Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 160. 
Cotumix raaltenii, Wall. JP. Z. 8. 1863, p. 486 [Timor; Mores]. 
Cüturnix (Synoicus) raalteni, Gray, List Gallince Brit Mus. p. 62 

(1867); id. JBand-l. B. ii. p. 269 (1870). 

Aduli male. In the dielest example the feathers of tbe upper 
parts are rufous with grey centres, Yery faintly mottled or dotted 
with black, and with mere indications of white shaft-stripes; the 
top of the head reddish brown: quills brown, washed and mottled 
with pale rufous on the outer web ; sides of head, chin, throat, and 
rest of underparts dull rufous, most of the feathers with pale buff 
at the extremity of the shaft, those of the sides and flanks with 
traces of dark bars; tail brown, indistinctly mottled with buff. 

In a somewhat less mature bird the pale shaft-stripes on the 

• upper parts are much more distinet; and the feathers of the lower 
breast, belly, sides, and flanks are distinctly barred with black. 

Total length 7*4 inehes, wing 3*5-3*8, tail 1*5-1*7, tarsus 0*95. 

Adult female. Differs from the male in having the whole of the 
upper parts blotched and marked with black, while the shaft-stripes 
are much wider and more distinet; the chin and throat are whitish 
buff, and the rest of the underparts are washed with pale rufous 
and much more strongly barred with black. 

Hab. Islands of Timor and Elores. 

a-c. 6 $ ad. sk. E. Timor. A. R. Wallace, Esq. [C.].

A'htlt male. Middle of tlie head, nape, back, and rump brown, 
with verniieulations and subterminal bars and blotches of black: 
inoät of the feathers below the nape with whitish sbafts, widest on 
thc lower back and rump. (In very old examples the shal't-stripes 
eiitirely disappear.) Eorehead, sides of the crown and head and 
neck, lt*sser and median wing-coverts, andupper taü-covertsmore or 
less washed with dark slate-blue. Outer webs and ends of the outer 
median wing-eorerts brighc chestnut. Primaries, secondaries, and 
their eorerts brown ; the outer -webs of the secondaries and of their 
coverts sandy, faintly Termiculated with brownish; a white band 
from the nostril to the eye; chin and throat blaek, a white band 
edged with black on either side; fore part of the neck white, 
edged with blaek ; upper part of the ehest, sides of the breast, sides 
and fianks slate-blue, resfc of the underparts rieh chestnut. (In 
very old speeimens the chestnut on the underparts gradually takes 
the place of the slate-blue tili very little of the latter remains.) 
Tail chestnut. Total length b'2 inches, wing 2-8, tail 1*1, 
tarsus *8. 

Yomiger males hare the general colour of the upper parts 
browner than in the adult, the black markings larger and more 
numerous, and almost all the feathers with a pale buff or white 
shaft-stripe; down the middle and along either side of the head the 
shaft-stripes of the feathers form pale bands. The wing-coverts 
resemble the plumage of the back, and only one or two show traees 
of chestnut on the margins of the outer webs; the edges of the 
black and white markings on the throat and neck are less sharply 
clefined. On the underparts the slate-blue predominates, and on 
the sides and flanks is mixed with sandy and spotted with black. 
Tau slate-blue, edged with chestnut.

Adultfemctle. Upper surface rcsembles that of the young male, but

rufous büß: towards the sides; rest of nnderparts buff, paler 

towards the middle of the breast and belly; ehest, sides, and flanks 

barred with blaek. 
(In yory old examples the barring on the 

ehest nearly disappears.) 

Immature females hare the feathers of the upper breast and sides 

spotted. As age inercases these spots resoiye themselyes into 

transverse black bars.

Adiät male. DifYers from the male of E. chinensis in having the 

whole of the Upper parts blackish browu washed with slate, except 

the wing-coverts, scapulars, upper tail-coverts, sides, and flanks,

blotched with black. (In very old specimens these marks disappear.)

further down on the ehest; and the rest of the underparts very 

dark slate-grey. Total length 5*2 inches, wing 2-9-3, tail 1*1, 

tarsus *8. 

Adult female. Yery similar to the female of the subspecies E. 

lineata^ but the wing-coverts and scapulars are more distinctly 

barred with black. The average wing-measurement is 3-1-3-2.

Adult male and female. Top of the head brown, shading inio 
sienna on ehest and mantle, each feather with a dark band down tlie 
sbaft; those of the head are also margincd with brownish -white, 
whüe those of the other parts have a submarginal band of whitisb, 
and are irregularly barred with. brown towards the margins. 
Best of the back, rump, and upper taü-coverts dull brown, finely 
vermiculated with whitish. Scapulars and lesser and median wing-
coverts the saine, but more coarsely marked with white and intermised 
with sienna towrards the middle. Primaries and secondaries 
and their coverts brown, finely mottled on the outer and slightly on 
the inner web with rufous. Superciliary stripes, cheeks, chin, 
throat, ancl neck dark brown, margined with whitish. Middle 
of the breast uniform buff; sides of the breast, sides and Hanks 
chestnut, irregularly and transversely barred towards the margins 
of the webs with dark brown and white. Thighs dark brown, 
irregularly barred with white; belly and under tail-coverts dark 
brown, the latter fringed with dirty white. Tail dark brown, 
faintly mottled, especially on the inner feathers, with rufous buff. 

Male. Total length 11 inches/wing 5*2, tail 3*6, tarsus 1-2. 
Female. Total length 9-5 inches, wing 4*7, tail 3*1, tarsus 1-3. 
Mab. Same as that of the genus.

Adult male andfemale. Top of the head recldish brown, ochraecous

s 

258 
PHASIANIDJ5. 

rump, and upper tail-coverts pale olive-brown, finely vermiculated 

with lighter colour and black, some of the longer upper tail-coverts 

bring also spotted along the shaf t with black. Primaries and second


aries and their eoverts light chestnut, darker towards the extremities 

of both webs; the secondaries and their eoverts narrowly margined 

and irregularly barred with buff. Ear-coverts chestnut (in some male 

speeimens black), superciliary stripe, sides of face, chin, and throat 

buff or palerust-colourod. Feathers of the ehest olive-brown, with a 

chestnut shaft-patch at the extremity, and a white blotch on either 

margin. Breast and rest of underparts pale buff; sides, flanks, and 

under tail-coverts with large black subterminal heart-shaped spots. 

Tail-feathers reddish brown, the middle pairs irregularly barred and 

mottled with buff. Male provided with a pair of spurs, female 

generally without. Upper mandible deep brown, lower brown; iris 

orange-hazel. Legs and feet grey, pale brownish grey, or dark. 

Male. Total length 12*3 inches, wing 5*8, tail 4*4, tarsus 1*9. 

Female. Total length 11*5 inches, wing 5*6, tail 4-2, tarsus 1*7. 

Immature speeimens differ in having buff shaft-stripes on the 
feathers of the back of the neck, back, wiug-coverts, and scapulars, 
and the rump and Upper tail-coverts with larger subterminal black 
spots, often running some distance up the shaft.

Sexes different. 
Tail composed of 14 feathers, fairly long, rounded, the outer 
feathers more than an inch shorter than the middle pair. 
Ist primary is much shorter than the 2nd, whieh is equal to or 
shorter than the lOth ; 5th and 6th slightly the longest. 

Tarsi rather longer than the middle toe and claw, and armed in 
the male with two and sometimes with three pairs of spurs. In the 
female one pair of spurs is developed, rarely two. though one or 
other of the tarsi may be armed with two spurs. 

Axillaries short. 
A large naked space before and around the eye. 


Bange. India and Ceylon.
