PHASlANIDiE. 

Achat mnh*. Lores and forehead sandy buff, shading mto dank 
brown on the top and back of tbe head; nape paler brown ; rest o± 
iho upper parte rufous cbcstnut; most of tbe feathers, especially 
those of tbo mantle, margined with pale greyish brown; and the 
wing-coverts, lower back, rump, and upper tail-corerts fmely 
Yermiculated with blaek. Quills brown, except tbe outer webs ot 
tbe secondaries, wbicb resemble tbe eoYerts; rest of tbe bead and 
neck pale greyish brown, sbading into whitish on tbe chm and 
throat • underparts chestnut or rufous chestnut, each feather margined 
with pale sandy brown or buff. Many specimens have a 
larger or smaller patch of feathers in the middle of the breast, 
ornamented with ash-grey centres ; these markings have apparently 
no reference to age, locality, or season. Under tail-corerts chestnut, 
vermiculated with black. Tail blackish brown, the centre pair of 
feathers and the outer webs of the second and third pairs mottled 
with rufous; legs and feet coral-red; bill dusky red at the base, 
horny touards the tip. Total length 14*6 inches, wing 6*3, tail 5*4, 
tarsus 1*7. 

An immature male has the plumage of the adult, but the upper 
parts and breast are intermixed with feathers resembling those of 
tbe feinde, and the spurs on the tarsi are wart-like or absent. 

Achat female differs from the male in having all the upper parts, 
especially the mantle and wing-coverts, mottled and irregularly barred 
with black, most strongly marked in specimens from Southern India. 
The feathers of the neck and underparts tipped with black, and all 
the tail-feathers mottled with rufous or buff. Tarsi sometimes 
without spurs, iisually with a pair and often two.

* Specimens from Mount Aboo are undoubtedly somewhat paler than those 
from the Nilghiris. The males have the breasts and underparts generally paler 
chestnut. and the feniales haxe the black rnarkings paler and less distinet, 
especially on the upper parts of the body. There caimot, however, be the 
slightest ground for suppo&ing that there are even two distinet races, much less, 
species, as this Variation in tint is rally aecounted for by the clifference in 
climate, the annual rainfall on Mount Aboo being slight compared with that of 
Calicut and the Malabar coa&ts, whence the most richly coloured birds in our 
series were obtained.

Adult male. Top of the head Hack, more or less glossed with 
dull purplish green, each feather with a white shaft usually ending 
in a subterminal white spot; mantle, back, and rump chestnut, the 
feathers, especially of the former, with white black edged ocelli at 
the extremity, but in some examples these markings are nearly or 
entirely absent on the lower back and rump; wing-coverts and 
scapulars resemble the feathers of the mantle, but are more or less 
mixed with dark brown, glossed with dull purplish green. Quills dark 
brown. Lores, sides and underparts of the head and neck white, 
spotted and barred with black; chin white. Chest, breast, and 


2G4 PHASLiNIDJE. 

middle of belly buff, each feathcr with a black terminal spot, much 

roduced in olcl examplcs ; sides and flanks like the back; nnder tail


coveris the same, but more mixed with black. Upper tail-coverts 

and tail black, slightly glossed with pnrplish green. Legs and feet 

grey ; bill blackish hörn ; lower mandible paler. Total length 

13-0 inchcs, wing 6-2, tail 4*8, tarsus 1-5. 

Immature males diffcr from the above in having the greater part 

of the wing-coverts and seapulars brownish black, glossed with 

purplish green, and the ehest and breast much more heavily spotted 

with black. 

Adultfemale. Top of the head black, with chestnut shaft-stripes ; 

neck and upper parts of the body dnll olive-brown, most of the 

feathers narrowly margined with dusky ; lores, snperciliary stripes, 

and cheeks mostly dark chestnut; chin and throat chestnut or 

chestnut mixed with buff, with a rather elearly marked buff band 

on each aide; ehest and breast ochraeeous brown, shading into dull 

olive-brown on the lower parts, most of the feathers with a sin all 

blackish terminal spot or margin. Quills and tail as in the adult 

male. Total length 12*6 inches, wing 5*9, tail 4*4, tarsus 1*4. 

Immature femcäes have the plumage of the upper parts flnely 

mottled and irregularly barred with chestnut and black; the outer 

secondaries and tail-feathers are more distinctly barred. 

In still younger examples the breast and mantie are spotted 

with buff.

Adult male. Middle o£ the crown and nape pale brownish grey, 
each feather with a black shaft-stripe ; sides black, separated from 
the blaek supcrciliary stripos on either side by a wide white band 
confluent with its fellow on the fore part of the heacl, which is 
also white; rest of the npper parts, wing-coverts, and scapiüars 
grey, more or less washed with olive-brown, each feather margined 
on the sides with blaek;fligh.fc-feath.ors dark brown, the primaries 
more or less mottled with rufous buff on the margin of the outer 
webs; a white spot before and behind the eye, and a white band 
down each side of the throat commencing below the eye; rest of 
the plumage on the sides of the head, chin, and throat blaek; rest 
of undorparts resemble the upper parts, but are somewhat grey er, 
except on the sides and flanks; linder tail-coverts black, fcipped and 
evenly spotted on either web with white. Tau dark olive-brown ; 
bill corai-red; logs and feefc dull red. Total length 9 inehes, 
wing 3-5, tail 3, tarsus 1. 

Immature males differ from the adult in having the last secondaries 
blaek, with a narrow buff shaft-stripe and transversa bars and marks 
like those of the female; a few ot the feathers of the middle of the 
back are brown marked with black, and almost like those of the 
female. 

Adult female. Upper parts warm light brown; some of the 
feathers of the middle of the head and all those of the nape and 
back of the neck with black shalt-stripes; a black band on each 
bide of the crown; those of the back and rump with subterminal 
triangulär black spots edged above with buff. Upper tail-coverts 
with irregulär black blotches and intermediate buff bars along the 
shaft; the feathers of the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts 
are also finely mottled with black; wing-coverts and scapulars like 
the back; flight-feathers brown, mottled and irregularly barred on

3. Ithagenes sinensis. 
Ithaginis sinensis, David, Ann. Sei. Nat. (5) xviii. art. 5, p. 1 (1873)

Adult male. Differs from the male of I. geoffroyi in having the 
sides of the crest brownish black : the patch of colour on the wing-
coverts rust-brown, some of the feathers being sometimes narrowly 
margined with crimson; the chin, throat, and fore part of neck 
blackish grey, shading into brownish grey on the ehest, each feather 
with a narrow whitish shaft-stripe, those on the chin being washed 
with crimson. Total length 17*6 inches, wing 8, tail 7, tarsus 2-Q. 
Immature and young males generally resemble those of I. cruentus, 
but the brown patch on the wing-coverts is distinctly marked though 
mixed with black. 
Adult female. Differs from the female of 7". geoffroyi in having 
the upper parts browner, more like those of the female of I. cruentus, 
but paler; the chin and throat whitish grey; and the underparts 
pale brownish buff, scarcely vermiculated on the ehest and breast. 
Total length 16-2 inches, wing 7*5, tail 5*9, tarsus 2-4. 
Hab. North of the Nan-shan and Kan-su Mountains; Sinling 
Mountains between Shen-si and Ho-nan.

T. satyra. 
Tail composed of 18 feathers, rather long, wedge-shaped, the 
outer pair about two-thirds of the length of the centre pair. 

The Ist primary is shorter than the lOth and mueh shorter than 
the 2nd, which is about equal to the 8th or 9th : 4th or 5th slightly 
the longest. 

The male has a short erest, a pair of elongate üeshy horns 
inserted aboTe the eye, and a large gular Aap, most prominent 
in the breeding-season and especially when the hirds are excited hy 
passion. Cheekd and throat thinly covered with hair-like feathers. 

Bides of the head feathered. 

Axillaries very long. 

Taraiw equal to or slightly lonsrer than the middle toe and claw, 
and arnied in the male (rarely in the fernab) with a short stont 
spur. 

luittfjt. Northern India; Himalayas from Cashmere to Assam 
and N.E. Manipur; China, north to Shen-si, west to Sze-chuen,

Adiät male. Top and sides of the head "black ; elieeks and throat 
thinly covered with black hairy feathers; sides of the oeeiput, 
mantle, ehest, breast, and rest of underparts orange-carmine, 
the basal part, espeeially of the flank-feathers, black, irregularly 
barred with buff; each of the feathers of the lower parts of the 
mantle and ehest and the rest of the underparts with a round white 
terminal spot edged externally with black, except on the belly, 
where the black margin is partially or entirely absent; back, scapulars, 
inner wing-coyerts, rump, and upper tail-coverts olive-brown 
at the extremity and black barred with buff towards the base, each 
feather with a white black-edged spot at the tip ; rest of wing-
coverts the sarne, but edged on each side with dark orange-carmine. 

2C). TKAG0PAN. 

Quills and primary-eoverts black, barred on botk webs with rufous 

buff; bastard-wing pale orange-red tipped with. black; lesser and 

median under wing-coverts orange-red. Tau black, thc basal 

part barred and variegated with buff. Bill blackish brown; uppcr 

throat and orbits purplish blue; gular wattlo orange or salmon with 

transverse blue bars ; horns greenisb blue; legs and toes pale flesh


colour. Total lengtb 26 inches, wing 10*2, tail 9-5, tarsus 3-3. 

Immature males resemble thefemale, buttho orange-red feathers 

of the male are more or less developed on the neck and sides of the 

occiput; some of the black feathers of thc head are likewise prosent, 

and some of the feathers of the back and scapulars are spotted with 

white at the extremity. 

Adolf female. General colour above black mottlecl with buff, 

rufous-buff, and sandy, many of the feathers of the back, scapulars, 

and wing-coverts witb buff shaft-spots ; on the wings the rufous-

buff tint predominates. Quills as in tbe adult male. Chin and 

throat white or buff; nnderparts sandy and buff finely mottled 

with lines of black, most of the feathers with whitish or buff 

triangulär shaft-spots. Tail black, irregularly mottled and barred 

with buff and rufous-buff. Total length 19*5 inches, wing 9, 

tail 7*1, tarsus 2*9. 

In a quite young speeimen nearly all the feathers of the upper 
and under parts have rufous shaft-stripes. 
Hab. The higher ranges of the Himalajas from Kumaon and 
Western British Gurhwal, through Nepal and Sikhim to Bhotan.

Satyra melanocephala, J. E. Gray, III Ind. Zool. i. pls. 46, 48 (1830


32): G. 11 Gray, List of JB. pt. iii. Galt p. 28 (1844).

tfe/ww, iVta. T'ög. p. 147, pl. 70 (1853); Fitz. Atl. Nat J ög. tig.

Ceriornis melanocepkala, Gray, Gen. B. iii. p. 499 (1845); id. Ceti. 

Hodgs. ed. i. p. 125 (1846); Blyth, Cat. Mus. As. Soc. p. 240 

(1849) ; Gould, JB. As. vii. pl. 45 (1855) ; Adams, P. Z. S. 1858, 

p. 498 [N.W. Himalajas]; id. P. Z. £ 1859, p. 185 [Pinjal Range: 5 
Jerd. B. Ind. iii. p. 517 (1863); Sclat. List of Phas. p. 10, pl. 10 
(1803) [N.W. of Simlaand S. Cashmere] ; Gray, List Gallince Brit. 
Mus. p. 41 (1807); v. Pelz. Ibis, 1868, p. 320 [Koteghur] ; JBeavan, 
Ibis,l8tl&, p. 380 [Simlal; Sclat P. Z. 8.1870, p.164; Gray, Hand~l 
B. ii. p. 262 (1870); Elliot, Mon. Phas. i. pl. 23(1872); Bume, 
N. § B. Ind. B. p. 522 (1873); Brooks, Str. F. iii. p. 256 (1875) 
[Mussooree and Gangaotri]; Marsh. B. Nest. Ind. p. 59 (1877; ; 
Hume 8f Marsh. Game B. Ind. i. p. 144, pl. (1878); Marsh. Ibis, 
1884, p. 422 [Chamba]; Oates, ed. Hume98 Nests § Eggs, iii. p. 410 
(1890). 
Adult male. Differs from T. satyra chiefly in having a Urach, 
longer black occipital crest tipped with dull Indian red ; no red 022 
the sides of the oeeiput; only the sides and back of the neck dark 
Indian red; a pateh of dark red on the upper wing-eoverts of the 
Shoulder only; the bastard-wing black, barred with buff like the 
quills; the white subterminal spots of the longer upper tail-coverts 
surrounded with rufous; the neck and upper part of ehest shining 
orange-scarlet, the feathers being unusually stifl and hard; the 
feathers of the rest of the underparts black at the extremity and 
dark red irregularly barred with black towards the base, excepfc the 
fiank-feathers, which have the basal part barred with black and buff; 
each feather with a round subterminal white spot. Bill blackish; 
naked skin round the eye bright red; fieshy horns sky-blue : gular 
Aap purple in the middle, flesh-coloured on the sides, spotted and 
edged with pale blue; legs and feet livid flesh-colour. Total length 
27 inches, wing 10-8, tau 9*2, tarsus 3*1. 

Imwiature males resemble the females in general plumage, but 
the head is suffused with black and the neck with dull orange-red, 
and most of the feathers of the upper parts and all those of the 
under have a round subterminal white spot edged with black. 

Adult female differs from the female of T. satyra in having the 
general tone of the plumage much greyer, with very little rufous 
buff even on the wings and underparts. 

Hab. Higher ranges of the Western Himalayas from Dative 
Gurhwal westwards to Cashmere.

3. Tragopau temmiacki. 
Satyra temminckii, J. E. Gray, LH Ind. Zool. i. pl. 50 (1830-32); 
G. R. Gray, List o/P.pt. iii. Gall. p. 28 (1844). 
Tragopan temminckii, Renn, P. Z. 8. 1834, p. 33. 
Ceriornis temmincki, Gray, Gen. B. iii. p. 499 (1845); Blyth, Cat. 
Mus. As. Soc. p. 240 (1849); Swinh. P. Z. S. 1863, p. 307 ; 8elat. 
List of Phos. p. 11, pl. 11 (1863) [China] ; Gray, List Gattin« Brit. 
Mus. p. 41 (1867); Gould, B. Asia, vii. pl. 46 (1869); Gray, Hand-L 

B. ii. p. 262 (1870); Sclat. P. Z. & 1870, p. 164 [N. & E. Szechuen 
to C. Ckinn]; Jerd. Ibis, 1870, p. 147 [Upper Assaraj; 
David, N. Arch. Mus. Bull vii. p. 11 (1871) [Sze-chuen]; Swinh. 
P. Z. S. 1871, p. 399; Blliot, Mon. Phos. i. pl. 24 (1872); Bamd 
<$• Oustal Ois. Chine, p. 118, pl. 112 (1877) [S.W. China to S. 
Shen-si] ; Hume, Str. F. viii. p. 201 (1879) [Mislimi Hills]; Sclat. 
P. Z. S. 1879, p. 117, pl. viii. %. 3 ; Seebohm, Ibis, 1891, p. 379 
[W. Sze-chuen]. 
Adult male. Differs from the male of T. satyra in having the 

orange-red occipital crest longer, the terminal part of the feathers 

of the upper parts Indian red and the subterniinal Spots pale pearl-

grey instead of white; the bastard-wing reddish buff, the inner 

webs barred and mottled with black ; the longer Upper tail-coverts 

brown, greyish towards the extremity, and margined all round with 

dark Indian red: the sides and fore part of the neck, Shoulders, 

and lesser under wing-coverts reddish buff; the outer half of the 

feathers of the rest of the underparts Indian red, each with a large 

subterminal grey spot; and only the feathers on the sides of the 

breast have this spot surrounded by black. Bill black; horns blue; 

gular Aap rieh deep blue, barred with red on the outer margins ; 

legs and feet red. Total length 25 inches, wing 9*9, tail 7*8, 

tarsus 3*2. 

Adult fmale. Appears to bear a close resemblance to the female 

of T. satyra. 

Hab. South-west and Central China; ranging from the Mishmi 

Hills through Sze-chuen to South Shen-si and Hoo-pee.

b. d ad. sk. China. J. R. Reeves, Esq.. [P.].

4. Tragopan blythi. 
Ceriornis temmincki, 
Jerd. (nee Gray) Ibis, 1870, p. 147 [Upper 
Assam]; Newtonj Ibis, 1870, p. 520. 
Ceriornis blythi, Jerd. P. As. Soc. Beng. 1870, p. CO; Sclat. P. Z. S. 
1870, pp. 103, 219, pl. 15; id. Ibis, 1870, p. 520; Gray, Hand-l. 

B. ii. p. 262 (1870); Gould, B. Asia, vii. pl. 47 (1872); Elliot, 
Mon. Phas. i. pl. 26 (1872); Godw.-Aust. P. Z. S. 1872, p. 496 
[Naga Hills]; Hume, Str, F. vii. p. 472 (1878) [ $ described]; Hume 
fy Marsh. Game B. Ind. i. p. 152, pl. (1878)• Godw.-Aust. Ibis, 
1878, p. 206 [Mozemah] ; id. P. Z. S. 1879, p. 457, pl. xxxix.; 
ßclat. P. Z. S. 1884, p. 477; Hume, Str. F. xi. p. 301 (1888) 
[N.E. Manipur]. 
Adult male. Differs from the male of T. satyra chiefly in the 
following points :—The orange-red feathers on the sides of the head 
form superciliary stripes commencing above the anterior part of the 
eye and joining one another posteriori)- in an occipital erest, as in 

T. melanoceplialus; the orange-carmine round the neck does not 
extend on to the mantle ; the terminal part of the feathers of the 
upper parts, on each side of the white spot, is very dark Indian red 
instead of olive-brown; the longer upper tail-coverts have the 
white subterminal spots surrounded with reddish brown as in T. 
melanoceplialus; the sides of the face, ehin, and throat are almost 
entirely naked. The fore part of the neck and ehest are orange-
carmine ; breast and belly smoky grey or greyish buff; sides and 
flanks like the upper parts. Bill blaek, orbital skin orange; horns 
azure; gular Aap brimstone tinged with blue; legs and feet light 
brown tinged with pink. Total length 24 inches, wing 10*2, tail 
7*4, tarsus 3*2. 
Adult female. Apparently nearly resembles the female of T. 
satyra, but has the upper surface blacker and less ferruginous, and 
the lower surface is paler and without the ferruginous buff. JFrom 
the female of T. melanocephalus rc is said to be distinguished by 
the black and buff of the upper surface, which are much richer and 
darker in tone. 

The female speeimen obtained by Mr. Hume from Mr. Gr. Damant 
and described by the former in the ' Birds of India' is not to be found 
amoug the speeimens in the Hume Collection. 

Hab. Higher ranges of North-east Assam, east of the Burrail 
ränge, and southwards to North~east Manipur. 

a. <$ ad. sk. Sadiya, Upper Assam. T. C. Jerdon, Esq. 
b. J ad. sk.

5. Tragopan caboti. 

Oeriornis caboti, Gould, P. Z. S. 1857, p. 161 [China!; id. B. As. 

vii. pl. 48 (1858): Sioinh. P. Z. S. 1863, p. 307; Sclat. List of 
Phas. p, 11 (1863) [? China] ; Sioinh. Ihis, 1865, p. 350 [Hüls of 
Quang-si ?]; Sclat P. Z. S. 1870, p. 164; Gray, Eand-l. B. ii. 
p. 262 (1870); Swinh. P. Z. S. 1871, p. 399; Salvad. P. Z. S. 
1871, p. 695; Elliot, Mon. Phas. i. pl. 25 (1872); David % Oustal. 
Ois. Ohme, p. 419, pl. 111 (1877) [Mts. hetween Fo-kien and 
Kiang-si]. 
Ceriornis modestus, David MS., David & Oustal Ois. Chine, p. 419 
(1877). 

Acluli male. Head very similar to that of T. blythi, but the black 
feathers of the back of the head cover also the nape ; the feathers 
of the upper parts differ in having the spot at the extremity of eacli 
terminal and buff-coloured, the edges maroon, and one or two 
irregulär white spots or short eross bars on the basal part of the 
shaft. The quills and tail-feathers are more coarBely barred and 
mottled with buff than in any of the other species of the genus. 
As in T. blythi the sides of the face, chin, and throat are naked. 
Chest, breast, and belly buff, mottled with black and buff and edged 
with Indian red towards the base ; sides and flanks mach like the 
feathers of the upper parts. Total length ca. 23 inches, wing 9*2, 
tail ea. 6S^ tarsus 2*9. 

Adult female is said to resemble the female of T. temmincM. 
Hab, South-eastern China: mountains between Fo-kien and 
Kiang-si; also the hüls in the interior of Qnang-si ?

27. LOPHOPHOBUS. Type 
Lophophorus, Temm. Pig. et Galt ii. p. 355 (1813) .. L. refulgens. 
Monaulus, Vieill. Analyse, p. 51 (1816) , L. impeyanus. 
Lophofera, Fleming, Philos. Zool. ii. p/230 (1822) L. impeyanus. 
Impeyanus, Less. TraiU d'Orn. p. 488 (1831) ... L. refulgens. 
Chalcopbasis, Mliot, Monogr. Phas. i. pl. xx. or pt. iv. 

(1871) L. sclateri. 

Tail composed of 18 feathers, of moderate length, and rounded, 
the outer pair about an inch and a half shorter than the middle pair. 

The Ist primary considerably shorter than the lOth ; 2nd about 

equal to the 8th; 5th slightly the longest. 
Head of male with an elongate crest of feathers or without a 
erest, all the feathers of the top of the head being curled (as in 

Manucodia comrii). 

Nearly naked space round the eye. 
Tarsus shorter than the middle toe and claw, armed in the male 
with a stout spur. 

Bange. Himalayas from Eastern Afghanistan to Korth-east 
Assam and northwarcls to Western Sze-chuen and Eastern 
Koko-nor.

279 

B. Nest Ind. p. 59 (1877); Eume # Marsh. Game B. Ind. i. 
p. 125, pl. (1878); Seidig, Str. F. viii. p. 342 (1879) [Nepal]; 
Fairbroth. Str. F. ix. p. 203 (1880) [Kummi, Afghanistan] ; 
Wardl.-Bams. lim, 1880, p. 70 [E. Afghanistan]; Gates, ed. 
Humiti Nests § Eggs, iii. p. 407 (1890). 
Lophophorus inrpeyanus, v. ref ulgens, Eodys, in Graifs Zool Mise. 

p. 85 (1844). 
Adult male. Top and sides of the head, crest of spado-shaped 
feathers, and a patch of feathors between the sides of the breast 
and mantle metallio green shot with blue and purple ; back and 
sides of tbe neck purple, shading into reddish copper and glossed 
with golden green; mantle sbining golden green ; outcr wing-
coverts mefcallie bluish green; inner wing-coverts and scapulars, 
rump and shorter upper tail-coverts bronze-crimson in some lights 
and purple edged with metallic bluish green in others; longer 
upper tail-coverts golden green; lower back snow-white; quills 
and bastard-wing brownish black ; throat blackiah, slightly glossed 
with golden green ; rest of the underparts blaek; tail pale rufous, 
darker towards the extremity. Bill black, cutting-edges of the 
mandibles pale horny ; orbital skin bright blue ; legs and feet dusky 
greenish or pale yellowish green. Total length 2ti inches, wiug 
11-6, tail 9, tarsus 3-2. 

Immature males resemble the females, but the chin and throat 
are usually more or less suffused with blaek, the markings on the 
underparts are coarser, and the whitish-buff shaft-stripes on the 
feathers are wider. In several cases at least some of the adult 
feathers appear to be obtained by a change of pattern without a 
moult. 

Adult female. Feathers of the top of the head, short crest, neck, 
mantle, and rump black, buff down the middle and often, especially on 
the mantle, with an irregulär black shaft-stripe or a black stripe on 
each side of the shaft meeting one another anteriorly; wing-coverts 
and scapulars the same, but the black lines in the buff centre part 
are still more irregulär and broken up into bars and mottlings ; 
feathers of the lower back alternately barred with irregulär black 
and buff, the bars more or less parallel to the edge of the feather; 
upper tail-coverts black barred with buff, the longer ones tipped 
with white freekled with blaek; quills blackish brown, the 
primaries slightly mottled with buff on the margin of the outer 
web, and the secondaries on both are margined at the ups with 
whitish buff. Sides of the head reddish buff mottled with black ; 
chin and throat white; feathers of ehest and sides of breast like 
the mantle; rest of underparts mottled with black and buff and 
with more or less distinet whito shaft-stripes. Tail black barred 
with rufous, and margined at the extremity with white, the blaek 
parts of the middle pair of feathers being mottled, especially towards 
the margins, with buff. Total length 23 inches, wing 10'5, tail 7*5, 
tarsus 2'6. 

Hab. Elevated forests of the Himalayas from Eastern Afghanistan 
to "Western Bhootan.

* Latham particularly mentions that in his speeimen " the back and wing-
coverts are rieh purple, tipped with green bronze," and the underparts and 
thighs dull black with here and there a greenish gloss. A glance at his figure 
will at once show that his description refers to the bird from Chamba, and not 
to L. refulgens, Temm.

2öl 
Adult male. Differs chiefly from L. refuhjens in having the 
feathers of the lower back golden green, shading into purplish 
blue towards their extremities; the longer uppor tail-coverts dark 
chestnut with golden-green tips; the purplish golden-bronze of the 
sides of the neck ncarly meeting in front; the chin, throat, and fore 
part of neck glossed with pale greenish gold, and the ehest and rest of 
underparts metallic golden green, shading into dark bluish green 011 
the sides, ilanks, and under tail-coverts. Total length 20 inches, 
wing 11*5, tail 9, tarsus 3.

3. Lophophorus Thiiysii. 
Lophophorus l'huysii, Verr. fy Geoff. St.-Hil Bull, Soc. Acclim. 

(2) iii. p. 223, pl. (1866) [Moupin Bist], iv. p. 706 (1867) ; Sei. 
P. Z. S. 1868, p. 1, pl. i.; id. Ibis, 1870, p. 297 [Ta-tsienlou];

p. 399; David, N. Arch. Mus. Bull vii. p. 11 (1871); Elliot, 
Mon. Phas. i. pl. 19 (1872); Gould, B. As. vii. pl. 54 (1873) ; 
Sclater, Ibis, 1874, p. 169 ; David ty Oustal. Ots. Chine, p. 403, pl. 
110 (1877) [Moupin, E. Koko-nor & W. Sze-chuen]; Seebohm.Ibis, 
1891, p. 379 [W. Sze-chuen]. 
Adult male. Differs from L. refulgens in the f ollowing points:— 
The occipital crest is purple-bronze and composed of ordinary 
elongate feathers; the back of the neck and upper part of the 
mantle are dark red-gold, shading into bronze-purple shot with 
greenish blue on the lower part of the mantle; the scapulars and 
wing-eoverts are not so purple and are shot with metallic golden, 
green; the rump-feathers resemble the wing-coverts, but are 
margined with white; the long upper tail-coverts, the outer part of 
both webs of the central pair of tail-feathers, the outer half of the 
outer webs of the rest, and the extremities of all bluish green shot 
with blue and purple; the rest of the tail-feathers (the middles of 
the centre pair, and the greater part of inner web and the inner 
half of the outer web of the rest) black, irregularly spotted on each 
side of the shaft with white. Bill horn-colour ; naked skin round 
the eye blue; legs and feet lead-colour. Total length 30 inches, 
wing 12-6, tail 10-3, tarsus 3*3. 

Adult female. May be distinguished at a glance from the female 
of L. refulgens, the whole of the lower back being pure white. 
Hab. Western Sze-chuen and Eastern Koko-nor. 

a, b. <5 $ imm. Mountains of Moupin, West- Purchased of M. Verreaux. 
sk. ern Sze-chuen (Dabry). (Types of the species.)

Adult male. Top of the head covcred with curly bluish-green 
feathers shot with purple and gold; ear-coverts the same but not

refleetions: manrle, longer scapulars, and median and greater 
secondary wing-coverts metallic green with purple refleetions* 
patch of lesser wing-coverts at the angle of the wing brilliant 
metallic dark green shot with blue and purple ; shorter scapulars 
and rest of lesser wing-coverts golden green and reddish copper; 
quills and primary-eoverts black, the seeondaries slightly glossed 
with bronze-green on the outer web; lower back, runip, and upper 
tail-coverts white, the two former mostly with narrow clark shaft-
stripes ; chin, throat, fore part of neck, and rest of underparts rieh 
black, with a slight purplish gloss on the sides and flanks; tail 
chestnut, with a white terminal band an inch and a quarter widc, 
the basal part of the feathers black irregularly barred and mottled 
with buff. Bill yellowish homy ; forehead, lores, and sides of the 
head bright blue, nearly naked ; legs and feet yellowish brown. 
Total length 26 inches, wing 11-8, tail 8*2, tarsus 3'1. 

Adult female. Head and neck very rieh dark umber-hrown, each 
feather of the former with a V-s^-aPe(^ Pale ochre mark; each of 
the latter has a centre line of rieher brown, finely mottled towards 
the margins. A broad extent of the rump and upper tail-eoverts 
pale ochraeeous white, very finely, delicately mottled with dark 
brown. Tail above rieh black, with six or seven narrow whitish 
bars and tipped with the same (the counter colouring of male); 
Shoulder of wing very rieh dark chestnut-brown, the shafts pale 
ochraeeous. Primaries rieh dark umber; seeondaries slightly 
mottled with brown. Cheeks and throat dark umber, markings like 
those on the head; chin white; breast, abdomen, and thighs dull 
umber. most delicately and finely mottled with pale ochre. Underside 
of tail black, with narrow white bars. The legs appear to have 
been of a pale grey and the bill whitish. [Godwtn-Aasten.'] "Wing 
11*5 inches, tail 8, tarsus 3.

3. Acomus inornatus. 
Acomus inornatus, Sahad. Ann. Mus. Civ. Genov. xiv. p. 250 (1879); 
id. P. Z. S. 1879, p. 651, pl. xlviii. [Mount Singalan, West Coast of 
Sumatra] ; Büttikofer, N. Leyd. Mus. ix. p. 77 (1887) [Padang, W. 
Sumatra]. 

Adult male (type)*. Reseoibles the females of both A. erythrophihalmus 
and A. pyronotus in general appearance, but rnay be at 
once recognized by its larger size, deep black colour all over, even 
on the head, and by having all the feathers of the upper parts, back, 
upper tail-coverts and wing-coverts, and also the feathers of the neck 
and breast, distinctly and sharply edged with shining dark bluish 
green, turning to blue near the hind neck, so that all these parts 
appear beantifully scaled ; this scale-like appearance is completely 

* A seoond male speeimen obtained by Klaesi in the Highlands of Padang, 
W. Sumatra, agrees exactly with Salvadon's type, so tbere can be now no 
cloubt that in this interesting and probably ancestral form tbe male is really 
black and closely resembles the femalea of the two other known species. Beccari 
writes on the label of the type speeimen " The female is reddish brown. I am 
told that it has no spurs." No speeimen has yet been obtained, but X much 
doubt the female of A. inomafus being reddish brown; probably the bird referred 
to was the female of L. rufa.

Adult male. Differs fromthe male of L. ignita in having the lower 
breast and rest of the underparts black, most of the feathors being 
edged with a steel-blue gloss; the feathers of the sides and ilanks 
with white shaft-stripes* ; and the central tail-feathers white. Bill 
white or horny white : facial skin and wattles bright smalt-blue; legs 
and feet vermilion-red, spurs whitish. Total length 27 inches, 
wing 11*6, tail 10*2, tar&us 4-3. 

An immature male, in which some of the rump-feathers and longer 
upper tail-coverts are black mottled with rufous like those of the 
female, has the wing-coverts, ehest, and underparts dull black, with 
scarcely a trace of steel-blue gloss except at the ends of some of the 
side feathers, which havo very narrow rufous-chestnut shaft-stripes; 
the white central tail-feathers with narrow black shaft-stripes on 
their basal two-thirds ; and a pair of short spurs 0*4 inch in length. 

* In most Sumatran speeimens (Euplocamus sumatranus, Dubois) the majority 
of the shaft-stripes are rufous buff or chestnut; but as this difference is also 
found, though in a slightly less marked degree, in some of the speeimens froin 
Bankasoon, Tenasserim, and is not constant even in Sumatran examples, it carniot 
be regardeel as ha\ing any specific importance. In Tenasserim speeimens it 
is certainly a sign of immature plumage ; in Sumatran birds it appears to be 
more or less retained in apparently I'ully adult examples with well-developed 
spurs.

Aduli feinde, Resembles the adult female of L. ignita, but is easily 
distinguishcd by baving the ground-colour of the lower back, rurnp, 
npper tail-coverts, wing-coverts, and scapulars paler than that of 
the neck* and mantle ; the outer webs of the secondaries chestnut, 
mottled with black, and the tail-feathers dark chestnut, the 
middle pairs bcing mottled with black ; soft parts as in the male, 
but not so bright. Total length 24 inches, wlng 10, tail 7*6, 
tarsus 3*6. 

In youmjer specimens the black yermiculations, especially on the 
greater wing-coverts and secondaries, are miich stronger.

Aäult male. Short feathers on the head, chin, and throat black; 
crest, neck, mantle, ehest, upper breast, scapulars, and npper tail-

buff, partially black on the outer web, and the two centre pairs 
uniform dark buff. Bill horny white, large smalt-bltie wattles 
surrounding the eye and covering the sides of the head ; legs and 
feet red. Total length 23 inches, wing 10*5, tail 8*4, tarsus 4*4. 

A quite young male has the plumage mostly like that of the young 
female, but the back of the head, middle of the nape, and the centres 
of the upper feathers are mostly black, slightly glossed on the margin 
with steel-blue.

LOPHURA, Sp. 

Fire-backed Pheasant, Lath Gen. Bist. viii. p. 184 (1823). 
Macartneya macartneyi, Less. Tratte ffOm. p. 493 (1831). 
Euplocamus ignitus, Sclat. (MG Shaw §• Nodd.), P. Z. S. 1863, p. 118;" 


Sölaf. P. Z. S. 1875, p. 380; Hirne, Str. F. v. p. 119 (1877); Elliot, 
Ibis, 1878, pp. 124, 411. 

Adult male. Eesembles the male of L. ignita, but differs in having the 
feathers down the centre of the low er breast and belly entirely black, those on 
the sides margined or largely raixecl with black, only the central part in some 
being rufous chestnut, and the central tail-feathers are white. 

This speeimen was sent by Mr. J. E. Eeeves froin China, ancl has eviclently 
been in captivity, for some of the quills of both wings have been cut. Elliot is 
of opinion that this speeimen is a hybrid between L. ignita, Shaw & Nocld , and 

I. rufa, Grray ; but I can see no reason for this conjeeture, and were it not for 
the fact that this bird was not shot in a wild state I should have no hesitation 
ha describing it as a distinet species. 
Since writing the above I have seen a second almost similar living speeimen 
in the collection of Mr. E. W. Marshall at Marlow, but was unable to discover 
whence ii^ had been obtained.

crest black, slightly glossed with steel-blue; neck, mantle, ehest,

wing-coverts, scapulars, and secondaries black, finely vermiculated

30 . LOBIOPHA.SIS.
crimson with bronze-red renections; primaries brownish black, 

faintly mottled with white; rest of the underparts, longer Upper 

tail-coverts, and tail black, slightiy glossed with steel-blue or purple ; 

the first three pairs of tail-feathers are unusually long and pointed, 

the third pair being considerably longer than first. Eacial skin and 

wattles red. Bill and spurs white; legs and feet scarlet. Total 

length 24 inehes, wing 9*8, tail 13, tarsus 3-4. 

A quite young male differs from the adult in having no crest; the 

neck and back mixed with rufous-chestnut feathers vermiculated 

with black like those of the adult 
female; the wing-coverts and 

secondaries interspersed with blackish-brown feathers, irregularly 

barred and mottled with buff, and the tail-feathers chestnut, 

marked and barred with black. 

Adult female. Top of the head and neck brown, shading into 
whitish on the chin and throat; mantle, ehest, breast, and sides of 
the belly reddish chestnut, the feathers of the two latter margined 
all round with white; lower back black, closely mottled with rufous 
buff; rump and upper tail-coverts mottled with buff; wing-coverts, 
seapulars, and secondaries black with wide-set buff bands, mottled 
with black; primaries brownish black, mottled with buff; rest of 
the underparts brownish black, edged with white; under tail-eoverts 
chestnut. Two middle pairs of tail-feathers like the outer secondaries, 
hVe outer pairs dark chestnut, third pair intermediate. Total 
length 21 inehes, wing 8*8, tail 8*3, tarsus 2*9. 

Sab. Shan States, Siam, Cambodia, and Cochin China.

30. 
LOBIOPHASIS. 
Type. 
Lobiophasis, Sharpe, Ann. May. N. S. (4) xiv. p. 373(1874). L. bulweri. 
Tail composed of 32 feathers in the male (28 in the female), 
compressed elongate, pointed, the middle pairs of feathers much 
curved and more than twice as long as the outer pairs, which have 
little or no outer web. All the feathers have the shaft produced 
beyond the web and in the outer pairs it terminates in a sharp 
point. 

Ist primary is much shorter than the 2nd, which is about equal 
to the lOth; the 5th is if anything slightiy the longest. 

The male has the head almost entirely naked, only a few feathers 
down the middle of the crown. Three pairs of elongate wattles—a 
large pair, one on each side of the oeeiput, a very large one on each 
side of the throat, and a small pair on the lores on each side of the 
base of the eulmen. In the female only the sides of the head are 
naked; there is a rudimentary pair of wattles, one on each side of 
the throat. 

v2 

292 
PHASIANIDJU. 

The tarsns is armed with a short stout spur, and is much longer 
than tlie middle toe and claw. 
Bange. Borneo. 

1. Lobiophasis bulweri. 
Lobiopliasis bulweri, Sharpe, Ami. Mag. N. II. (4) xiv. p. 373 (1874) 
[Lawas Mts., Sarawak]; Gould, B. Asia, vii. pl. 13 (1875); Sclat. 

P. Z. S. 1876 ,p. 465, pl. xliv.; Sharpe, Ibis, 1879, p. 267; Treacher, 
Ibis, 1888 p. 413 [Kinabataugan]: Everett, List B. Born. p. 198 
(1889). 
Lobiophasis castaneicaudatus, Sharpe, P. Z. &1877,p. 94 [Lawas R.]* 
Gould, B. Asia, vii. pl. 12 (1877); Sharpe, Ibis, 1879, p. 267. 

Acliüt male. Neck and ehest dark crimson ; back, rump, and lesser 
and median wing-coverts blaok, more ox less tinged with purple ; 
all the feathers are margined with steel-blue at the extremity, which 
is slightly curled. Primäry-qnills and their coverts dark brown; 
secondaries and secondary-coverts brownish black ; breast, sides, and 
flanks like the back, bnt the steel-blue margins are narrower; belly, 
thighs, and very short under tail-eoverts black ; upper tail-coverts 
and tail pure white. Bill horn-colour; naked skin of face and 
wattles bluo; legs red. Total length 35 inches, wing 10*3, 
tail 18, tarsus 3*5. 

Immature males differ from the adults in having the top of the 
he ad thickly covered with purplish-black feathers mixed with rufous; 
the chin and throat thinly covered with black feathers; the wattles 
rudimentary* the dark crimson on the neck and throat rauch 
brighter; and the tail-feathers and the upper tail-coverts dark 
chestnut and shaped more like those of the female. 

Aduli female. Upper parts finely mottled with brownish buff and 
black, inclining to rufous on the wing-coverts; the outer webs of the 
primaries mostly rufous, indistinctly mottled with black, the inner 
webs uniform dark brown; secondaries black, mottled on both webs 
with rufous, Underparts rufous, flnely mottled with black. Upper 
tail-coverts and tail chestnut, with some small black vermieulations. 
Total length 20 inches, wing 9-4, tail 6*4, tarsus 3*7. 

A young female differs from the adult in having most of the wing-
coverts and scapulars tipped with rust-red and obliquely barred 
with black on one or both webs; the outer webs of the primaries 
blackish, only slightly vermiculated with rufous buff towards the 
margin; and the upper tail-coverts finely mottled with brownish 
buff and black. 
Hab. Borneo*

31. CROSSOPTILON. 
Type. 

Crossoptilon, JELodgs. J. As. Soc. Betig. vii. p. 864 
(1838) C. tibetanum. 


Tail composed of 20 to 24 feathers, large, füll, and rounded; the 
middle pair o£ feathers twice as long as the otiter pair; the extremities 
of the middle pairs much curved, and the webs very long 
and free. 

Ist primary considerably shorter than the 2nd, which is equal to 
the 9th or lÖfch; 5th or Cth slightly the longest. 

Top of the head covered with short, soft, curly feathers; ear-
coverts produeed into long white tufts on each aide of the head; 
rest of the plumage of the body long and hairy. 

Sides of the face naked, covered with papillse. 
Sexes similar in plumage, but in the male the tarsi are armed with 
a pair of short stoufc spurs. 
Tarsus considerably longer than the middle toe and claw. 
Range. Higher ranges of Central and Eastern Asia.

feathers; the ear-coverts, as in all the members of this genus, are

2. Crossoptilon leucnrum. 
Grossoptilon tibetanum, Oustal Ann. Sei Nat. (7) xii. p. 315 (1892) 
[part.]. 

Crossoptilon leucnrum, Seebohm, Bull. Brit. Orn. Club, no. iv. p. xvii 
(Dec. 21 st, 1892); id. Ibis, 1893, p. 250 [Between the Sok Pass 
and Chianido, E. Tibet]. 

Adult male and female. Like G. tibetanum^ but with the greater 
part of the tail-feathers white. In the male all the tail-feathers are 
pure white, with black extremities glossed with purplish. blue. In 
the female the white on the tail-feathers is less extensive, and the 
middle and outer pairs have the inner webs grey, while all are 
tipped and margined with dark grey. 

Hab. Eastern Thibet, between the Sok Pass and Chiamdo and 
Lhassa.

* In tlie type speeimen the six outer pairs of tail-feathers have an oblong 
white spot or line on their outer web nearly parallel to the shaft, but these 
markings are not equally developed on the two sides. In three speciraens 
of G. tibetanum living in the Zoological Society's G-ardens, as well as in a large 
number of skins I have examined, the white spots on the outer tail-feathers 
are entirely absent, and in one the primaries are greyish brown. There can be 
no doubt that 0. drouyni is synonymous with C. tibetanum.

5. Crossoptilon harmani. 
Crossoptilon harmani, Elwes, Ibis, 1881, p. 399, pl. xiii. [E. Tiiibet]. 
Adiät male. Eesembles G. auritum in general plumage and 
appearance, bnt may be at once distinguished by having a wide 
and well-marked white band across the back of the head between 
the ear-coverts and no white on the basal part of the outer tail-
feathers; moreover the white of the throat extends fnrther down 
towards the ehest, and the plumage of the head and .neck appears 
to be somewhat darker. It is impossible to say certainly how 
many tail-feathers there may have been originally, as the unique 
type speeimen is in very bad condition and the tail-feathers are all 
loose. Capfc. Elwes, in the original descripfcion, gives the number 
as 20, but the plate represents 22. There are now 19 to be found, 
one on the left side being absent; but it appears to me that the 
two central pairs are wanting, and that the füll number is 24, as in 

G. auritum. 
Hab. Thibet, 150 miles east of Lhassa. 
a. 
<$ ad. sk. 150 miles east of Lhassa, IL J. Elwes, Esq. [P.]. 
6000 ft. (Type of the species.)

(1852) G. lineatus. 
Hierophasis, Elliot, Mon. Elias, text to pl. xxv. p. 2 
(1872) G. swinhoii. 
Tau o£ 16 feathers, long, latcrally compressed; the centre pair 
somewhat or considerably longer than the second pair, and at least 
three times the length of the outer pair. 
Ist primary considerably shorter than the 2nd, which is equal to 
the 9th or lOth; the 5th or 6th slightly the longest. 
Head with an elongate hairy crest. 
Sides of the head naked. 
Tarsi considerably longer than the middle too and claw, and 
armed in the male with a pair of stout, fairly long spurs. 
Hange. Himalayas ; Indo-Chinese countries.

albocristatus, Adams, P. Z. 8. 1858, p. 499 [Simla, 
Cashmere] ; Sclat. List of Phas. p. 9 (1863); Gray, List Gallina 
Brit. Mus. p. 32 (1867); id. Hand-l. B. ii. p. 260'(1870); Elliot, 
Mon. Phas. ii. pl. 18 (1872) [syn. part.J; Hume fy Inglis, Str. F. v. 

p. 42 (1877); Hume 8f Marsh. Game B. Ind. i. p. 177, pl. (1878); 
Marsh. Ibis, 1884, p. 423 [Cliamba]: Oates, ed. Hume's JSfests & 
Eggs, iii. p. 413 (1890). 
Gallophasis albocristatus, Mitch. P. Z. S. 1858, p. 544, pl. 148.fig. 1, 
& pl. 149. fig. 3; Adams, P. Z. Ä 1859, p. 186; Jerd. B. Ind. iii. 

p. 532 (1863) [part.]; Blyth, Ibis, 1867, p. 153; Tytler, Ibis, 1868, 
p. 203 [Simla to Mu&soorie]; t?. Pelz. Ibis, 1868, p. 321 [Koteghur]; 
Beavan, Ibis, 1868, p. 380 [Simla]; Brooks, Ibis, 1869, p. 60 [Naixd 
Tal, Almorah]; Hume, N. <$r E. Lid, B. p. 526 (1873): Marsh. 
B. Nest Md. p. 59 (1877). 
Adult male* A long hairy white er est; forehead, sides and back 
of the head and neck, manfcle and wing-coverts, and upper tail-
coverts black, glossed witb purplish and steel-blne; featbers of the 
mantle and upper tail-coverts also narrowly margined witb dirty 
white; lower back and rump the same, but with a wide white 
terminal band ; primaries brown ; secondaries darker, and slightly 
glossed with greenish blne on the outer web; chin and throat 
black ; fore part of neck dirty white, gradually shading into brown 
on the belly and rest of the underparts. Tail black, glossed with 
purplish blue. Naked faciai skin scarlet. Bill greenish white; 
legs and feet livid white tinged with brown. Total length 
25 inches, wing 9*3, tail 11, tarsus 3. 
Immature males have the edges of the longer Upper tail-coverts 
flnely mottled instead of margined with white ; the spurs, too, are 
small or absent. 
A very yowng speeimen has the plumage of the upper parts like 
that of the female, but darker, and most of the feathers of the 
mantle and wing-coverts have a wide subterminal black band; the 
underparts are brownish white. 
Adult female. A long brownish-grey hairy crest; whole plumage 
reddish brown, redder on the rump, upper tail-coverts, ehest, and 
rest of the underparts; feathers of the upper parts flnely vermiculated 
with blackish and edged with grey, except those of the 
wing-coverts and underparts, where the margins are white; chin, 
throat, and middle of belly dirty white ; primaries brown; middle 
pair of tail-feathers reddish flnely mottled with black, rest black 
glossed with steel-blue. Total length 22-5 inches, wing 8*8, 
tail 8'8, tarsus 2-5. 
Immature females drffier only in having the -middle pair of tail-
feathers with rather strongly marked wavy bars and mottlings of buf£. 
Hab. Lower and middle ranges of the "Western Himalayas, from 
Hazara to Kumaon and Western Nepal.

Euplocomus cuvieri, Hume 8f Marsh. Game B. Ind. i. pl. only (1878). 
Adidt male. Black glossed with purplish or steel-blue; feathers 
of the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts with a terminal 
white band very narrow on the latter; soft parts as in G. albocristatus. 
Size the same as in the other species. 
Immature males have less gloss on the feathers, the edges of the 
wing-coverts, scapulars, and upper tail-coverts, and the outer 
margins of the secondaries vermiculated with rufous and buff. 
Adult female. Eesembles the female of G. leucomelanus or G. 
muthura, but in old speeimens tihe centre pair of tail-feathers 
become uniform dark chestnut, whereas in the two latter there is 
always some blackm ottring. As a rule the rump is pal er andmore 
olive-brown, and contrasts rather strongly with the middle pair of 
tail-feathers.

Adult male. Eesembles the male of G. horsfieldi, but all the

Immaiure male. Differs from G. cuvierl in having the white lines 
on the feathers of the upper parts coarser and more regulär, especially 
on the mantle, scapulars, and wing-coverts. The feathers of these 
parts have an outer submarginal white line parallel to the eäge, 
within which are four or five irregulär but more or less parallel lines. 
In this respect the present subspecies approaehes G. andersoni, but 
the white lines are narrower and the blaek iiiterspaces broader than 
in the former.

Nycthemerus lineatus, Blyth § Waiden, Cat. Mamm. & B. Burma. 

p. 149 (1875) [Karen Hills]. 
Adult male. Top of the head and elongate erest blaek, glossed 
with purplish blue ; back and sides of the neck, back, rump, upper 
tail-coverts, lesser and median wing-coverts, and scapulars finely 

82. GENNJCUS.
vermiculated with alternate black and white lines. running ehiefly 
across the feathers : primaries and their coverts blackish brown; 
secondaries and secondary-coverts black, all with obliquely-irrcgidar 
white lines; chin, tliroat, fore part of neck, and rest of underparts 
black with a slight blue gloss; the feathers on the sicles of the 
breast always have white shaft-stripes **. Middle pair of tail-
feathers dirty white, more or less vermiculated with black on the 
onter web except at the extreinity ; rest of the feathers obliquely 
vermiculated with black and white, the black gradually increasing 
and the white diminishing on each snecessive feather, so that the 
onter pair are black, obliquely vermiculated with white. Bill bluish 
or brownish horny; facial skin blood-red; legs and feet tieshy 
brown. Total length 29 inches, wing 9*7, tail 12, tarsus 3*3* 

In an immature male the wing-coverts and scapulars are intermixed 
with pale olive-brown feathers, greyish towards the tip and 
vermiculated with black; some of the black feathers of the breast 
are mixed with brown, and the white shaft-stripes are mostly confined 
to the feathers of the sides and flanks. 

Adult female. Top of the head and crest tinged with rufous, rest 
of the Upper parts olive-brown ; most of the feathers of the mantle 
with V~snaPed white marks narrowly edged with black ; inner webs 
of the primaries and secondaries browja; the outer webs of the 
latter slightly mottled with whitish buff along the margin; sides of 
the neck with triangulär white spots; chin, throat, and fore part 
of neck whitish; rest of the underparts brownish chestnut, each 
feather with a pointed white shaft-stripe margined with black. 
Middle pair of tail-feathers buff, mottled on the outer web and also 
slightly on the inner with black; the six oater pairs are reddish 
brown, with wide irregulär white bars mottled and widely margined 
with black ; the second pair have the basal two-thirds like the outer 
pairs, and the terminal third buff mottled with black like tho 
middle pair. Total length 22*5 inches, wing 8-9, tail 8*7, 
tarsus 2*7. 

Hab. Pegu, Tonghoo and Karen Hills, Tenasserim as far south 
as Tavoy, and K.W. Siam. It is also stated to extend up the 
Irrawaddy Valley as far as Bhämo.

* ID. some fully adult and very old speeimens almost all the feathers of the 
breast and belly have white shaft-stripes, while in other equally adult examples 
these marks are absent except on the sides of the breast; this character seems 
to have no reference to age or locality, and appears to be individual.

Euplocamus lineatus, Feilden (nee Vig.), Str. F. iii. p. 168 (1875) 
[Tnayetmyo Hills). 

Adult male. Resembles the adult male of G. lineatus, but differs 
in haying the feathers of the lower back and rump fringed w ith 
white and only the margins of the inner webs of the iniddle pair of 
tail-feathers white, without any black marking. In one speeimen 
the feathers of the sides of the breast have white shaft-stripes; in 
another they are uniform black. Size and soft parts the same as 
given for G. lineatus. 

Adult female. Resembles the female of G. Tiorsfieldi in general 
plumage, and differs from that of G. lineatus in haying no white 
triangulär spots on the sides of the neck, while the underparts are 
warm brown, with narrow buff-coloured shafts, much the same as 
in G. Tiorsfieldi. It differs, moreover, from both these, as well as 
from the other nearly allied forms, in haying the outer tail-feathers 
chestnut slightly mottled with black, as in Lophura rufa, while the 
centre pair are brownish buff thickly mottled with wayy lines of 
black.

Thayetmyo.

Adiät male. Top of the head and crest black glossed with purple; 
sides of the head, back, and sides of the neck and rest of the iipper 
parts white, the feathers of the mantle, lower hack, rump, and upper 
tail-coverts each with five or six narrow regulär black concentric 
lines; scapulars, wing-coverts, and quills the same, but the black 
lines are fewer, coarser, and less regulär; chin, throat, fore part of 
neck, and rest of underparts black, glossed with purple, some of 
the feathers on the sides of the breast with white shaft-stripes, 
others with the whole of the outer wTeb white. Tail unusually long; 
centre pair of tail-feathers pure white, rest white, with irregulär 
oblique black lines gradually increasing in number and thickness 
towards the outer pair. Bill greenish hörn ; facial. skin blood-red ; 
legs and feet scarlet. Total length 40 inches, wing 10*5, tail 24, 
tarsus 3*6. 

Toung male has the upper parts like those of the female, but 
raost of the feathers of the wing-coverts have narrow bars of buff 
edged with black running parallel to the margin ; the outer webs of 
the secondaries obliquely vermiculated with black and buff lines ; 
most of the feathers of the chin, throat, and ehest black, glossed 
with purple, but the majority of the feathers on the rest of the 
underparts marked with alternate black and white or black and buff 
lines running parallel to the edge; tail as in the female. 

Adult female. Crest blackish brown; top of the head, rest of 
upper parts, and middle pair of tail-feathers olive-brown, more or 
less vermiculated with fme dusky lines; inner webs of the quills 
brown; chin and throat dirty brownish white; neck and rest of 
underparts similar to the upper, but the feathers of the belly, thighs, 
and under tail-coverts are mottled and vermiculated, especially the 
latter, with black ; the second pair of tail-feathers are brownish 
buff, obliquely vermiculated with brownish black ; the outer pairs 
are black, obliquely vermiculated with white. Colours of soft parts 
like those of the male, but not so bright. Total length 20*5 inches, 
wing 9*1, tail 9*8, tarsus 3*2.

Euplocamus swinhoii, Gould, P. Z. S. 1862, p. 284 [Formosa]; Seht

Euplocomus swinhoii, Gray, Hand-l. B. ii. p. 260 (1870). 

Adult male. Feathered parts of the head, the chin, throat, and 
neck black, the latter slightly glossed with steel-blue ; mantle pure 
white; lower back, rump, and shorter Upper tail-coverts black, glossed 
with purplish blue, and somewhat curled towards the estremity; 
scapulars dark erimson, with bronze-red reflections; wing-coverts 
and outer secondaries black, margined with a glossy steel-green 
band, the ends of these feathers are also slightly curled, giving 
them, as well as the feathers of the lower back &c, the appearance 
of having, in some lights, a velvet-black subterminal band; primaries 
brownish, secondaries and their coverts black; underparts 
black, richly glossed with purplish blue on the ehest, breast, and 
sides ; centre pair of tail-feathers longest, pure white, rest black; 
sometimes the second pair have the inner web white. Bill and 
spurs pale horny; facial skin and wattles erimson; legs and feet 
scarlet. Total length 29*5 inches, wing 9*5, tail 16, tarsus 3*8. 

An immature male * has the crest short and mxxed with black ; 
the mantle chestnut, rtiixed with black above, most of the feathers 
with white shaft-stripes; the wing-coverts, lower back, and rump 
dark chestnut and rufous buff thickly mottled with black, most of 
the feathers of the latter margined with metallic purplish blue; 
underparts black without any gloss; and the middle pair of tail-
feathers dark chestnut mottled with black. 

Adult female. The short crest, top of the head, and neck reddish 
brown mottled with black, and with rufous-buff shaft-stripes; 
mantle the same, but the middle of each feather black, and the 
shaft-stripes are V-shaped; wing-coverts and scapulars similar,

varies in its resemblance to the one sex or the other."

33. PUCRASIA* 
Type. 

Eulophus, Less. (nee Geoffr., Hym. 1764) Comp. 

Buffon, "vii. p. 354 (1836) P. nipalensis.

p. 144 (1846) .. .# P. macrolopha. 
Lochniophasis, Heine, Nomencl. Mus. Hein. p. 298 
(1890) P. nipalensis. 
Tail composed of 16 feathers, long, wedge-shaped; the iniddle 
pair of feathers slightly the longest, and about twice as long as the 
outer pair. 
The Ist primary is considerably shorter than the 2nd, which is 
about equal to the 8th ; the 4th is slightly the longest. 
Head (in the male) with an elongate crest; the feathers behind 
the ear-eoyerts are greatly elongated and surpass the crest in 
length. 
Sides of the head feathered. 
Tarsus about equal to the middle toe and claw; armed in the 
male with a moderately staut and long spur. 

Range. Himalayas, from K Afghanistan and Kaflristan to the 
mountains of Eastern Thibet, China, and Mantchouria,

Phasianus 
macrolopha, 2%$, Cat. Mus. As. Soc. p. 245 (1849) 
[part]. 

Adult male. Long occipital crest bright buff; a large snow-white 
patch on each side of the neck; rest of the head, chin, throat, and 
fore part of neck black, glossed with dark green, the patch of 
feathers on each siele above the ear-coverts being enormously elongated 
and considerably surpassing the crest in length; mantle, lower 
back, rump, and upper tail-coverts grey, wing-coverts and scapulars 
browner and more or less tinged with olive and rxifous; all the 
feathers of the mantle and most of the wing-coverts with a moderately 
wide black shaft-stripe exten ding to the end of the feather ; 
greater secondary-coverts and scapulars with a black subterminal 
blotch ; in very old birds the black shaft-stripes on the lower back, 
rump, and upppr tail-eoverts (with the exception of the median line 
ot feathers) are not visible, being confined to the basal half of the 
feathers. Quills brown, the outer webs of the second to the sixth 
primary buff, and the margins of the outer webs of the secondaries 
greyibh brown ; the middle of the ehest, breast, and belly dark 
chestnut; feathers of the sides greyish white, with narrow or 
moderato black shaft-stripes. Centre pair of tail-feathers chestnut, 
blackish down the middle and tipped with brownish grey; outer 
pairs black, shading into brownish red on the basal three-quarters of 
the outer web and narrowly tipped with white. Bill black; legs 
and feet grey, tinged with flesh-colour or purplish. Total length 
23 inches, wing 9*4, tail 9-5, tarsus 2-6. 

Inirnature males have the black shaft-stripes on the mantle twice 
as wide as in adult birds, and on the lower back, rump, and upper 
tail-coverts they are strongly marked and extend to the extremities 
of the feathers. 

In a young male the top of the head is brown, the crest and 
lengthened feathers are undeveloped, the feathers of the chin and 
throat are white, those of the fore part of the neck white, margined 
with black; the back of the neck buff, barred and mottled with 
black; the chestnut on the breast is only partly represented, and 
the im der tail-coverts are widely tipped with white ; otherwise the 
plumage does not differ much from that of the adult. 

Adult female. Top of the head black, with rufous bars, a short 
occipital crest brown in the middle, buff on each side, and edged 
and mottled with black; feathers on the nape with black bars 
glossed with green; feathers of the mantle black, tipped with 
brownish grey or sandy brown, and with irregulär ^-shaped 
rufous shaft-stripes ; wing-coverts and scapulars mottled with black 
and rufous, with buff shaft-stripes, and the longer ones with large 
black subtcrminal blotches extending over one or both webs : lower 

33. PUCIUSIA. 313 
"back, rump, and shorter upper tail-coverts sandy brown, motilod 
IA ith black, eacli feather with a wide black centre and a narrow rufous 
shaft-stripe ; longer upper tail-coverts without black centres; quilla 
brown, more or less edged and mottled with buff and rufous ; wide 
buff superciliary stripes; featbers o£ tbe cbeeks and ear-coverts 
buff, edged with black; chin and throat white; ehest, breast, sides, 
and rlanks like the mantle, but there is less black and tho shaft-
stripes are mach wTider; belly white, marked with black; under 
tail-coverts chestnut, widely tipped with white, separate«! by a 
black bar from the chestnut; middle tail-feathers irregularly barred 
with rufous buff, edged with black; outer feathers black, more or 
less mixed, especially on the outer web, with chestnut, and tipped 
with white. Total length 19*6 inches, wing 8*7, tail 7, tarsus 2*2.

4. Pucrasia meyeri. 
Pucrasia meyeri, Madaräsz, Ibis, 1886, p. 145 [Central Thibet]. 
Pucrasia darwinii, Oustal. (nee Sioinh.) Le Nat. 1886, p. 276 [Yerka-
lo, Upper Mekong-]. 

Aclult male. Differs from the male of P. xanthospila in having 
"the upper tail-coverts fawn-colour, striped and freckled withblack; 
central tail-feathers rufous, becoming whiter at the tips, with two 
irregulär black bands on each side, margined with fawn-colour; 
outer tail-feathers rieh rufous on the outer webs and brownish on 
the inner margins, banded with black, each feather tipped with 
pure white." 

It will be noted that the description of the upper tail-coverts 
and tail of P. meyeri agrees closely with that of P. macrolopha. In 
other respects the present species appears to be entirely similar to 

X. xanthospila. 
Aduli female. Differs from the female of P. xanthospila in having 
the middle tail-feathers fulvous vermieulated with black, and the 
outer tail-feathers rufous, black towards the apex and tipped with 
white. 

Hab. Yer-ka-lo, Upper Me'kong to Central Thibet.

Adult male. Top of the head blackish brown, each feather, 
especially the longer ones of the crest, tipped with dirty white; back 
of the head grey; neck white, barred on the nape with black; 
mantle barred with black and pale crearny white, each feather 
fringed with whitish grey and with a subterminal blackish band 
glossed with dark green; wktg-coverts arid seapularslike the mantle, 
but the black bars, except the subterminal one, are broken up and 
irregulär and the ground-colour ochraeeous buff; iower back and 
rump rust-colour, each feather with a subterminal black band glossed 
with green ; quills and primäry-coverts brownish black, irregularly 
edged and mottled with buff; feathers of the check below the naked 
pateh and ear-coverts brown ; chin, throat, and ehest dirty white ; 
breast and sides of the belly whitish buff, barred with black; 
middle of the belly black; flanks, venl, and under tail-coverts 
ochraeeous rust-colour; upper tail-coverts and centre pair of tau-
feathers whitish buff, with wide irregulär black bars as wide as the 
interspaces, rest of the tail-feathers the same. but the bars on the 
inner webs at least are mostly dark chestnut. Bill pale horny brown ; 
naked skin round the eye scarlet; legs and feet grey-brown. Total 
length ^4 inches, wing 10, tail 20*5, tarsus 2-9. 
Immature males differ from the adult in having the breast and 
sides of the belly almost devoid of black markings and washed with 
brightbuff; the black subterminal bars on the upper parts, especially 
on the lower back and rump, where they are often abbent, not 
glossed with green; and the spurs are rudimentary. 
Adult female. Differs ohiefly from the male in having the feathers 
of the head and crest edged with buff; the upper parts of the 
mantle pale chestnut, widely barred and marked with black; the 
lower back and rump a mixture of dirty brown, black, and buff, the 
former predominating; the quills regularly barred, those on the

Phasianus colchicus septentrionalis, Lorenz, J.f. 0. 1888, p. 572 

[N. Caucasus]. 
Adult vnale. Top of the head bronze-green: forehead, "back and 
base of the neck, chin and throat dark green, shading into purple 
on the sides and front of the neck; mantle fiery orange, each feather 
with a narrow W-shaped margin of dark purplish green; feathefs 
of the scapulars and interscapulary region rnottled with black and 
hufT in the middle and surrounded by consecutive bands of bnfY, 
black, and orange-red, roughly parallel with the margin of the 
feather, which has the tip glossed with pnrplish lake ; lower back #, 

* It is very rarely now that anything approaching a pure-bred nialo of 
P. colchicus can be found in England; even in speeiraens which appear to be 
pure bred at the first glance (that is, in those which hare r«o trace of a white 
ring), the subterminal green bar of P. torquatus is usnally rnore er less developed 
on the feathers of the lower back, and the basal parfc of the central tail-
feathers is rather widely barred with black.

322 rHASMIDJE. 

rnmp, and iippcr tail-coverts rufous buff, mottlcd with black and 
widely tipped with red, glossed with purplish lake ; lossor and 
median wing-coverts roddish sandy brown, tbe inner ones edged 
with red. (iuills, greater coverts, and bastard-wing ligbt brown, 
barred and mottled with whitish bnff, the outer webs of tho 
seeondaries shading into bnff towards their margins ; ehest, breast, 
and fianks liery orange-red, each feather with a rieh purple margin ; 
middle of breast and sides of belly glossed with dark purplish green ; 
rest of nnderparts dark brown mixed with rufous, especially on tho 
im der tail-coverts. Centre pair of tail-feathers ligbt olive-brown in 
the middle and widely edged on each side with rufous glossed 
with purplish lake; a series of wide-set black bars across the 
olive-brown central band, narrow on the basal part ancl increasing 
in width towards the extreniity; outer pairs similar, 
but shading into blackish brown towards the margins of the 
inner web. Bill whitish hörn ; legs and feet brownish horn-colour; 
naked skin on the sides of the face and wattles, when present, 
scarlet-vermilion. Total length 37'5 inebes, wing 10-1, tail 21-2, 
tarsus 2*8. 

Irnmature males rcsemble the adult, but the plumage is less pure 
and bright and the tail is shorter. 

Adult female. Top of the head black, each feather edged with 
sandy brown and tipped with black; back and sides of the neck 
the same, but the feathers have a slight pinkish tinge and a 
giossy crimson and purple line across the tip; mantle and sides 
of the breast chestnut, with black centres and pale pinkish-white 
margins mottled with black; rest of the upper parts black, orange-
brown towards tho tips and margined with sandy brown mixed 
with buff. Quills as in the male, but the barring and mottling, 
especially on the outer webs of the seeondaries, is much coarser; 
an elongate patch of white black-tipped feathers below the eye; 
chin and throat pale rufous buff; ehest and upper breast much the 
same as the mantle, but the basal parts are almost entirely hidden 
by the sanely-pink tips; fianks barred with black and buff in the 
middle and edged with pale buff; rest of underparts pale buff, flnely 
vermiculated with dusky brown. Middle pair of tail-feathers 
reddish brown down the middle, shading into sandy olive on the 
sides and with wide irregulär bars of black, buff, and black ; outer 
pair very similar. Total length 24*5 inches, wing 8*6, tail 11*5, 

tarsus 2#4. 

Eah. Southern Turkey, Greece, Asia Minor to Transcaueasia, 
extending northwards to the Volga.

? Phasianus colchicus, Blanf. R JPersia, ii. p. 272 (1876) [Mazan

Phasianus persicus talischensis, Lorenz, J.f. 0.1888, p. 571 [Talisch]. 
Phasianus colchicus, Badde <§• Walt. Omis, 1889, p. 90 [Tausch.] 

Adult male. Differs from typical P. colchicus and resembles 

P. persicus in having the middle of the breast amd sides of the belly 
purplish carmine and the ehest and upper breast narrowly margined 
with purple. It differs from P. persicus and resembles P. colchicus 
in the colour of the wing-coverts, which are reddish sandy brown 
instead of nearly white. 
Adult female. Does not difFor from the female of P. colchicus, 

Hab. Talisch, south-west shore of the Caspian Sea. I t is 
probably also the bird that extends through Äazandaran to the 
Gurgan River.

Phasianus shawi, Elliot, Ibis, 1876, p. 132. 
Adult male. Eeseinbles P. cohMcus in goneral plumage and in 
having tho lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts glosscd with 
purplish lake. It differs in having the lesbor and median wingcoverta 
nearly white; the blaek bars on the iail scarcely half as 
wide; the ehest and breast-feathers glossed with purplish lake and 
their dark pnrple margins much narrower, and the middle of the 
breast and sides of the belly purplish carmine. Total lengfch 
35 inches, wing 9-3, tail 19-5, tarsus 2-8. 

Adult female. Closely resembles the female of P. eolchicus.

Phasianus 
principalis, Sclat. P. Z. & 1885, p. 322, pl. xxii, [Bala

Phasianus 
komarowii, Bogd. Bull. PMersb. xxx. p. 356 (1886) 
[Aschabad]; id. MSI. Mol. xii. p. 319 ^1886); Zaroudn. Bull. 
Mose. lxi. p. 322 (1886) [Tchirin-Ichai & Kizil-Kan, tributaries 
of Atrak R.]. 

Adult male bears the same relationship to P.persicus fhat P. clvrysomelas 
bears to P. shawi. It differs from the former in having no 
purple-lake gloss on the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coveits, 
which are orange-red, the ehest and breast widely tipped with purplish-
red bronze, and the flank-feathers widely tipped with dark 
greenish purple. Total length 35*5 inches, wing 9-4, tail 21-5, 
tarsus 2*7. 

Adult female very similar to the female of P. chrysomelas. 

Hab. ISTorth-western Afghanistan and North-east Persia.

with greenish blue instead of purplish blue, thus showing an approaeh to 
P. chrysomelas froin the Ainu Darya.

5. Phasianus shawi. 
Phasianus shawi, Elliot, P. Z. S. 1870, p. 403 [Yarkand] ; id. Monog. 
Phas. ii. pl. i. [text] (1872); Scully, Str. F. iii. p. 433 (1875), iv

(1875). 

Phasianus chrysomelas, Elliot, Str. F. v. p. 198 (1877). 

Adult male. Diuers chießy from P. colchicus in having the lesser 

and median wing-eoverts white or whitish buff; the lower back 

and rump and upper 
tail-coverts without any purplish-lake gloss, 

and the feathers of the two former with. a subterminal green spot 

on eacb side of the shaft; the ehest and breast-feathers edged with 

dark green, and the middle of the breast and sides of the belly dark 

green. It is distinguished from P. chrysomelas by the tips of the 

Üank-feathers being purplish green instead of green, and the much 

narrower margins to the feathers of the ehest, breast, and mantle. 

Total length 33*5 inches, wing 9*6, tail 19*5, tarsus 2*7. 

Adult female. Much 
paler than the female of P. colchicus; no 

chestnut on the feathers of the mantle, of whieh the ground-colour 

is pale rufous-buff; the ground-colour of the rest of the plumage is 

whitish buff. Total length 23*4 inches, wing 8*3, tail 11*2, 

tarsus 2-3. 

Hab. Valleys of the Yarkand, Kashgar, Aksu, and Khotan Eivers.

tail-coverts green and buff instead of orange-red. Total length 
30*3 inches, wing 9*3, tail 16*3, tarsus 2*8.

7. Phasianus cliryscraielas. 
Phasianus ehrysomelas, Severtz. Bull Mose, xlviii. pt. 3, p. 207 (1875) 
[Amu-Darya]; id. Ibis, 1875, p. 493 [Lower Amu-Darya]; id. 

J.f. 0. 1875, p. 225; Gould, JB. Asia, vii. pl. 36 (1876); ßogd. 
Comp. Av. Ross. fasc. i. p. 20 (1884) [Amu-Darya]; Seebohm, 
Ibis, 1887, p. 172; Pleske, Mem. Ac. St. Päersb. (7) xxxvi. no. 3, 
p. 48 (1888) [Kasalinsk]. 
Phasianus dorrandti, Severtz. J. f. 0. 1875, p. 225. 
Phasianus oxianus, Severtz. J. f. O. 1875, p. 225. 
Phasianus insignis, Eiliot, Ibis, 1876, p. 132. 
Adult male. Differs fromP. shawi chiefly in having the feathers of 
the mantle widely edged with green, the ehest, breast, and flanks very 
widely tipped with the same colonr, eaeh of the feathers of the lower 
back and rump with a triangulär green spot at the end of the shaft, 
and the black lines on the tail-feathers much narrower. Total 
length 34 inches, wing 9*3, tail 19, tarsus 2*8. 

Adult female. Similar to the female of P. shawi, but the black 
spots on the middle of the ehest and breast-feathers are more 
strongly marked. Total length 24 inches, wing 8*3, tail 12*4, 
tarsus 2-4:.

8. Phasianus mongolicus. 
Phasianus colchicus, Licht, {nee Zinn.) in JSoer&m. Reise nach 
Buchara, p. 133 (1823) [Kuwan and Jan Darja]; Meyend. Voy. ä 
Bokhara, p. 428 (1826). 

Phasianus torquatus, Karelin {nee GmeL), Bull. Mose. p. 561 (1841). 
Phasianus mongolicus, Brandt, Bull. Acad. St. Petersb. iii. p. 51 
(1844) [Altai]; Gould, B. Asia, TU. pl. 41 (1858); Sclat. List Phas. 

p. 4 (1863); id. P. Z. S. 1863, p. 116; Gray,List Gaüince Brit. Mus. 
p. 27 (1867); id. Hand-l. B. ii. p. 257 (1870); Elliot, P. Z. 8. 
1870, p. 408: id.Monog. Phas. ii. pl. iv. [text] (1872); Severtz. 
Turkest. Jevotn. p. 68 (1873); id. Bull Mose, xlviii. pt. 3, p. 208 
0875); id. J. f. 0. 1875, p. 224; id. Ibis, 1875, p. 493; Dresser, 
Ibis, 1876, p. 323; Finsch, Terh. Ges. Wien, xxix. p. 241 (1880); 
Bogd. Consp. Av. Boss. fasc. i. p. 20 (18.84); Seebohm, Ibis, 1887, 
p. 173; Pleshe, Mem. An. St. Petersb. (7) xxxvi. no. 3, p. 47 
(1888) [Oliinaz], 
Adiät male. Differs from all the maroon and orange-red rumped 
speeies in having a wide white ring (interrupted in front) round the 
neck; otherwise it most nearly resemhles P. persicus, but the 
mantle and scapulars, ehest and breast are bronze orange-red with 
purple and green reflections ; the feathers of the lower back, rump, 
and upper tail-coverts are mixed with dark green and glossed with 
green and purple ; the chin and throat are mostly purplish bronzered 
; the ehest, breast, and flanks are tipped with very dark green; 
and the middle of the breast and sides of the belly are dark 
green. Total length 36mo inches, wing 9*6, tail 22, tarsus 2*8. 

Adult female. Eesembles the female of P. chrysomelas, bnt on 

each feather of the upper mantle there is a subterminal black spot, 

and a bar across the middle instead of a broad black submarginal 

border. Total length 26 inches, wing 8*5, tail 12*3, tarsus 2-5. 

Hab. Banging from the "Valley of the Syr-Darya across the 

basin of Lake Balkash as far east as Lake Zaisan and the Valley of 

the Black Irtish, and southwards to the Valley of the Ili and 

Issik-Kul.

9. Phasianus elegans. 

Phasianus elegans, Mliot, Ann. # Mag. N. H. (4) vi. p. 312 (1870): 

Sclat. P. Z. 8. 1870, p. 670 [Yun-ling Mts., W. Sze-chuen]; JSlliot, 

Monog. Phas. ii. pl. viii. [text] (1872); 8eebohm, Ibis, 1888, p. 315. 
Phasianus sladeni, Anders. MS., Mliot, P. Z. 8.1870, pp. 404, 408; 
Anders. P. Z. 8. 1871, p. 214 [W. Yunnan]; Swinh. P. Z.8. 1871, 

p. 398; David £ Oustal. Ois. Chine, p. 411 (1877) [W. Sze-chuen 
and W. Yunnan]; Anders. P. W. Yunnan, p. 671 (1878) 
[Momien diät.]. 
Adult male. This and the following species are at once distinguibhed 
from the species of the group including P. cohhicus and 
its near allies by the general colour of the lower back, rump, and 
upper tail-coverts, which are greenish or bluish slate with a rustcoloured 
patch on each side *, and by the black bars on the basal 
part of the middle tail-feathers, which are much wider. The 
feathers of the mantle and scapulars are dark orange-red, rather 
widely tipped with Sandy buff and slightly glossed with green, the 
upper feathers of the mantle are faintly edged and spotted at the 
extremity with dark green; tho feathers of the lower back and 
rump with rather wide subterminal dark green bands; the lesser 
and median wing-coverts greenish grey; the ehest, Upper and 
middle parts of the breast, and sides of the belly dark green; 
otherwise the plumage is very similar to that of P. colcMcus. 
Total length 27-5 inches, wing 9-1, tail 14*7, tarsus 2-5. 

Adult female. Differs chiefly from the female of P. colcMcus in 
having the chin, throat, and fore part of the neck white, and the 
ehest an.d rest of the underparts barred with irregulär black bars; 
it is scarcely to be distinguished from the female of P. strauchi. 
Total length 21*1 inches, wing 7*9, tail 9*8, tarsus 2*3. 

Hab. West Yunnan and Western Sze-chuen. 

* Excepfc in P. versicolor.

Adult male*. Differs froni P. elegans chiefly in liaving the general 
colonr of the mantle and scapnlars sandy red, and the^ sides and 
flanks golden buff instead of dull orange-red glossed with purple. 
It is distinguished from P. straucM by its much paler scapnlars and 
by having the ehest mostly dark green instead of fiery orange-red. 
Total length 31*5 inches, wing 9-5, tail 17*5, tarsus 2-6. 

Adult female. Upper parts like those of P. colekieus, but the 
black markings are much fainter and the predominating colonr is 
pale buff; the chin and throat are pure white, and the rest of the 
underparts whitish buff with very faint indications of brown crossbars. 
Total length 22*5 inches, wing 8*2, tail 11, tarsus 2-4.

17. Pkasiauus ellioti. 
Pliasiamis ellioti, Sicinh. P. Z. S. 1872, p. 550 [Che-kiang]; David $ 
OustaL Ois. Chine, p. 412, pl. 101 (1877) [Öhe-kiang, E. Fo-kien]. 
Caiophasis ellioti, Ettiot, Monog. Phas. ii. pl. xiii. bis ["textl (1872); 

Gouid, JB. Asia, TO. pl. 23 (1874). 
Gallophasis ellioti, BJume, Ibis, 1881, p. 608. 


Aclult male. Top o£ the head sandy brown mixed with chestnut; 
nape and back of the neck grey, shading into white on the sides; 
chin, throat? and fore part of neck black, slightly glossed with 
pnrple ; a band of black feathers widely tipped with white divides 
the mantle from the scapulars and runs roughly parallel to a dark 
purplish-steel band across the lesser wing-coverts ; the mantle, 
scapulars, median wing-coverts, ehest, and breast orange-red, with 
fiery-gold reflections, the former and the latter with short subterminal 
black cross-bars; the lower back and rump-feathers black, 
barred and fringed with white; primaries and their coverts brown, 
the terminal part of the outcr webs and tips of the former mixed 
with rufons; secondaries and secondary-coverfcs mostly brown on 
the inner web and chestnut on the outer, with a black subterminal 
bar and white tip; the white tips of the coverts are very wide, and 
make a broad bar across the wing, subparallel to the two former; 
fiank-feathers like the secondary-coverts ,* belly and vent white; 
under tail-coverts black, mixed with chestnut. Upper tail-coverts 
and tail with wide alternate bars of chestnut and grey, edged with 
black, most marked on the outer tail-feathers. Total length 32*5 
inches, wing 3*8, tail 19, tarsus 2*8. 

Adiüi female. Feathers of the top of the head brown, edged with 
chestnut; sides of the head, back, and sides of the neck and chin 
sandy grey ; throat and fore part of the neck black ; mantle black, 
mottled with rufons buff and tipped with sandy brown, the upper 
feathers with irregulär white shaft-spots; lesser, median, and 
seconclary wing-coverts very similar, and separated from the mantle 
by a wide sandy-grey band; lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts sandy brown, mottled with rufous buff and black. Qnills 
dark brown, irregularly barred and mottled with buff and rufous 
buff. Chest, breast, and flanks sandy brown, irregularly spotted 
with black; the lower feathers edged with white, rest of underparts 
mostly white; middle pairs of tail-feathers brownish white 
mottled with black, outer pairs and under tail-coverts chestnut 
widely tipped with white, and with a wide black subterminal bar. 
Total length 20 inches, wing 8, tail 7*7, tarsus 2-5. 

Hab. Mountains of South-eastern China, Che-kiang, and Fo-kien.

A marked variety of this species has been named P. scintülans by 
Gould. The male differs from the typical male of P. sosmmerringi 
in having most of the feathers of the wing-coverts, back, and 
especially the rump margincd on either side with a white black-
edged band instead of with fiery gold ; while the lighter parts of 
the tail-feathers below the black cross-bars are usually-paler and often 
strongly dotted with black. This form cannot possibly be regarded as 
a distinet species, for it not only oecurs in the same islands where 


F. soemmerringi is found, but every intermediate stage between the 
two forms may be seen. 
Tho following synonymy belongs to this variety:—

Tail composed of 18 feathers, vaulted, the middle pair very long, 
more than four times as long as the outermost pair, which are short. 
Ist primary umcli shorter than the 2nd, which is rather shorter 
than the lOth, the 5th being slightly the longest.

armed in the male with a pair of short spurs.

of erectile, squarely truncate feathers.

Adult male. Top of the head and crest brilliant golden yellow; 
cape-like feathers covering the back of the neck brilliant orange at 
the extremity, shading into yellowish buff towards the base, each
