purplish blue, and with the basal half grey; lower back, rump, and 
shorter Upper tail-coverts brilliant golden yellow like the crest, some 
of the feathers on the sides and the shorter upper tail-eoverts mixed 
with crimson-scarlet; longer upper tail-coverts and central palr of 
tail-feathers black, thickly ocellated with pale brown spots, the former 
with the terminal half crimson-scarlet and the latter tipped with 
whitish buff; the rest of the tail-feathers are obliquely barred and 
marked with pale brown and black, except the outermost pairs, 
which are dark chestnut-brown, mottled with black; seapulars dark 
crimson-scarlet; wing-coverts chestnut, mottled with black ; quills 
brownish black, the primaries partially margined on the outer web 
with buff, and all the outer secondaries glossed with. rieh purple-
blue; chin, throat, and sides of the head pale rusty ; rest of the 
underparts crimson-scarlet, shading into orange-brown on the middle 
of the belly and thighs. Bill greenish yellow; legs and feet greenish 
hörn. Total length about 40 inches, wing 7*7, tau 27, tarsus 2*8.

barred with buff and black, the feathers of the mantle are mixed

1 am exceedingly doubtful if this bird has any right to even subspecific 
rank. It is probably a domestic variety of Ö. pictits and 
has never been obtained (so far as I am aware) in a wild btate.

Adult male. Top of the head dark bronze-green; elongate occipital 
crest blood-red: cape-like feathers covering the back of the head 
and neck pure white, margined and barred across the middle with 
black, glossed with steel-blue, and mostly rounded at the extremity; 
mantle and scapulars dark green, very similar in colour to the 
feathers of the mantle in O. pictus, but the extremities are much 
more rounded; feathers of the lower back and rump black, widely 
tipped with yellowish buff, and with a subterminal band glossed 
with dark green ; shorter upper tail-coverts tipped with scarlet; 
longer upper tail-coverts white, irregularly barred with black and 
widely tipped wtih orange-red; centre pair of tail-feathers white, 
with arched black bars on either web and tho interspaces marked 
with wavy lines of black; the outer feathers have the outer webs 
brownish white, barred with black, but without any intermediate 
black mottlings, and the inner webs white irregularly mottled with 
black; the wing-coverts and outer secondaries black, glossed with 
dark purplish green ; primaries brownish black, partially margined 
with buff on the outer web, remaining secondaries black; ehin.

346 PHASIANIBJE. 

Adult male*. Top of the head and mantie dark orange or orangered, 
sliading into orange or yellowish orange towards the extremities 
of the longer hackleaf; feathers on the lower part of the mantie 
hidden by the hackles ancl lesser coverts round the bend of the wing 
black more or less glossed with green or purplish blue • seapulars, 
median wing-coverts, and lower back dark maroon-red, shadinginto 
orange or orange-red on the long hackles which represent the rump-
feathers and shorter upper tail-coverts: secondary-coverts black 
glossed with purplish green ; quills black, the outer margins of the 
primaries cinnamon and the outer half of the outer webs of the 
secondaries chestnut or deep rufous brown; fore part of the neck, 
ehest, and rest of underparts black, slightly glossed with green; 
longer upper tail-eoverts and tau glossed with green or purplish green. 
Bill dark brown ; emarginate comb and wattles crimson or red; ear-
lappets generally white or pinkish white in Indian birds, red in 
Burmese and Malayan speeimens: naked skin on the sides of the 
head, chin, throat, and fore part of neck paler red; legs and feet 
slaty. Total length 29 inches, wing 9-5, fcail 14, tarsus 3*1. 

Immature males have the hackles of the mantie mueh paler than 
in the majority of adult birds and mostly with dark shaft-stripes; 
the chestnut part of the outer webs of the secondaries flnely 
mottled with black nearly to the margins; the feathers nnderlying 
the hackles of the mantie dull brownish black without any green 
gloss, and the comb and wattles rudimentary. 

Adult female. Top of the head rust-red, shading into orange on the 
neck and pale yellow on the Upper mantie, each feather with a wide 
black stripe down the centre; rest of the upper parts pale reddish 
brown, flnely mottled with black and with pale shafts; quills 
blackish brown, the outer half of the outer webs of the secondaries 
mottled with pale reddish brown; fore part of neck chestnut; ehest 
and breast pale light red, shading into pale reddish brown on the 
sides, flanks, and belly, each feather with a pale shaft; under tail-
coverts brownish black; tail-feathers like the secondaries, the 
centre pair of feathers mottled on the margins of both webs and 
the outer pairs on the outer web with pale rufous. Soft parts much 
tho same as those of the male; the comb in very much smaller, and 
the wattles are absent. Total length 16*5 inches, wing 7*5, tail 
5-5, tarsus 2*4. 

Hab. The jungles of Nbrth-eastern and parts of Central India, 
ranging south through the Malay Peninsula, east through Siam to 
Cochin China and Hainan ; it also oecurs in a wild state in Sumatra, 
Java, Lombock, Timor, Celebes, Palawan, and the Philippines. 

* In June the hackles and long tail-feathers are moulted both in this and the 
following species, and the fönner are replaced by short black feathers. A second 
moult takes place in September, and the shorfc feathers of the neck are again 
replaced by hackles and the long tail-feathers reappear. 
t There is considerable Variation in the colours of the hackles covering the 
mantie and rump and other parts of the plumage in different speeimens, but 
these differences appear to be inerely individtial and are not dependent on 
locality.

2. Gallus lafayetti.

Blyth, Ibis, 1867, pp. 154, 307 ; Gray, Rand-L B. ii. p. 261 (1870;;

Gallus lafayettii,

37. GAILUR. 349 
JECume Sf Marsh. Game JB. Ind. i. p. 241, pl. (1878); Ilume, Str. F. 

vii. p. 429 (1878); Legge, B. Ceyl iii. p. 730, pl. (1880); öatc«, 
ed. Hume's Nests §• Eggs, iii. p. 422 (1890). 
Adult male, Top of the head rufous orange; hacklcs on tho back 
and sides of the neck, Upper part of the mantle, and lessor wing-
coverts golden orange, with a black band down the middle; low-
part of the mantle, scapulars, and median wing-covertb orange-reo, 
with a dark maroon centre stripe; lower back and rump brighfc 
orange-red, the terminal half of cach feattier with a large triangulär 
spot of rieh glossy violet and narrowly margincd with black ; upper 
tail-coverts glossed with purple and blue; primaries brownibh black, 
lightest on the outer web : secondarics black, slightly glossed with 
purplish blue; greater coverts black, more or less mixed or margincd 
on the outer web with dark chestnut; feathers at the base of 
the naked throat rieh glossy violet; ehest, breast, and sides like 
the lower part of the mantle; feathers of the belly chestnut, 
mottled and tipped with black; flanks, thighs, and under tail-
coverts mostly black; tail black glossed with purplish blue. Comb, 
wattles, and naked skin about the head yellowish or purplish red, 
the former with a large oval yellow spot on the middle of the 
posterior half. Bill brown ; feet and legs pale yellow. Total length 
30 inches, wing 9, tail 11, tarsus 3. 

In a young male the greater part of the plumage above is dark 

chestnut, the glossy violet spots on the lower back and rump are 

present, also some median wing-coverts like thoso of the adult male; 

all the secondaries and secondary-coverts are blackish brown, finely 

mottled with chestnut, except the second quill, which is barred with 

bufY like that of the female. The ehest and breast are chestnut, 

with here and there an adult feather. The tail is much like that 

of the female, but the two outer pairs of feathers aro black. 

In an immaiure male some of the outer secondaries have their 

inner webs and extremities finely mottled with rufous, otherwise 

the plumage is like that of the adult. 

Adult female differs chiefly from the female of G. gcälus in 

the following points :—The fringes to the feathers of the neck and 

upper mantle are darker, more rufous, and not so wide; the 

secondaries are black, irregularly barred \uth buff; the feathers of 

the ehest and sides are black, mottled with rufous buff and with 

whitish shaft-stripes; the breast and rest of the underparts are 

white, irregularly barred and margined with black; and the tail-

feathers are black, thickly mottled with rufous. Comb very small; 

no wattles; facial skin not quite so naked as in G. gallus. Total 

length 17 inches, wing 7*5, tail 4-9, tarsus 2-4. 

An immature female has much less white about the ehest and the 

tips of the wing-feathers are mottled with pale rufous.

Aduilt male. Top of the head, back and sides of tbe neck, and 
upper part of the mantle covered with short truncate feathers, 
somewhat curved at the extremity, black at tbe base, shading into 
purplish blue edged witb golden green near tbe extremity, and 
rnargined witb purplish or greenisb bronze and fringed with black; 
lower part of tbe mantle golden green sbot witb blue, shading into 
violet-bronze towards tbe extremity and rnargined with. black; 
hackles of tbe lower back and rump long and black, narrowly 
rnargined all round witb golden yellow: shorter upper tail-coverts 
the same, but some have tbe centre part glossed with bluish green; 
lesser and median wing-coverts elongate and reddish orange, with 
a wide black stripe down the middle; quills and greater coverts 
black, sligbtly glossed with bluish green ; ehest and rest of underparts 
black, somewhat mixed with bufT towards the vent; longer 
upper tail-coverts and tail black, glossed witb bluish green. Upper 
margin of the oomb entire, a single wattle down the middle of the 
throat; sides of the head and lores naked, with only a few tiny 
isolated plumes. All the naked parts are scarlet; the comb and 
wattle green, yellow, and scarlet; bill horn-colour; feet and legs 
flesh-eolour. Total length 28 inches, wirig 9, tail 11*2, tarsus 2*9. 

In an immature male the secondaries and secondary-coverts are 
rnargined and mottled with bufü, and the comb, wattle, and spurs 
are rudimentary. 

Adult female. Top of the head, neck, and upper part of the 
mantle sandy brown, the feathers of the latter with submarginal 
blackish bands and dusky centre stripes; rest of the upper parts, 
secondaries, and secondary-coverts black, sligbtly glossed with 
green and irregularly barred and rnargined au the extremity with 
buff; primary-quills and coverts dark brown; lores, supercüiary 
stripes, and sides of the face pale bufT; chin and throat white; 
underparts bufT, the chest-feathers with brownish margins and the 
sides and flanks with blackish mottlings ; tail black, irregularly 
edged with buff. Total length 15-3 inches, wing 7'7, tail 4*5, 
tarsus 2*3.

POLYPLECTRON *. 
Type. 
Polyplectron, 7Tmm, P(r/. ^ GW/, ii. p. 363 (1813) .. P. chinquis. 
Diplectron, Vieill Analyse, p. 50 (1816) '. ... P. chinquis. 
Polyplectrum, Less. Traue ä'Orn. p. 487 (1831) .... P. chinquis. 
Diplectrum, Agas*. Index Universalis, p. 125 (1846).. P. chinquis. 
Diplectropus, Gloger, Hand- u. Hilfsb. p. 382 P. chinquis. 
Emphania, Reicherib. NaL Syst. Toy. p. xxix (1852) . P. napoleonia. 

Tail composed of 20 to 24 feathers, large, füll, and rounded, the 
middle pair twice as long as the outer pair and each ornamented 
with one or a pair of metallic oeelli. 

Ist primary much shorter than the 2nd ; 2nd shorter than the 
lOth ; 6th slightly the longcst. 

Sides of the face naked or very nearly so. 

Tarsus longer than middle toe and claw, and armed in the male 

with generally two and sometimes three spurs on each leg. 
Range. Indo-Chinese countries, from Sikhim to Cochin China, 
throughout the Malay Peninsnla, Sumatra, Borneo, Palawan, and 
? Philippines. 

Key to tlie Species. 

I. 
Mantle and wing-coverts ornamented with 
brilliant round metallic oeelli or with the 
terminal portion of each feather metallic. 
(Males.) 

A. 
Breast and belly brown, thickly spotted 
and mottled with dirty white or buff. 
a. 
Outer tail-feathers with well-developed 
metallic oeelli on the inner as well as 
the outer webs. 
a'. Oeelli green or bluish green, with 
blue and violet refiections. Facial 
skin pale fleshy yellow, throat 
white chinquis, p. 354. 

b'. 
Oeelli golden green, with bluish-
violet refiections. Facial skin 
crimson; no white throat germaini, p. 357. 

b. Outer tail-feathers with no oeelli on the 
inner web bicalcaratum, p. 357.

Aäult male. Feathers of the top of the hoad rather elongate, 
hairy, and mottled with black and white; feathers of the neck 
"barred with brownish white and brown, those on tho back soft and 
somewhat downy; all the rest of the upper parts brown, irregularly 
dotted all over with dirty white ; nearly every feather of the 
mantle, scapulars, lesser and median wing-coverts, outer secondaries 
and their coverts with a large, round, subterminal metallic 
ocellus of dark green, shading into violct exteriorly and with 
purple and hlue refleetions; each spot is edged with successive 
rings of "black, brown, and dirty white; longer upper tail-coverts 
and all the tail-feathers with pairs of ocelli, very similar to the 
above, but situated one on each side of the shaft at somo distance 
from the extremity; these spots are more oval in shape than those 
on the wings, and are entirely green in one light and purple in 

* There are now no speciinens from Southern China in the Oollection, and 1 
cannot find any record of any ever having been there.

PHASIANIDJE. 

another; tlie dirty white fmg surrounding each is imperfect 
exteriorly, and disappears into tlie brown of the feather; the 
prirnaries aro f aintly dottecl witb buff 011 the outer web and uniform 
brown on the inner; sides of the head almost entirely naked; chin 
and throat thinly covered with white feathers ; rest of underparts 
brown, with irregulär niottled and dotted bars of dirty white. 
Facial skin pale fleshy yellow; bill black, except basal part of lower 
inandible which is yellow; legs and feet blackish. Total length 
25*6 inches, wing 8*4, tail 13-2, tarsus 3. 

In an immature male the plumage resembles that of the female, 
but the ocelli on the mantle, scapulars, wing-coverts, and secondaries 
are mostly irregularly represented by somewhat obscure dark 
green and violet spots, the latter colour predorainating; the rings of 
dirty white enclosing the ocelli are represented by irregulär dots. 

Adult female. The top of the head and neck brown, the latter 
obscurely barred with paler brown and white dots situated at the tips 
of ihe shafts ; rest of the upper parts brown niottled with pale brown; 
the ocelli on the mantle, &c, of the male are represented by black 
spots more or less glossed, espeeially on the outer secondaries, with 
violet and purple; the tip of each feather is thickly mottled with dirty 
white; the feathers of the back and rump have white shafts and a few 
scattered whitish dots; the ocelli on the longer tail-coverts are 
absent and are only obscurely represented on the outer pairs of tail-
feathers, not, as a rule, on the middle pairs, which have only dark 
spots; chin and throat white; rest of underparts brown, finely 
mottled with whitish buff, under tail-coverts the samo. Eacialskin 
pale fleshy yellow; bill horny brown ; legs and feet very dark 
plumbeous. Total length 19 inches, wing 7*1, tail 8, tarsus 2*4. 

An immature female has the outer secondaries and longer scapulars 
margined and mottled with rufous and the outer webs of the secondaries 
are dotted with pale rufous. 

ff ab. Indo-Chinese countries, ranging in the north-west to Sikhim, 
eastward to the Laos country, and southwards through Tenasserim 
as far as Mergui.

2. Polyplectron germaini. 
Hen Peaeock Pheasant from China, JEdiv. Nett Mist. JB. ii. pl. 69 

(1747). * 
L'Eperonnier, D'Aubent. PL Eni pl. 493 [fenielle]. 
Polyplectron germaini, Mliot, Ibis, 1866, p. 56; id. 3£on. Phas. i. 

pl. 8 (1872) [Bien-lioa, Cochin China]; Hume, Str. F. vii. p. 426 
(1878); Sume $ Marsh. Game JB. Ind. i. p. 111 (1878). 

Adult male. General colotir blackish brown, irregularly spotted 
with light brown, the spots being much smaller and closer together 
than. in P. chinquis. Head and back part of neck black, eacb 
feather barred with white; back, wings, and tail covered with 
metallic spots, in some lights of a dark lustrous green, in others of 
a rieh purple; primaries dark brown. Upper mandible black, 
lower horn-colour ; orbital skin erimson ; feet black. Total length 
20 inches, wing 7*5, tail 10*5, tarsus 2*5. 

Adultfemale is distinguished from the fernab of P. chinquis by 
the following characters :—The ocelli on the mantle, scapulars, wing-
coverts, and outer secondaries are eomparatively well-marked and 
glossed with dark green, changing to purple and bordered anteriorly, 
especially on the scapulars and outer secondaries, with narrow fcshaped 
black and buff bands ; the extremities of these feathers are 
not thickly spotted with dirty white; most of the longer upper 
tail-coverts, like the tail-feathers, carry a pair of dark green ocelli, 
shot with purple, and situated one on each web. The only speeimen 
examined has only 18 tail-feathers, but no doubt some are missing. 
Total length 18*6 inches, wing 7*1, tail 8*5, tarsus 2*3.

Adult male. At onco distinguished from P. biccdcaratum, to which 
it is most nearly allied, by the following characters :—The crest is 
cuxled forwards; the frill round the back of the neck is moro 
developed and the violet margin much wider; the ocelli on the back 
and wings are bluish green• the sides of the neck and ehest are 
black, finely mottled with buff, each feather with a golden-green 
subterniinal, heart-shaped ocellus ehanging to bluish purple; the 
middle of the neck and ehest white, which colour is irregularly continued 
down the middle of the breast and belly; the rest of the 
underparts are black speckled with buff; the ocelli on the middle 
pair of tail-feathers and Upper tail-coverts touch but are not confluent. 
Pill horn-brown; naked skin on face reddish ; legs and feet 
blue-grey. Total length 20 inches, wing 7*8, tail ca. 7*8, tarsus 2*6. 

Adult female. Differs chiefly from the female of P. bicalcaratum 
in having no ocelli on the longer upper tail-coverts, so that the tail 
shows only a single series, and the underparts washed with black.

Adidt male. Top of the head and elongate crest dark green,

green and changing to dark blue and deep vi ölet; the lesser wing-

coverts black; the bastard-wing, quills, and their coverts brownish 

black; the lower back and rump black, thickly spotted and mottled 

with rufous buff; the Upper tail-coverts and tail the same, but the 

spots are fewer, rounder, and paler than on the back; the longer 

tail-coverts and tail-feathers are terminated by a submarginal black 

band, edged on either side with buff and fringed externally with 

black; each of these feathers is ornamented with a pair of bluish-

green oeelli, changing to deep violet and circumscribecl by a black


and-grey ring; but the three or four outer pairs of tail-feathers 

have the eye on the inner web obsolete and only represented by a 

black spot; a very narrow superciliary * and a triangulär pafch 

covering the hinder part of the cheek and ear-eoverts pure white ; 

lores, thin covering of feathers on the sides of the face, chin, throat, 

and rest of underparts black; the feathers on the fore part of the 

neck are sometim.es obscurely tipped with golden green, like those 

of the back. Bill dark brown, tip horny; orbital skin crimson. 

Legs and feet pirrple-brown. Total length 19 inches, wing 7*3, 

tail 8-7, tarsus 2-o. 

An immature male resembles the female, but the tail and greater 
coverts are like those of the adulfc male, though the oeelli are much 
smaller and are absent on the inner web of all the tail-feathers 
except the three rniddle pairs; one or two of the feathers of the 
mantle have a metallic bluish-green patch in the middle ; and traces 
are apparent of black plumage on the mantle, wing-coverts, throat, 
and underparts.

Argusa giganteus, Kelliam, Ibis, 1881, p. 530 [Perak, Malacca]. 

Adult male. The top of the head and short oecipital crest black; 
back of the neck thinly covered with hairy feathers finely barred 
with black and white; mantle, wing-coverts, and scapulars black, 
chequored and mottled with buff; lower back and shorter rump-
feathers clear buff, with rounded black spots; longer rump-feathers 
paler buff, and clongate middle pair of tail-coverts whitish, thickly 
marked with kidnoy-shaped black spots and blotches ; rest of upper 
and nnder tail-coverts black, with narrowr wavy bars of white. Primaries 
greyish brown, shading into yellowish towards the margins 
of the outer wcbs and ornamented with closely approxirnated rows 
of black and rufoas spots; on the basal part of the inner web, and 
separated from the shaft by a yellowish line regularly barred with 
black, is a band of rufous minutely dotted with white ; shafts dull 
blue, edged with yellow near the extremity. Secondaries pale 
brownish white, the onter web with oblique bands and rows of 
black spots; next the shaft a series of large ocelli, gradually 
increasing in size towards the extremity; each of these ocelli is 
yellowish in the centre, shading into white on the one side and 
reddish brown on the other and surronnded by a black band ; the 
inner web white towards the margin, ornamented with several rows 
of round black spots ; the terminal part of each feather black, reti


culated with pale rufous and spotted and marked with white. Pore 
part of neck chestnut barred with black; rest of underparts black, 
with wavy bars and markings of chestnut and buff. The long 
middle pair of tail-feathers tipped with dirty white ; the outer web 
reddish brown shading into black towards the shaft, and the inner 
web grey: the whole thickly dotted with small white ocelli surrounded 
by black rings ; the out er feathers similarly marked, bufc 
ncarry uniform black, mottled with rufous towards the extremit}*. 
-Bill and claws bhrish white ; facial skin dark blue; legs and feefe 
bright red. Total length 72 inches; wing to the end of the primaries 
19, to the end of the secondaries 34 ; tail 50, tarsus 4*4. 

The immature male differs from the adult in having the lower 
back, rump, and upper tail-coverts like those of the female, only 
more coarscly marked; the primaries rufous, mottled and spotted 
with small irregulär black marks ; the secondaries like those of the 
female, but the ocelli of the adult are present in a rudimentary form ; 
the breast finely vermiculated with reddish brown and black ; and 
the outer tail-feathers mottled with rufous to the base. 

Adult female. Peathers on the top of the head buff edged with black; 
nape as in rhe male ; neck chestnut, slightly mottled with black and 
shading into reddish buff on the mantle, which is thickly mottled 
with black: lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts bright buff, 
irregularly barred and vermiculated with black ; primaries chestnut, 
mottled and spotted with irregulär black marks- wing-eoverts, 
scapulars, and secondaries black, thickly covered with buff hiero


40 . ARGUSLOrUS. 
365 

glyphics, the outer webs of the latter next the shafts mixed with 
rufous; ehest and rest of nnderparts rufous, fmely motüod with 
bla.dk; under tail-coverts black, fmely vermiculated with pale rufous ; 
tail-feathers black, thickly mottlcd with irregulär rufous lines and 
marks. Legs and feet duller red than in the male. Total length

3. Argusianus bipnnctatus. 
Argus bipnnctatus, 
Wood, Ann. Mag. N. H. (4) viii. p. 67 (1871); 
JElliot, Mon. Fhas. i. pl. 13 (1872). 

This species is still known only from a portion of a primary 
wing-feather from a male bird, which is now preserved in this 
Musenm ; bnt it is so perfeetly distinet both in its markings and in 
the shape of the shaft of the quill from either of the above species 
that one can have no hesitation in recognizing it as belonging to 
a distinet species, in spite of the somewhat fragmentary evidence. 

The general colour of this feather is similar to that of a primary 
quill of A. argus and A. grayi, but there is a reddish-brown 
band minutely dotted with white on the outer as well as the inner 
web. These bands estend over a large proportion of both the webs; 
the shaft is remarkably narrow and attenuated. 

Mab. Unknown.

Portion of primary quill. Locality unknown. E. Bartlett, Esq. [P.].

Adult male. Top of the head covered with short eurly metallic 
green and blue feathers, occipital crest composed of fan-shaped 
bluish-green feathers at the end of elevated shafts; neck greenish 
blue, shading into rieh purplish blue on the upper parts of the 
mantle and ehest; feathers of the mantle with the terminal half 
copper-coloured, surrounded with golden green and margined with 
black, and with narrow green shaft-stripes; feathers of the lower 
back, rump, and upper tail-coverts, especially the latter, enormously 
developed, with the greater part of the web free; the 
majority of these feathers, except the very longest and some of the 
outer tail-coverts, are oraamented with brilliant subtorminal ocelli, 
green with purple pupils in a field of golden copper, and circumscribed 
with rings of gold, copper, and other metallic hues; the 
general ground-colour of the shorter feathers in the middle of the 
train is purplish eopper, and the rest golden green, the wholo 
varying in eolour aecording to the light, a number of the lateral 
feathers are blade-shaped and feathered on the outer web of the 
shaft only; the longest upper tail-coverts terminate in green fan-
shaped plumes devoid of ocelli; the lesser and median wing-coverts, 
scapulars, and outer secondaries pale buff, barred and mottled with 
black, more or less glossed with green; the primarios and their 
eoverts and the bastard-wing pale chestnut: the inner primarios 
more or less mottled with black; the rest of the secondaries and 
their eoverts black ; a few of the outer median eoverts black, glossed 
with purplish green ; feathers in front of the eye, the superciliary 
stripe, chin, throat, fore part of neck, breast, and flanks dark glossy 
green; belly and largely-developed downy under tail-coverts 
blackish brown; thighs whitish buff; taii blackish brown, the 
outer web with wavy buff mottlings. Kaked skin round the eye 
and on the cheek livid white; bill and legs dark horn-grey. Total 

iength to end of teil 35 inches, to end of upper tail-coverts 78, 
wing 17*5, tau 19*5, tarsus 5*5. 
Adult female. Top of the head, lores, superciliary stripe, car-

VOL. XXII. 2 B 

370 PffASIAKTIDJE. 

covorfcs, and nape dark chestnut, irregularly bordered with white; 

orcst shapcd like that of the male, but the terminal plume mostly 

chestnut edged with golden green ; upper neck chestnut, most of the 

feathers tipped with golden green; lower part of neck and upper 

mantie golden green, some of the lower feathers fringed with buff; 

rest of the upper parts brown, more or less indistinctly mottled with 

buff; primarios and secondaries dark brown, the former indistinctly 

mottled with rufous and the latter with buff towards the edge of 

the outer web ; the outer median and secondary wing-coverts more 

coarsely mottled with buff and black; chin, throat, and a part of 

the neck white; ehest brownish black, edged with green and 

shading into buff; breast, sides, and flanks buff, more or less 

mixed with rufous, and shading into brown on the belly and under 

tail-coverts; tail dark brown, slightly mottled with whitisb buff. 

Total length 32 inches, wing 16, tail 13, tarsus 4*8. 

Young males closely resemble the female, but the primaries are 

mostly pale chestnut, more or less mottled with black, and the 

secondaries are more coarsely mottled with pale buff. 

Immature males resemble the adult, but the mantie and ehest are 

greenish blue and not nearly so brilliant, and the train is absent 

or rudimentary.

Sport of Nature.

Pavo spieifer, Schirm, Nat. Vög. p. 150, pl. 73 (1853). 

Adult male. Differs chiefly from P. cristatus in having the feathers 

of the crest more elongate, normally developed, and equally webbed 

on each side of the shaft; the whole of the feathers of the neck, 

upper mantle, and ehest dull gold, narrowly margined with blaek 

and with a large central patch of deep blue shading into golden 

green on the sides• the wing-coverts and scapulars black, glossed 

with purplish blue and margined with green; the feathers of the 

lower back, rump, and shorter upper tail-eoverts more glossed with 

purple, the longer upper tail-coverts with. brilliant gold and green ; 

the thighs black glossed with 'green. ÜNaked skin round the eye 

bluish green, on the cheek orange; bill horn-grey; legs and feet 

dark brownish grey. Total length to end of tail 51 inches, to the 

end of the upper tail-coverts 82-5, wing 19*1, tail 22*5, tarsus 0*6. 

An immature male resembles the female, but the lower back is 

mostly bronze-green shading into bronze on the rump, the upper 

tail-coverts are golden green tipped with bronze, and do not extend 

to within six or seven inches of the end of the tail. 

In quite young speeimens the green of the neck, mantle, and breast 

is well developed, though slightly mottled here and there with buff; 

the crest also is about three inches in length ; and the tail is 

distinctly barred with buff. 

Adult female. Differs from the male in having the lower mantle, 
back, rump, scapulars, and outer secondaries mostly blackish brown, 
barred and indistinctly mottled with buff and only very slightly 
glossed with green ; the upper tail-coverts extending nearly to the 
end of the tail and of a golden-green hue irregularly barred with 
buff. Total length 4i inches, wing 16*7, tail 16, tarsus 5*4. 

Hab. Indo-Chinese countries, ranging north to Chittagong, east 
through Siam to Cochin China, and south through the Malay Peninsula; 
also Sumatra ? and Java.

43. PHASIDUS 
•jLype. 
Phasidus, Cassin, P. Ac. Phüad. 1856, p. 322 P. niger. 
Head and neck naked, with the exception of a band of feathers 
from the base of the bill to the occiput, and a few small scatterod 
pluraes on the neck. 
Tail probably composed of 14 feathers, moderately long and 
ronnded. Upper tail-coverts about § the length of tail. 
Ist primary considerably shorter than the 2nd, which is about 
equal to the lOth, the 4th slightly the longest. 
Tarsus somewhat longer than the middle toe and claw, provided 
with a short bitint spur in the male.

Adult. Bony helmet long, elevated, and compressed, and usually 
curved backwards ; the base extends from the forehead to the 
oeeiput, and the height varies from 1 ineh to 1*5. The gencral 
colour of the plumage is black, tbickly spotted all over with white; 
the spots on the upper parts smaller than those on the under, 
and divided from one another by a network of dotted white lines ; 
the feathers round the base of the neck are more or less barred 
with narrow black and white bands; a band of elongate black 
feathers on the nape; over the naked head and neck a few hairs 
are scafctered, most numerous below the eye; each of the white 
spots along the margin of the outer web of the secondaries takes the 
form of a short oblique band. Upper parts of the head and wattles 
at the angles of the gape red; neck bluish purple : bill yellowish 
horn-colour, darker at the base; legs and feet dark horn-brown. 
Total length 20-5 inches, wing 11, tail 64, tarsus 3*1, middle toe 
(with claw) 2-65.

Ann. Mus. Civ. Genov. xsl p. 212 (1884); Shelley, P. Z. S. 1888, 
p. 48 [Tingaai]. 
Numida meleagris, Lefeb. Abyss., Ois. p. 142 (1845-50). 
Numida ptilornynchus, Gray, List Gallints Brit. Mus. p. 43 (1867). 
Adidt. Hesembles the male of N. mit rata, but difiers from this 
as well as from all the allied species in havirig a bunch of horny 
bristles at the base of the culmen: these bristles vary greatly in 
length and number; in some fully adult specimens they are largely 
developed, while in others they are very short and few in number. 
The npper half of the neck is thinly covered with black feathers ; 
the margins of the onter webs of the secondaries are finely vermiculated 
with black and white; the white spots on the greater secondary 
coverts are more or less eonfluent and form oblique white bands. 
In some specimens the inner webs of the primaries have two or 
threo rows of white spots, in others they are uniform dark brown or 
with only a few spots near the extremity. The absence or presence 
of white spots is apparently purely individual, and has nothing to 
do with age or sex. Bare skin of neck, face, and wattles blue; 
helmet and bristles pale horny: legs reddish dusky. Total length 
19 inches, wing 11, tail 6'4, tarsus 3-2, middle toe (with claw) 2*7.

Bogos-Land, Suakim, Sennaar, and Kordofan.

one of Mr. Elliot's types now before me and with two speeimens frora Mozambique, 
bui. iL is impossible to teil from dried skins, which look all clark. On the 
other hand, the specimen described and figureel bv Mr. Sclater ancl obfcained 
near the Victoria Falls, Zambesi, " seems to differ," he says, "in having a conspieuous 
fold of naked skin at the back of the neck of a pale yellowish-grey 
colour, the naked skin on the throat not red but leaden grey, and a siightly 
feathered chin." This description applies to the great majority of our series of 
Cr. edouardi from Natal, Zulu-land, and Zambesi. Tt may be that the birds 
described as having the throat bright red are old birds in the breedmg-season, 
and that the birds with the yellowish-grey neck and leaden-grey throat are 
younger examples; but, even supposing Mr. Elliot's Statement to be correet, 
there can be no doubt that all the speeimens before me belong to one and the 
same species, Cr. edouardi. Mr. Ayres (Ibis, 1873, p. 256) says " the bare skia 
of the sides of the head, chin, throat, and upper neck is blaek, but whitish on 
the oeeiput." This note is made from speeimens which were being hawked 
about the town of D'ürban, and, as no doubt the dark purple skin on the sides 
of the head, chin, throat, and upper neck turns black soon after death, this description 
agrees well enough with Mr. Sclater's figure and description of the 
live bird in the Zoological Gardens.

PHASIANTDJE. 

oblique lines of white on tho outer web ; primaries blackish brown, 
spotted with white towards the tip and the inner ones mottled with 
tho samo colour along the margin of the otiter web ; inner seeondaries 
brownish black, outer black, all more or less spotted with 
white at the extremity, and, except the first two, with oblique white 
bars on the outer web and oblique rows of white spots on the inner, 
the first four are also margined with reddish brown, and the third 
and fourth have a submarginal band of purplish blue, while the 
fifth is narrowly margined with the same colour. Breast and belly 
cobalt-blue, black down the middle. Long pointed middle pair of 
tail-feathers black, minutely dotted all over and spotted with white 
towards the base; outer ones black, largely spotted all over with 
white. Naked parts of the head and neck cobalt-blue. Total 
length 30 inches, wing 12*2, tail 11*3, tarsus 4*1, middle toe (with 
claw) 3. 

Adult female. Differs from the male only in having no spurs on 
tho tarsi and being a little smaller. Total length 27 inches, 
wing 12, tail 10, tarsus 3-8, middle toe and claw 2*9. 

In immature specimens the hackles on the neck and ehest are 
interspersed with short feathers transversely barred with blaek and 
white, some of the wing-coverts are also barred with white, and the 
back of the neck is thinly covered with feathers. 

A very young female has the head still covered with rufous down, 
longitudinally barred with black; the plumage of the upper parts 
alternately barred with black, buff, and rufous, and tipped with 
buff; the chin and throat white, and the underparts black, barred 
and fringed with pale buff.

situated on the middle of the breast; feathered part of the back of 
the neck, upper back, lesser, median, and greater seeondary-eoverts 
and underparts copper-bronze, shot with purplish green and fiery

purplish band; upper tail-coverts with the basal part barred with 
chestnut and the extremity widely tipped with white. Primaries, 
primary-coverts, and bastard-wing nearly equally barred with dark 
brown and white, the white bars on the inner webs more or less 
mottled with brown: secondaries similar, but the white bars are 
narrower and the brown paler and mixed with rufous, especially on 
the outer quills, whieh are somewhat glossed on the onter web with 
purplish green and red-gold. Plank-feathers and under tail-coverts 
black, with a wide subterminal metallic band and widely tipped 
with white. Tail-feathers mottled with dull chestnut and black, with 
a wide subterminal black band and white tip, the out er feathers 
have a slight metallic band across the middle of the black. Xaked 
skin on head and neck pale crimson ; bill orange-red; legs and feet 
coral-red. Total length ca. 43 inches, wing 21, tail 15-5, tarsus 7. 

Adult female. DifTers from the male in having the feathers up the 
middle of the back of the neck continued in a narrow "band over the 
crown to the base of the small ereetile process ; no buneh of hairlike 
feathers on the breast and no spurs ; the plumage Is very similar 
though not so bright, and the lower back and all the underparts are 
fringed with white like the feathers of the rump and upper tail-
coverts. Total length ca. 40 inches, wing 17*9, tail 14*3, tarsus 5*3.

3. Meleagris ocellata. 
The Turkey, Pennant, Phil. Trans, lxxi. p. 79 (1781) [pari, Yucatan], 


Meleagris ocellata, Cuv. Mim. Mus. d'Hist. Nat. vi. p. 1, pl. i. 

(1820) [Gulf of Honduras]; Temm. PL Col. v. pl. 1(3 [no. 112] 
(1824); Less. TraiU d'Orn. p. 400 (1831) ; Jard. Nat. Üb., Orn. 
in. p. 143, pl. iii. (1830); Caboty P. Post. Soc. i. p. 73 (1842); 
td. J. Post. Soc. iv. p. 246 (1842) [park]; Gray, List of B. 
pt. iii. Gatt. p. 29 (1844); Solat $ Sah. Ibis, 1859, p. 225; 
Moore, P. Z. S. 1859, p. 62 [Belize, Petenl; Taylor, Ibis, 1860, 

p. 311; Selat. P. Z. S. 1861, p. 402, pl. xi., & 1863, p. 125; Gray, 
List Gallinm Brit. Mus. p. 42 (1867); id. Kand-l. B. ii. p. 2ß'2 
(1870); Elliot, Mon. Phas. i. pl. 33 (1872); Boucard, P. Z. S. 
1883, p. 461 [Yucatanl; Piägw. Man, N Amer. B. p. 207 
(1887). 
Meleagris aureus, Vieill. Tabl. Encycl. MSth. i. p. 361 (1823). 

Adult male. Eeathers of the mantle, scapulars, and ehest have 
the basal half black, the terminal half brass-green shading into 
purplish black towards the extremity, margined by a narrow dark 
black line and fringed with greenish copper. On the lower back 
and rump the basal parts of the feathers are finely mottled with 
white, their extremities gradually increase in brilliance and the 
margins in width tili on the upper tail-coverts and tail the colours 
attain their greatest magnificence; here the brass-green of the 
mantle is replaced by brilliant greenish-blue bands changing to purple 
and forming subtcrminal ooelli on the tail-feathers; the wide margins 
are rieh copper-red with grecn reflections. The lesser and median 
wkig-coverts are mostly golden green with shades of dark bhie and 
narrow black margins; the greater secondary-coverts reddish copper 
shot with golden green and pnrple and shading into greenish gold 
towards the ends of the inner webs. Primaries, bastard-wing, and 
primary-coverts brownish black barred with white, widest on the 
outer webs of the inner quills; bastard secondary with the outer 
web uniform brown, rest with the outer web mostly white, the 
dark bars being confined to the part next the quill; inner webs of 
all dark brown barred with white; the outermost secondaries have 
the dark bars glossed with metallic golden green. Breast and belly 
black, with copper-red margins to the feathers; flanks and under 
tail-coverts like the lower back. Head and neck covered with 
naked blue skin, scarlet round the eye, and ornamented with small 
red wart-like wattles, the largest situated between the eyes; the 
erectile process on the forehead blue with red warts at the tip. 
Bill, legs, and feet red; the tarsus armed with a long stout sharp 
spur. Total length ca. 40 inches, wing 16*5, tail 13*5, tarsus 55 . 

Adult female resembles the male; but the plumage is not so 
brilliant and the ocelli at the ends of the tail-feathers are much 
reduced. The erectile process is very small, and the great spurs 
are represented by small wart-like knobs. Total length ca. 33 
inches, wing 14*2, tail 13*1, tarsus 4*4. 

Bah. Central America; Guatemala, Yucatan, and British Honduras.

49. DENDBOETYX. 
Type. 
Dendrortyx, Gould, Mbn. Odontoph, pl. xx. or pt. i. 
(1844), Introd. p. 20 (1850) D. macrourus. 

Sexes praetically similar. A short occipital crest. 
Ist primary much shorter than the lOth ; 5th longest. 
Tail composed of 12 feathers, the outer pair much shorter than 


the middle pair, which are as long or nearly as long as the wing. 
Tarsus shorter than the middle toe and claw. 
Bill very stout and ahort; claws moderate. 
Range. Central America, from Southern Mexico to Costa Bica.

Adult male. Head, chin *, and throat black, the longer occipital

commencing above the middle of the eye and continued backwards 
above the ear-coverts ; a similar parallel stripe below the ear-
coverts and bordering the sides of the throat. Feathers of the 
neck, mantle, ehest, and sides chestnut in the middle and widely 
edged with grey on the sides, on the middle of the ehest and sides 
the chestnut centres are paler and less distinet; lower back, rump,

and uppcr tail-coverts dull olive-brown, finely mottled with black,

2. Dendrortyx barbatus. 
Dendrortvx barbatus, Licht., Goidd, Mon. Odo?itoph. pt. ii. pl. 22 
(1846)palapa]: Gray, List Gallince Brit. Mus. p. 74 (1867); id. 
Hand-l. B. ii. p.'272 (1870). 

Adult male and female. Top of the head and ear-coverts brown, 
forehead paler, the occipital feathers forming a fairly long crest; 
superciliary stripe, cheeks, throat, and fore part of neck dark grey, 
chin and middle of throat usually palcr; back and sides of the 
neck chestnut, edged on the sides with grey ; mantle similar, but the 
grey sides are narrower and there is an irregulär black and white 
spot on the margin of both webs; rest of tho upper parts very 
similar to B. macrourus, but the ends of the scapulars and outer 
secondaries are mostly deep black, irregularly edged and marked 
with buff round the extremity; the ehest, breast, and sides of 
belly are dull light chestnut; rest of the underparts nearly similar 
to D. macrourus, The ground-colour of the quills and outer tail-
feathers reddish chestnut. Bill, naked skin round the eye, legs and 
feet red. Total length 13-6 inches, wing 6*2, tail 4*8, tarsus 1-95, 
middle toe and claw 2*1. 

An immature bird differs from the adult in having most of the 
feathers of the nape and mantle blotched with black at the

3. Dendrortyx leucophrys. 
Ortyx leucophrys, Gould, P. Z. S.1843, p. 182 [Coban]. 
Dendrortyx leucophrys, Gould, Mon. Odontoph. pt. ii. pl. 21 (1846) ; 
Seht, fy Salvin, Ibis, 1859, p. 226; Gray, List Gallince Brit. Mus. 

p. 73 (1867); id. Hand-l B. ii. p. 272 (1870); Boucard, P. Z. S. 
1878, pp. 40, 42 [Volcano of Irazu, Costa Kica, 7000 ft.]; Zeledon, 
P. U. S. Nat. Mus. viii. p. 112 (1886) [Costa Kica], 
Adult male and female. Differ chiefly from D. maerourus in 
having the forehead, lores, chin, and Upper part of throat white; 
the superciliary stripe complete; the white stripe below the ear-
coverts absent; the occipital feathers dull rufous and. shorter; the 
lower part of the throat and neck similar to the mantle, which has 
the dark chestnut stripe down the middle of tho feathers edged on 
either side with black; the lower back, rump, and upper tail-
coverts uniform olive-brown finely mottled with dusky, and almost 
if not entirely devoid of buff niarkings, those on the wing-eoverts 
and secondaries much reduced; the breast and. rest of underparts 
more dusky grey, with well-marked rufous stripes down the middle; 
and the quills and outer tail-feathers with the ground-colour 
chestnut. Bill black, lower mandible orange below; naked space 
round the eye, tarsi and feet orange-red. Total length 13*6 inches, 
wing 6, (ail 5*7, tarsus 1*95, middle toe and claw 2*1.

(1849) [N. Mexico " and the adjoining parts of California!"].

(1881) [Bio San Pedro, Arizona], 

Adult male. Porehcad and sidcs of head grey, short occipital 

crest and ear-coverts brown, the former tipped with white; chin 

and throat whitish buff• neck, mantle, ehest, and sides of breast 

grey, shading into pale whitish buff on the middle of the breast 

and belly, every feather margined with black, giving all these parts 

a 
beautiful scaled appearance, while across the middlo of each 

feather of the imderparts is a V-shaped dusky band or mark; 

wings, lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts brownish grey, 

the longer scapulars and outer secondaries margined on the inner 

web with white; flanks grey, with white shaffc-spots on the terminal 

half of the feathers ; vent buff; under tail-coverts pale rufous buff, 

with usually a dark mark or band down the middle; tail grey, 

the outer feathers narrowly margined round the tips with white. 

Total length 10 inches, wing 4*8, tail 3-6, tarsus 1*2, middle toe 

and claw 1*35. 

Adult femdle. Differs only from the male in having dusky

Type.

(1884) [Colorado desert]. 
Orortyx picta, Coues, Key N. Am. B. p. 591 (18S4). 
Oreortyx pictus plumiferus, A. O. U. Check-list, p. 108 (188G); 
Rithjw. Man. p. 191 (1887); Toionsenä, P. U. S. Fat Mus. x. 

pp 199, 235 (1887) [N. California]; Beiding, Occas. Pap. CaL 
Ac. Sei. ii. p. 9 (1890); Bendire, N. Am. B. p. 14, pl. i. figs. 2, 3 
'(189:2). 

Oreortyx pictus confmis, Anthony, P. Calif. Ac. Sei. (2) ii. p. 74 
(1889) • id. Zoe, i. p. 5 (1890) [San Pedro Martir Hange, Lower 
CaL]; Bendire, N. Am. B. p. 17 (1892). 

Adiät male and female. An occipital crest of two very long black 
feathors ; top of the head, back and sides o£ tho neck, upper part of 
mantlo (in males and some females) *, ehest, and breast slate-grey ; 
rest of upper parts olive-brown ; tbe scapnlars and outer seeondaries 
margined on the inner web with white more or less mixed with 
pale rufous ; a white band extending across the chin fco the lores ; 
throat and fore part.of neck deep chestnnt, margined on eitherside 
by a white band, which passes across the basal half of the ear-
coverts* a black patch on the eheek below the eye often continued 
on the side of the throat in a line between the chestnnt and 
white ; upper part of the bolly mostly chestnnt; underparts and 
vent pale buff; sides and flanks irregularly marked and barred with 
chestnut, white, and black ; thighs rufous ; under tail-coverts 
black, with chestnut middles; tail-feathers dark olive-grey, finely 
mottled with black. Bill black ; iris, legs, and feet brown. Total 
length 9-6 inches, wing 5*2, tail 3*3, tarsus 1*4, middle toe and 
claw 1*6. 

A quite young bird in August has all the upper parts olive-
brown, washed with rufous on the inner webs of the scapulars and 
outer seeondaries, and all finely mottled with blaek and pale buff; 
many feathers of the mantle have also pale shafts, and the scapulars 
and some of the wing-coverts are blotched with black; the chestnut 
throat of the adult is black; the ehest and upper breast dirty 
grey, most of the feathers with pale shafts and whitish spots at the 
tips ; only a few of the chestnut feathers of the flanks are beginning 

* Most of the males have the mantle grey, but in some speeimens this eolour 
is more or loss mixed with olive-brown; on the other hand, most females have 
the olive-brown continued up the back of the neck to the erest, but some have 
the upper mantle more or less washed with grey. I have seen no males with 
the olive-brown going up to the crest, and no females have the back of the neck 
and mantle clear grey hke the breast; but several speeimens in mtennediato 
plumage belong to both sexes. Ridgway, in bis ' Manual,' P- 191, recognizes 
two subspecies of Oreortyx (0. pictus and 0. plumiferus), and uses these &cx/ral 
characters to clistinguish them. He inakes out that the brown-necked birds 
(females) are confined to the Coast-region, while those with grey neck and 
mantle (males) inhabit the Sierra Nevada. But in a good series of speeimens 
from Öarson, Nevada, I find many brown-necked speeimens (all females) as 
well as grey, and from the Coast-region there is about an equal number of 
each.

p. 169 (1886); Townsend, P. ü. 8. Nat. Mus. x, pp. 200, 235 
(1887) [N. California, interior]; TLidgw. Man. N. Am. B. p. 192

Beldinq, Occas. Pap. Cal. Ae. Sei p. 12 (1890); Bendire, N. Am. B. 
p. 26 (1892). 
Adidi male. Porehead yellowish buff with dark shafts, bounded 
behind by a white band which crosses the head between the eyes, 
and is continued behind them in a white supereiliary stripe; OD. 
each side of this band the head is black, shading into brown on 
the occipital region; a weli-developed crest of black club-shaped 
feathers ; ehin, throat, and oheeks black, bounded by a white band 
which passes across the base of the black ear-coverfcs; back and 
sides of the neek, mantle, and ehest grey ; each feather of the former 
with a black marginal band, produced up the shaft and giving a 
W-shaped appearance ; there is also a subterminal white spot on 
both webs ; these last disappear on the feathers of the mantle, on 
the lower feathers of which the black margins also gradually disappear 
; the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts are olive-
brown, washed with grey (in coast speeimeus), or grey washed with 
olive (in inland speeimens); the wing-coverts, scapulars, and outer 
secondaries are usually rather darker, the latter edged, especially on 
the inner web, with buff; primaries and inner secondaries brownish, 
the middle of the breast buff; middle of belly chestnut, shading into 
white or whitish buff on the sides and underparfs; all the feathers 
are margined and barred across the middle with black; the sides 
and flanks with white shaft-stripes; thighs and under tail-coverts 
buff, blackish down the middle; tail slate-grey. Total length 9*7 
inches, wing 4*4, tail 3*6, tarsus 1*25, middle toe and claw 1*45. 

Adultfemale. Differs chieny from the male in having the crest 
shorter and browner, no black and white pattern on the head and 
throat, most of the feathers being dirty white with dark centres, the 
general colour of the neck, mantle, and ehest brownish grey, and of 

VOL. XXII. 2 D 

402 
riiAsican.x:. 

the underparts white, tinged with buff on the belly. Total length 
9 inches, wing 4*3, tail 3*3, tarsus 1*2, middle toe and claw 1-4. 

Younrf mdles and females somewhat resem})le the female adult, but 
most of the feathers of the Upper parts and ehest have buff shafts • 
the wing-coverts, scapulars, and outer secondaries are mostly 
washed with rufous and finelv mottled and marked with b]ack ; the 
throat, breast, and rest of underparts are whitish, the two latter 
indistinctly marked and barred with dusky; and the tail with 
transverse whitish mottling*. The adult feathers usually begin to 
appear ürst on the sides of the neck and ehest. 

Hab. Western States of X. America, ranging north to Washington 
south as far as Cape St. Lucas, Tower California, and eastwards to 
Nevada. Introduced into various parts of the world.

2. Lophortyx gambeli. 
Lophortyx gambeli, Nntt., Gambel,P. Ac. Philad. 1843, p. 260 [West

U. 8. $ Mex. Surv., Birds, p. 23 (1859) ; id. B. N. Amer. p. 645

Lophortyx californicus, 
Coues (nee Shaw 8? Nodd.), Ibis, 1865, p. 105 
[Arizona]; Dresser, Ibis, 1866, p. 27 [Devil's River]. 

Adult male is at once to be distinguished from L. californicus by 
having the forehead blacker ; tlie back of thc head chestnut; the 
feathers of the back of the neck without snbterminal white spots; 
the ehest with dark shafts ; the middle of the belly black; the 
feathers of the "breast and "belly without black margins, and tho 
feathers of the sides deep chestnut instead of grey. Total length 
9*8 inehes, wing 5, tail 4, tarsus 1*3, middle toe and claw 1*55. 

Adult female. Differs from the female of L. californicus in having 
the crest considerably more developed, the back of the neck without 
white spots, the ehest with dark shafts, the feathers of the breast 
and belly not margined with black, and the flanks chestnut}. Total 
length 9-2 inches, wing 4*6, tail 3*9, tarsus 1*3, middlo toe and 
claw 1-45. 

A young male differs from the adult much in the samo points 
mentioned for the young of L. californicus, but tho crest is deep 
chestnut, and the crown of the head is washed with the same 
colour ; there are also traoes of the chestnut sides and flanks and 
the black pateh on the belly of the adult.

Adult male and fcmale. Top and sides of the head olive-brown, 
washed with rufous OD the crown ; a well-developed occipital crest of 
blackibh-brown, parallel-cdged feathers, tippcd with rufous; neck 
and mantle grey or olive-grey, each feather margined with reddish 
brown ; lowor back, rump, and npper tail-coverts olive-brown, 
margined and barred across the middle with black and buff; wing-
coverts, scapnlars, and onter secondaries olive-brown, baried and 
tipped with buff, and mostly, espceially the two latf er, 1 lotched with

and inner secondaiios brown, the latter barred on the onter 
web with buff; chin and throat white; ehest, sides of breast, 
belly, and flanks strongly barred with black ancl white, and fringed 
with reddish brown at the extrtmity; middle of breast and belly 
white, some of the feathers with a rounded or oval black spot in the 
micldle ; vent and under tail-coverts bnff, tho latter with heart-shaped

Immature birefo (in January) have the lores, superciliary stripes, 
and the greater part of the chin and throat black; many of the 
feathers of the mantle, scapnlars, aucl wing-coverts with buff shaftphipes, 
and the piimaries marked on the onter web and tipped 
with buff. 

A very young speeimen has the top of the head covered with 
dark chestnut down; the lores, forehead, and superciliary stripes 
and cheeks rufous buff; the chin, throat, and middle of the breast 
yellowish white; all the rest of the body is covered with feathers; 
the npper parfs are much like those of the adult, bot the mantle 
is blotched with black and every feather has a wide buff shaft-
stripe ; the fore part of the neck, ehest, and breast black, with white 
shaft-stripes, and the flank-feathers white, spotted on each web with 
black.

mottled bars or vermiculations of pale buff. Total length 8 inches,

5. Eupsychortys leylandi 
Ortyx leylandi, 
Moore, P. Z. S. 1859, p. 62 [Oinoa to Oomayagna, 
Honduras] ; Sehet,fySalvin, Ibis, lb59, p. 220 ; Taylor, Ibis, 1860, 

p. 312 [Comayagua, Honduras]; Boucard, P. Z'.S. 1878, p. 42

Eupsvchortyx 
leueofrenatus, Ellict, Ann. Lijc. iV. York, vii. p. 106, 
pl. 3 (18U0) [Honduras]. 
Colinus leylandi, O/wrrie, Auh, ix. p. 329 (1892) [San Jose, Costa 
llica]. 

Adult male. Most nearly allied to E. sonnini and E. parvicrisiatus, 
the ehest being vinaeeons, indistinctly vermiculated with 
dusky and very sparingly spotted, bnt easily to be distinguished 
Irom either by having the chin and throat black; the sides of the 
throat and superciliary stripes bufff, wider and nearly nnifornx 
in old birds, but narrower and each feather tipped with black in 
yoimger examples; in old birds, too, the base of the throat is bonnded 
by white feathers with black tips, in yotmger birds these are represented 
by dull rufous feathers edged with black; the npper 
parts are considerably darker than in either of the above-mentioned 
species, the black yermiculations and markings being mnch coarser. 
Total length 8'4 inches, wing 4*1, tail 2*4, tarsus 1*1, middle toe 
and claw 1*3. 

* The description and measurements are taken from the most richly-coloured 
Bogota speeimens, with the breast and belly mostly chestnut; in other speeimens 
which more nearly approach E. semnini m the coloration of these parts the 
general size is rather larger and the tarsua is 1*2. With limited material and 
labeis without exaet particulars, it is iinpossible to say what the cause of this 
Variation in size and colour may be, but the probability is that it is elimatic. 
t Very conspieuous in two birds from Nicaragua, much less so in two from 
Costa Eica; but, as another adult speeimen from Nicaragua is perfectly intermediate, 
I do not attach much importance to these difftrences, and believe 
they are due to age and not to locality.

PH A Sil NID JE. 

Touncjer wales have the black feathers of the throat with white 
shafts and middles. 

Äclult female. To be distinguished from the females of E. sonnini 
and E. parvicrutatus, which it greatly resembles, by having the 
ehest like that of the male, but more spotted ; the superciliary 
stripe wider and pure yellowish buff; the throat the same, with 
very slight black edges to the outer feathers ; and the upper parts 
with the black markings coarser.

Adult male. Lores, superciliary stiipes, chin, and throat Hack;

mottled with black; lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts grey

with chestnut; under tail-coverts rufous, tipped with whitish and 
with black eentres ; tail brownish grey, the middle feathers especially 
more or less mottled towards the tips with whitish brown. Total 

length 8-2 inches, wing 4-1, tail 2*3, tarsus 1-15, middle toe and 
claw 1-35.

Adult male. DifFers from all the previously deseribed species 
chiefly in having the superciliary stripes, chin, throat, ehest, breast,

with whitish grey, more clo&ely than in any other species oü the 
genus. Total length 7*8 inches, wing 4*1, tail 2*5, tarsus 1-1,

Immature males have the breast, belly, sides, and flanks much like 
those of the female, but more or less intermixed with tho white 
f eathers of the adult male aecording to age ; the scapulars and outer 
secondaries are barred with white. 

Adult female closely resembles tho female of E. cristatus, but the 
feathers of the crest are darker. Total length 7*5 inches, wing 4*1, 
tail 2*5, tarsus 1*1, middle toe and claw 1*25.

Adtdt male. Lores whitish, shading into pale buff on the superciliary 
stripes; forehead black ; feathers of the top of the head black, 
widely tipped with rufons chestnut; back and sides of neck mostly 
white, with a triangulär chestnut patch at the extremity, edged on 
the sides with black; mantle vinaeeous rufous, shading into grey 
towards the sides of the feathers, which are more or less distinctly 
barred with black ; lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts olive-
grey, finely mottled with dusky and buff; most of the feathers down 

.55. ORTYX. 
417 

the middle of the low er back blotched with black and mottled with 
rufous at the extremity, and the rump-feathers and uppcr tail-
coverts with a black subterminal shaft-spot; tho inner wing-covorts, 
scapulars, and outer secondaries rufous, shading into grey on the 
outer web, which is indistinctly barred with white ; a black subterminal 
blotch and black vermieulations towards the extremity, 
whieh together with the inner web is margined with buff; the 
rest of the wing-coverts rufous, irregularly barred with black on 
the edges; quills greyish brown, the inner secondaries edged and 
irregularly barred along the margin with rufous buff; a black 
band across the check from the gape to the ear-coverts, which are 
chestnut; chin and throat white, terminated by a wide black band 
which extends across the throat belween the ear-coverts ; upper 
ehest vinaeeous rufous like the mantle, shading into whitish buff 
or buff on the lower ehest and breast and into white on the belly, 
all these parts are somewhat irregularly barred with rather narrow 
wide-set black bands ; sides and nanks chestnut in the middle, and 
white irregularly barred with black along the margin, the last black 
bar on each side of the extremity is usually more or less crescent-
shaped, producing an ocellated appearance; imder tail-coverts pale 
rufous tipped with buff, each with a subterminal arrow-shaped 
black mark on the shaft; taü-feathers slate-grey, mottled towards 
the extremity with greyish. Total length 8*6 inches, wing 4*5, 

tail 2-Q, tarsus 1-2, middle toe and claw 1*45. 

Aclult female. DifTers chiefly from the male in having the throat 

bright buff; the black bands from the gape to tho ear-coverts and 

across the front of tho neck represented only by black tips to the 

featners; the black bands on the underparts are much less distinet 

and usually absent on the middle of the breast and belly. Total length 

8-6 inches, wing 4*5, tail 2*5, tarsus 1-2, middle toe and claw 1*4. 

A chick has the lores, forehead, and sides of the head covered with 

buff-coloured down, the top of the head with brownish rufous, and 

the ehin and throat 
wirb white; the ear-coverts brownish black; 

general colour of the upper parts browner than in the adult and all 

the feathers with pale shaft-stripes; the rest of the underparts 

brownish white, also with pale shafts and a whitish-buff: spot on the 

extremity of each feather. 

Höh. Eastern United States of North America ; ranging north to 

Massachusetts and Minnesota, west to Dakota and Indian Territory, 

Texas, and south to Georgia and other Gulf States. Also introduced 

into many of the West Indian Islands and various parts of the üld 

World.

Adult male. DifFers chiefly from the male of 0. virginianus in 
having the general tone of the plumage darker, the top of the head 
much blacker, and the black markin gs on the rest of the lipper 
parts coarser and more inarked; the buff edges of the outer 
secondaries and scapiüars much narrower; the ear-coverts black, 
and the band from the gäpe passing uninterruptedly across them 
round the base of the throat, where it usually widens ont considerably, 
often extending over the upper ehest and generally 
taking the place of the vinaeeons rufous which predominates in 

0. virginianus. The black bands on the rest of the underparts are 
much coarser and more strongly marked. Total length 8*6 inches, 
wing 4*3, tail 2*3, tarsus 1*2, middle toe and claw 1*35. 
OD. ORTYX. 
419 

Adult female. DifFers from the femalo of 0. virginianus in being 
generally darker and having the buff edging of tho outor secondaries 
and scapnlars rauch narrower ancl the black markings on tho 
breast and underparts much more strongly marked and equally 
developed on the feathers of the middle of the breast aud belly. 
Total length 8*6 inches, wing 4*3, tail 2-3, tarsus 1*15, middle toe 
and claw 1*3. 

The cliiclc in July resembles the chick of 0. virginianus described 
above. 

Quite young birds (both male and female) in August rosemble the 
above, but the top and sides of the head are oovered with greyish-
brown feathers, and on the mantle, wing-coverts, and sides of breast 
and belly the adult feathers begin to mako their appcarauce.

Ortyx virginiana texana, Sennett, Bull U.S. Qeol. Surv. iv. p. 53 
(1878) [Rio Grande, Texas]; Brown, Bull. Ntttt. Orn. C. vii. 

p. 41 (1882) [S.W. Texas]; Coues, Key N. Am. B. p. 591 (1884). 
Ädult male. Differs from 0. floridanus in having the upper 
parts much paler and greyer, and the vinaceous chestnut markings 
of the latter replaced by pale vinaceous. It resembles 0. virginianus 
in having the black band round the base of the throat 
narrower, and 0. floridanus in having the black bars on the 
ehest and breast coarser and more marked. Two speeimens, which 
apparently represent only an individua] variety, have a large black 
patch covering the chin and middle of the throat; but, otherwise, 
their plumage is perfectly similar to the above. Total length 
8*6 inches, wing 4*3, tail 2*4, tarsus 1*2, middle toe and claw 1*35. 

Adult female. Resembles the female of 0. floridanus, but the 
general colour of the upper parts is greyer and paler, and the 
vinaceous chestnut markings are replaced "by pale vinaceous. Total 
length 8*4 inches, wing 4*2, tail 2-2, tarsus 1*15, middle toe and 
claw 1*3.

3. Ortyx pectoralis.

Colinus pectoralis, Ridgw. Man. N. Am. B. p. 189 (1887). 
Adult male. General colour of the upper parts very similar to 
that of 0. te,vanus, but in the most adult example the top of the 

42iJ 
PUASIANIDJS. 

head is entirely black; otherwise the markings of the head, chin, 
and throat are very similar. The upper ehest is black, most of the 
feathors with a white bar across the basal half; the rest of the 
underparts are uniform pale nifous chestnut. Total length 7*7 inches, 
wing 4, tail 2*1, tarsus 1*1, middle toe and claw 1-25. 

In a specimen wliich appears to be a younger bird the black 
feathers of the ehest are devoid of white cross-bars, and the thighs 
and under tail-coverts are similar to those of the adult female. 

Ad idt female. Yery similar to the female of 0. texanus, but the 
general colour of the Upper parts is darker and browner and the 
black markings on the underparts are heavier. Total length 7'6 
inches, wing 4, tau 2*1, tarsus 1*1, middle toe and claw 1*25.

8. Ortyx castaneus. 
Ortyx castaneus, Gould, P. Z. S. 1842, p. 182 ; id. Monogr. Odontoph. 
pt. iii. pl. 3 (1850); Gray, List GallincB JBrit. Mus. p. 76 (1807); 
id. Hand-l. JB. ii. p. 273 (1870). 

Adult male. Differs chiefly from 0. cubanensis in having the top of 
the head, mantle, and general colour of the rest of the upper parts 
dark chestnut, the black markings being much reduced and fche buff 
edges to the scapulars and oute» secondaries strongly marked ; the 
chin and throat are entirely black, and the wide white superciliary 
stripe of 0. cubanensis is only represented by an indistinet white line. 
The ehest is dark chestnut like the mantle, and the middle feathers 
of the breast and belly are white barred witb black. Total length 
9 inches, wing 4*5, tail 2*4, tarsus 1*3, middle toe and claw 1*5. 

It has been suggested [Baird, Brew., and Bidgw. N". Am. B. iii. 

p. 468 (1874)] that this is " a somewhat melanistic plumage (of 
0. virginianus) occasionally seen in speeimens from Iowa, Illinois, 
&c?" but this seems to me exceedingly improbable. In the 
Museum colleetion there are varieties of 0. texanus which have the 
chin and middle of the throat black, but otherwise their plumage 
56. CYKT0NYX. 
425 
does not differ from the ordinary type; still, it may be a similar 
case to Ferclix montana, which is no doubt only a strongly-marked 
rufous variety of F. perdix.

N. Amer. B. iii. p. 492 (1874) ; Coues, B. N.-West, p. 443 (1874); 
Stephens, Bull, Nutt. Orn. C. iii. p. 94 (1878) ; Bremst Bull. Nutt 
Om. C. vüi. p. 35 (1883) [Oliiricalnia Mts., Arizona] ; Coues, Key

Cyrtonyx uiontezumae, Stejn. Auk, ii. p. 46 (1885) ; Scott, Auk, iii. 
p. 389 (1886) [Arizona] ;*A 0. ü. Check-list, p. 170 (1886); Bidyw. 
Man. N. Am. B. p. 194 (1887); Lloyd, Auk, iv. p. 187 (1887) 
[W. Texas]; Beckham, P. U.S. Not. Mus. x. pp. 637, 656 (1887) 
[S.W. Texas] ; Mearns, Auk, vii. p. 52 (1890) [Arizona]; Ben-

Adult male. Pcathers of the top of the head black, barred and 
tipped with sandy brown and with buff shaft-stripes: occipital 
crest reddish buff; forehead, sides of the bead and tbroat, and fore 
part of neck with an elegant black-and-white pattern, tbe black 
rnarkings being arranged as follows :—the space down the middle of 
the forehead, a band bordering tbe top of the head and passing in 
front of the eye across the lores and cheeks and ending in a wide 
triangulär bluish-black patch; ear-coverts, chin, middle of the 
throat, and a band bordering the base of the neck; a narrow line of 
Hackfeathers also surrounds the eye; mantle, scapulars, lower back, 
and rump are pale rufous thickly barred with black; each feather, 
except those of the lower back, with a wide buff: black-bordered 
shaft-stripe* the wing- and upper tail-coverts are greyer, and the 
black markings take the form of a row of spots on each web ; primaries, 
priniary-coverts, and secondaries dark brown, wifch the outer 
web barred with white, the bars on the inner secondaries being 
washed with pale rufous and extending across the outer half of the 
inner webs; middle of the ehest and breast dark chestnut; sides and 
flanks dark grey, with a row of three or four paired spots on each 
web; rest of underparts deep black; tail-feathers very similar to 
the upper tail-coverts. Total length &2 inches, wing 5*1, tail 2'2, 
tarsus l-l, middle toe and claw 1-4. 

An immature male has the sides of the head and throat like those 
of the female, with only a few black feathers beginning to appear 
on the chin and ear-coverts. 

Adult female. Feathers of the top of the head black barred with 
brown or ruf ous-buff and with pale shafts ; mantle, scapulars, lower 
back, rump, and Upper tail-coverts pale reddish or sandy brown, 
barred and blotched with black; all the feathers, except those of 
the lower back and rump, with broad buff black-edged shaft-stripes;

palevinaeeous, shading into buff on the middle of the breast and 
belly, as well as on the under tail-coverts, and spotted and marked

3. Cyrtonyx ocellatus. 
/ 

Ortyx ocellatus, Goutd, P. Z. S. 18:16, p. 75. 
Cyrtonyx ocellatus, Gould, Mon. Odontoph. pt. ii. pl. 8 (1846); Sclat. 


$ Sa'lvin, Ibis, 1859, p. 226 ; Gray, Lisi Gallina Brit. Mus. p. 74 

(1867); id. Hand-l B. ii. p. 272 (1870) [Guatemala]; Ridgw. Man. 

N. Am. B. p. 194 (1887). 
Cyrtonyx sumichrasti, Lawr. Ann. N. T. Sei. i. p. 51 (1877) [Santa 
"Efigenia, Tekuantepec]. 

Adult male. Differs from tue male of G. scdlcei in having many of 
the black markings on the upper parts in the form of round black 
spots; the middle of the ehest and breast pale buff tipped with 
ruf ous, and the sides with buff; feathers of the flanks chestnut, 
somewhat irregularly barred with black, shading into grey towards 
the margins. Total length 8*3 inches, wing 5*3, tail 2*2, tarsus 1*25, 
middle toe and claw 1*5. 

The young male has none of the black pattern on the chin, 
throat, and sides of the head, these parts being nearly white, while 
the chestnut on the breast, belly, and flanks is much paler; the 
feathers of the Upper parts are mostly black barred with ruf ous buff, 
and with wide buff or rufous-buff shaft-stripes edged on either side 
with black. 

Adult female. Scarcely differs from the female of 0. montezumee, 
but the general ground-colour of the Upper parts is black, finely 
barred with ruf ous and mottled towards the tips of the feathers 
with sandy, and the outer wing-coverts are more distinctly barred 
with black. Total length 8 inches, wing 5, tail 2*2, tarsus 1*25, 
middle toe and claw 1*45. 

An immature female has most of the underparts pale rufous buff 
with small spots of black, the adult vinaeeous feathers being 
partially represented on the sides and flanks. 

Bah. Central America; Tehuantepec and Guatemala.

57. DACTYIORTYX. 
Sexes different. Occipital feathers lengthened into a short er est. 
Ist primary equals the 8th • 4th longest. 
Tail composed of 12 feathers, f- of the length of the wing. 
Tarsus mueh shorter than the middle toe and claw. 
Claws very long, much like those of Arboricola. 
Bill moderately stout, not so deep as that of Odontophorus. 


Range. Central America ; Southern Mexico, Yucatan, Guatemala, 
and San Salvador. 

1. Dactylortyx thoracicus. 
Ortyx thoracicus, Gambel, P. Ac. Philad. iv. p. 77 (1848) [Jalapa, 
Mexico]. 
Perdix lineolata, Licht, in Mus. Berlin,fide Gould, Monogr. Odontoph. 
p t iii. text to pl. 32 (1850). 
Ortyx lineolatus, Natterer, MS., ßde Gould, Monogr. Odontoph. 
pt. iii. text to pl. 32 (1850). 
Odontophorus lineolatus, Gould, Monogr. Odontoph. pt. iii. pl. 32 
(1850); Gray, List Gallium Brit Mus. p. 73 (18G7) : id. Eand-L 

B. ii. p. 272 (1870). 
Strophiortyx lineolatus, Bonap. C. B. xlii. p. 883 (1856). 
Odontophorus thoracicus, Sclat. $• Salvin, Lbis, 1860, p. 276 [Volcan 
de Fuego]. 

Adult male. Top of the head brown, more or less washed with 
rusty, the feathers down the middle with pale shaft-stripes ; feathers 
of the nape black mixed with brown and with wide buff centres; 
mantle almost similar to the top of the head; lower back, rump, 
and upper tail-coverts pale olive-brown, some of the feathers, especially 
the upper tail-coverts, indistinctly blotched with black near 
the extremity of the shaft* scapulars, wing-coverts, and outer 
seeondaries largely mixed with black towards the extremities of the 
inner or both webs, the rest of the feathers fmely mottled with 
sandy brown, rufous, and black, shading into greyish on the outer 
webs ; all the feathers have pale bufF shaft-stripes, and the longer 
scapulars and outer seeondaries have the outer web margined with 
golden, buff* quills brown, mottled with bufT on the outer web; 
superciliary stripe, cheeks, chin, and throat reddish chestnut, eareoverts 
dark brown, and a black patch of feathers on the side of the 
throat: ehest and rest of underparts grey, faintly washed with 
reddish brown, and with white shaft-stripes ; thighs like the tipper 
tail-coverts; middle of belly and vent white; under tail-coverts 
buff, irreguiarly barred with black; tail blackish brown, with 
irregulär mottled bars of bufT. Total length 9 mehes, wing 5*3, 
tail 2*2, tarsus 1*3, middle toe and claw 1*7. 

A nearly mature male has the middle of the chin and throat white 
and some of the feathers of the ehest and breast spotted with black. 

Adult fernale has the upper parts very similar to those of the 
male, but the superciliary stripes and cheeks are greyish white; the 
chin and throat white, and the ehest and breast dull brick-red, with

pale shafts. Total length 8'5 inches, wing 5-3, tail 2, tarsus 1-3, 
midclle toe and claw 1*7. 


Immature females have the ehest and sides of the breast spotted 
with black ; and in still younger birds the sides and flanks are also 
thickly spotted with. black.

Adult male and female. General colour of the top of the head 
deep ehestnut, with irregulär marks and dots of paler rufous and 
black; nape and mantle grey, finely mottled with black; lower 
hack and rump sandy rufous-brown, shading into darker rufous on 
the upper tail-coverts and all dotted with. black, put in very old 
speeimens these black dots are almost obsolete; wing-coverts. 
scapulars, and outer secondaries rufous, blotched, especially towards 
the tip of the inner weh, with black and all irregularly marked and 
mottled with the same colour—some of the scapulars have an 
irregulär dirty white or grey band on the outer web next the shaft 
and the longer scapulars and outer secondaries have the inner web 
edged with buff • quills dark brown, irregularly barred on the outer 
web with buff; chin, cheeks, and sides of throat dark ehestnut; 
ear-coverts buff; middle of throat and fore part of neck greyish; 
ehest and rest of underparts paler or darker rufous-buff* more or 
less barred and marked with dusky on the ehest, sides, and flanks*; 


tail dark rufous-brown with indistinet bars. Bill bluish black; iris 
hazel; naked skin round the eye vermilion: legs and toes bluish 
lead. 

Male. Total length 11 *5 inches, wing 5*9, tail 2-8, tarsus 1*6, 
middle toe and elaw 1*8. 
Female. Total length 10 inches, wing 5*4, tail 2*3, tarsus 1*5, 
middle toe and claw 1*6. 
Hab. British Guiana and Lower Amazons. 

* In some speeimens these barrings are much heavier and more marked 
than in others ; but, apparently, this is not due to age, and in what appears to 
be a perfectly adult male speeimen from Camaeusa, British Guiana, the whole 
of the underparts are barred with black, and in general appearance the bird 
closely resembles speeimens of 0. marmoratus, wkich appear to ns to be barely 
aubspeeifieally distmet, but more material is necessary to deeide this question.

marmoratus, Sclat. $ Salvin, P.Z.S. 1864, p. 371

Adult male and female. TMs form appears to intergrade with 

O. guianensis, but rnore material is reqiired before the question can 
be satisfactorily settled. The charaofcers by which the present subspecies 
is apparentfy distinguished are that the sides of the head and 
chin are rust-red, the general colour of the underparts darker and 
almost invariably barred with black and buff, thoagh amongst the 
series before us we find a speeimen from Lion Hill, Panama, which 
so closely approaches typioal 0. gulamnsis that it cannot be distinguished. 
Nb doubt the present foon is barely subspeeifieally distinet 
from Guiana birds, and is absolutely identical with 0. pachyrhyneJius, 
Tschudi, from Peru. Total length 11 inches, wing Q'2, tail 3, 
tarsus 1*7, middle toe and claw 1*8 *. 
An immature bird differs chiefly in having the crest and top of 
the head uniform dark reddish brown, very faintly vermiculated 
with dusky; the mantle grey, slightly washed with sandy brown 
and with very faint or almost imperceptible dusky vermiculations ; 
the dull reddish-brown middles of the outer secondaries sharply 
defined from the black marginal lin.es and almost devoid of black 
vermiculations; the inner weos of the quills, especially the outer 

* Speeimens from Panama are considerably smaller than those from the U.S. 
of Colombia. A Panama male has the wing 5'5, tail 2*7. The marked difference 
in size between the sexes observed in 0. guianensis does not apparently 
obtain in tne present form, judging from Panama speeimens only, as none of 
our speeim^as from the U.S. of Colombia are marked as females.

2. Odontophoriis capueira. 

Perdix capueira, Spix, Av. Sp. Nov. ii. p. 59, pl. 76 A (1825) [Eio 

de Janeiro]. 

Perdix dentatus, Max. (nee Temm.) Beitr. Hat. Breis, iv. p. 486 (1832). 

Ortyx capistrata, Jard. 8f Selb. Hl. Orn. i. text to pl. 38. 

Odontophorus capistratus, Gray, List of B. pt. iii. Gatt, p. 43 (1844). 

Odontophorus dentatus, Gould (nee Teni7n.)1 Monogr. Odontoph. pt. ii. 

pl.26 (1846); Burmeister, Uebers. Thiere Bras. iii. p. 333 (1856); 

Gray, List Gallin® Brit. Mus. p. 71 (1867) ; id. Hanä-l. B. ii. 

p. 271 (1870); v. Feh. Orn. Bras. p. 289 (1870); Reinhardt, Vid. 
Medd. Kfibenh. 1870, p. 52. 
Adult male. Upper parts very similar to those of 0, guianensis, 
but the mantle is brown or rufous brown blotched with black and 
with pale buff shafts ; the markings on the outer webs of the prirnaries 
are white; and the chin, throat, and underparts are dark 
grey. Bill blaek; legs and feet greyish black. Total length 
11 inehes, wing 6*2, tail 3*1, tarsns 1*8, middle toe and claw 1*05. 

Adult female. Similar in plumage to themale, but rather smaller. 

Immature birds have the pale shaft-streaks on the mantle wider 
and more conspieuous than the adults • the black shaft-spots, too, 
on the lower back and rump are mueh coarser, and the grey underparts 
are washed with reddish brown. 

In quite young speeimens the shaft-stripes of the mantle are still 
wider ; the lower back, rump, and upper tail-coverts are dewid of 
black shaft-spots; the ehest and underparts are rufous brown, 
marked and barred with black and buff. The upper mandible 
is orange; the lower yellowish. 

Hab. Eastern South America, ranging north to Bahia, west to 
Goyaz, and south fo liio Grande del Sur.
