5. Odontophorus hyperythrus. 
Odontophorus kyperytlirus, Gould, P. Z. S.1857, p. 223 [Santa Fe de 
Bogota] ; Salat $• Salvin, P. Z. S. 1879, p. 545 [Santa Elena, 
Antioquia]. 

Odontophorus hypospodius, Sclat 8>* Salvin, Nomencl. Av. Neotrop. 

p. 163 (1873) [Antioquia]. 
Adult male, General colour above olive-brown, slightly washed 

•with rufous and finely vermiculated with black ; the scapulars and 
outer secondaries are marked very similarly to those of the other 
species, and the rest of the quills are like those of 0. Imcolmmus; 
lores, superciliary stripes, chin, throat, and underparts deep rust-
red, rather paler towards the middle of the breast and belly; a 
small patch of white on the ear-coverts ; thethighs, vent, andunder 
tail-coverts rufous brown vermiculated with black, and the latter 
edged with rufous buff. Total length 11 inches, wing 5*9, tail 2*4, 
tarsus 2, middle toe and claw 2*15. 
Adult female. Differs from the male in having the breast and rest 

of underparts dark grey, shading into blackish grey on the flanks. 

Total length 10 4 inches, wing 5-6, tail 2*2, tarsus 1*8, middle toe 

and claw 1*9. 

Less mature males have the feathers of the wing-coverts aud 
scapulars spotted with buff at the extremity, some of the fe%thers 
of the mantle blotched or marked with black, and the ridge of the 
culmen and the tip of the beak orange-red. 

Less mature females have the grey feathers of the breast and belly 
mixed here and there with rust-colour, 

It would thus appear that the young females in their hrst 
plumage resemble the male parent and have the whole of the 
underparts rusk-coloured, and that the grey plumage of the adult 
female gradually takes the place of the rufous,' for in the specimens 
before us all the new feathers which are heing moulted-in 
are grey, while some of the old rufous feathers appear to be changmg 
to grey without a moult,

6. Odoutophorus speciosus. 
Odontophorus speciosus, 
Tschudi, Wiegm. Arclu 1843, p. 387; id. 
Fauna Pentana, p. 281, pl. xxxiii. (1844-46) [Clianchonaayo, 
Peru]; Gould, Monoffr.OäontopJi. pt. iii. pl. 25 (1850)* Gray, List 
Gallince Brit. Mus. p. 71 (1867); id. Hand-l B. iL p. 271 (1870) ; 
Tacz. P. Z. 8. 1874, p. 658 [near Chilpes, Central Peru] ; id. Orn. 
Perou, iii. p. 288 (1886). 

Adiät male. Top of the head dark reddish brown, faintly vermiculated 
with black; upper parts similar but paler, the scapulars and 
outer secoiidaries with the usual black patehes near the extremity ; 
most of the feathers of the back of the neck and mantle with whitish-
buff shaft-sfcripes; wing-coverts and scapulars mostly with a triangulär 
buff spot at the extremity• most of the feathers of the 
lower back with a black shaft-spot near the extremity; quills 
brown, the inner primaries slightly and the secondaries largely 
mottled with buff on the outer web ; well-marked black and white 
superciliary stripes passing backwards above the ear-eoverts down 
the sides of the neck; chin, throat, and sides of face black ; neck, 
ehest, and rest of underparts bright rust-red; thighs and under 
tail-coverts brownish, with mottled bars of black and rufous-bufl 
tips. Total length 10 inches, wing 5*7, tail 2*2, tarsus 1*8, middle 
toe and claw 1*9. 

This species is nearly allied to 0. hyjjerythrus^ but is easily 
distinguished by the black-and-white eyebrow and black chin and 
throat. 

A younger male differs from the adult in having the black-andwhite 
superciliary stripe much reduced in width; mantle with 
scarcely any trace of pale shaft-stripes; the inner webs of the 
longer scapulars and outer secondaries widely edged towards the 
extremity with rieh rufous buff; chin, throat, and sides of the face 
chestnut with dusky margins. 

Adult female. Differs chiefly from the adult male in having only 
the ehest rufous chestnut, the breast and belly being dark grey with 
a few of the feathers on the sides tinged with rufous. Total length 
9*5 inches, wing 5*3, tail 2*1, tarsus 1'8, middle toe and claw 1*9»

chin and sides ; and the upper ?nd lower mandibles are orange-red. 

A quite young lircl has the rust-red hind crest well developed ; 

and apparently the young resemble the male and differ from the 

female parent in this respect, but the want of properly sexed female 

speeimens prevents my being quite certain of this. 

Specimens from Dota, Costa Bica, and Chiriqui, where the ranges 

of the present species and 0. veraguensis overlap, are somewhat 

intermediate, having the underparis more or less strongly washed 

with rufous.

Adulu Top of the head and nape rusty brown; feathers of the 
mantle dark grey, edged with reddish brown; lower back and rump 
buff, thickly elouded and vermiculated with grey, and the median 
feathers with black shaft-stripes; scapulars and outer seoondaries

quills brown; secondaries blotched with rufous buff on the outer 
webs; lores, forehead, superciliary stripes, cheeks, ear-coverts,

and sides o£ the throat bright rust-red ; middle of ehin and throat

indistinctly clouded with dusky and barred with black; under tail-
coverts buff, barred with black; tail finely mottled with rufous 
and black. Total length 7*5 inches, wing 4-9, tail 1-8, tarsus 1*4, 
middle toe and claw 1*15. 

In the type speeimen the rump and upper tail-coverts are washed 
with vinaeeous grey, and in both this and a second speeimen the rufous 
and buff markings on the wing-coverts and seapulars are more 
strongly marked than in the bird described above, while a f ew of the 
feathers of the nape have white shaft-stripes or spots. These 
characters probably indicate that the birds are not yet in the most 

adult plumage. 
Hab. Yeragua and Panama.

2. Ehynchortyx cinetns. 
Odontophoms cinetus, Salvin, Ibis, 1876, p. 379 [Veragua]; Mowleyi 
Orn. Mise. iii. p. 59, pl. lxxxvi. (1878). 

Adult. Top of the head, mantle, ehest, and sides of breast deep 
rufous; a white band from the lores to the eye, and continued 
behind the eye aboye the ear-coverts and along the sides of the 
neck ; wings very similar to those of IL sjiodiostethus ; in the type 
the lower back and rump are dark grey, finely mottled with whitish; 
but in a second example these parts are dull vinaeeous, very slightly 
freckled with black, while a line of feathers down the centre have 
deep black shaft-stripes (these differences are due probably to either 
age or sex, but it is impossible to say which); upper tail-coverts 
reddish brown, vermiculated with black; superciliary stripe and 
sides of head dull olive-brown; ear-coverts blackish chestnut, chin 
and throat white; breast, belly, and flanks white, rather widely 
barred with black, except down the middle of the body; under tail-
coverts buff, barred with black; tail-feathers reddish brown, 
vermiculated with black. Total length 7*5 inches, wing 4*6, 
tail 1*7, tarsus 1*3, middle toe and claw 1*15.

The hallux is on the same level as the other toes, and its basal 
phalanx as long as that of the third toe. 

Family I. MEGAPODIID^E. 

Oil-gland nude. 

Eggs deposited in the sand or in a monnd raised by one or more 
pairs of birds; young hatched fully feathered, without the Intervention 
of the parent bird, and able to fiy almost from birth.

* Doubtful species :— 
1. MEGAPODIUS, sp. 
Thero are two quite young specimens in the British Museum, which are said 
to have beeil obtained on Lord Howe's Island. They differ from all other young 
of a similar age which I have examined in haying the back and wings barred with 
öuffaud blaek, as well as by the paler eolour of the underparts. They closely 
resemble the figureof the young o£M. laperousii ghen by Finsch in the J. Mus. 
Gtodeifroy, viii. pl. v. fig. 3 (1875). So far as I am aware, no species of 
Megapode is known to occur on this island, and the probability is that these 
young birds represent an unknown species; but this eannot be decided tili adult 
specimens are obtained.

Adult male and female *. Top of the head reddish or olive-
brown; sides of the crown from. behind the eyes, the oeeiput, and 

* 
Some speeimens, as has been already remarked by Twecddale (Ann Mag. 
N. H. (4) xiv. p. 163, 1874), have a curious tendency to lose the feathers on the 
crown and assume a naked callosity. In a female adult from JSIangcowry I. 
the crown is entirely naked and covered witk afchiok black-looking skin, which 
appears almosfc of the nature of ascab; the same peculiarity is equally developed 
in an immature male from Oamorta; while in three other speeimens (both adult 
and immature) the crown is parbially clenuded and the skin is of the saine black 
colour. In all the other speeimens the skin of the top of the head is red. 
I am of opinion that the naked head in the above-mentioned speeimens is 
abnormal, and possibly caused by disease.

it is probably founded on an immature specimen.

sp., Vorderm. Nat. Tijdsehr. Ned. Ind. xlix. p. 71 
(1889) [Kangeang Arcli.]. 

After carefnlly examining a large series of speeimens from 
Lombock, Floris, Hei, and Aroe Islands, also New Guinea and 
Atistralia, I have arrived at tbe same conclusions as Oustalet, 
who was the first to recognize that the birds inhabiting these 
islands were not spoeifieally distinet from one another. If we 
compare tbe more lightly coloured birds from Floris and Lombock 
(AL gouldii, Gray) witb the much darker speeimens from Western 
Australia (M. tumidvs, Gould), the differenee between the two is no 
doubt considerable both in colonr and size, though the latter is of 
little or no importanee, bat the Lombock birds cannot be distinguished 
from soine speeimens from Kei and Aroe Islands, while 
other speeimens from the latter localities are undistinguishable from 
New Guinea and Australian examples. It is therefore impossible 

456 
MEGAP0DIIM2. 

to recognize more than one'species, as the chain of intermediate 
forms botween the extreme types is eomplete. 

Adidt male and fernab. Top of the heacl with a füll occipital 
crest of brown feathors; back of the neck and mantle grey, shading 
into rufescent olive-brown on the middle of the back and wings; 
lower back, rump, and Upper tail-coverts daik chestnut; tail 
blackish chestnut; chin, throat, and underparts smoky grey ; sides, 
Üanks, thighs, and inider tail-coverts mostly dull chestnut. Bill 
rcddish brown, with yellow edges ; iris dark brown; legs and feet 
bright orange; toes dark redclish brown. 

(Adult from Floris.) Total length 14 inehes, wing 8*8, tail 3*6, 
tarsus 2-55. 
( $ adult fVom Kei Islands.) Total length 14 inehes, wing 8*7, 
tail 3*5, tarsus 2*65. 
((5 adult from Aroe Islands.) Total length 15 inehes, wing 9, 
tail 3*5, tarsus 2'ß5. 
( $ adult from Dorey, New Guinea.) Total length 15*5 inehes, 
wing 9-4, tail 3*9, tarsus 2-9. 
(Adult from Port Molle.) Total length 16 inehes, wing 10*2, 
tail 4-2, tarsus 2*9. 
(c? adult from Cairncross Island.) Total length 10*8 inehes, 
wing 10*2, tail 4*1, tarsus 3. 

Immature birds are easily recognized by their sharp-pointed 
outer primaries, and even in speeimens in which the ehest appears 
to be uniform grey there are almost always a few pale rufous 
feathers of the first plumage hidden beneath the grey plumage of the 
adult. 

In quite young speeimens the chin and throat are bufT, shadirg 
into grey on the neck, and into pale rufous-brown on the rest of 
the underparts. 

Mab. Ranging from the Kangeang Arehipelago in the west, through 
Lombock, Moris, Sumba, Eanda, Kei, Aroe, Balawatti, Western 
and Southern New Guinea, and the Islands of Torres Straits to 
North-east Australia.

Adult male andfcmale. General colour black; feathers of foreliead 
extend to the base of the eulmen, those on the oeeiput rather 
elongate and forming a shorfc füll crest: top of the head, mantle, 
and upper back washed with grey; wings, Jower back, rump, and 
upper tail-coverts with a brownisk and sometimes an olive-farown 
tinge; feathers on the chin, throat, and rest of the unrlerparts 
black, washed with grey like the mantle, shading into brownisk 
black on the belly and thighs. Xaked skin on the sicles of the 
head and neck dull red; bill dusky horn-colour, paler towards the 
extremity; iris chestnut; legs and fect black. Total length 15 
inches, wing 8-7-9, tail 3-3*3, tarsus 2*7-3. 

Immature hirds resemble the adult, bnt may be easily recognized 
by their smaller size, pointed outer primaries, and by the brownishbnff 
feathers still remainiug among the dark greyish-black plumagc 
of the underparts, also by having some of the secondaries edged with 
rufous on the outer web.

Talegafla 
cuvieri, Less. Man. d'Orn. ii. p. 186 (1828) ; id. TraitS 
d'Orn. p. 526 (1831); Sclat. Joum. P. Zinn. Soe. ii. p. 168 
(1858); Wallaee, P. Z. S. 1862, p. 165; Rotenb. J. f. 0. 1864, 

p. 135 [part]. 
Tallogalla cuvieri, Rosenb. Nat. Tijdschr. Ned. Ind. xxv. p. 252 
(1863) [part.]. 
Tallegallus cuvieri, Schi. Mus. Pays-Ba$} viii. p. 80 (1880) [part.]. 

Adult male and female. General colour of the plumage black; 
head and back of the neck thinly covered with narrow (almost hairlike) 
feathers, which are recumbent on the crown; chin and throat 
thinly covered with brownish-white or dirty-white feathers : iris 
yellow or yellowish red ; bill orange-red (yellow in dried speeimeus); 
naked skin on the sides of the head and throat reddish brown; legs 
and feet orange or yellow. Total length 20 21 inches, wing 10*8, 
tail 6-3, tarsns 3-3-3-5. 

In a younger examjole the back and sides of the neck are raostly 
dark chestnut; the outer primaries extreraely pointed; some of 
the secondaries marked with rufous butf along the margin of 
the outer web; and most of the wing-coverts and the feathers 
of the mantle indistinctly edged with dull rufous; the upper 
mandible is dusky, especially towards the base, and the top of 
the head, chin, and throat more thickly covered with feathers than 
in the adult. 

In a still younger ecsnrrvph the top of the head is mostly covered 
with brownish-coloured downy feathers ; while on the Shoulders 
and the middle of the neck and ehest patches of the reddish-brown 
feathers of the first plumage aro still intermixed with the dark 
plumage of the adult. 

Hab. Western New Guinea, Salawatti, Mysol, Gilolo.

1. Aepypodius bruijni. 
Talegallus bruijnii, Oustal C. R. xe. p. 906 (1880) [Waigiou"); id. 
Guide du Naturaliste, no^. 9 & 10, p. 192 (1880); id. Bull. Assoc. 
Sei. Fr. (2) i. p. 178 (1880); id. Le Nat. no. 41, p. 323 (1880) ; 
Reickenmo # Schal J.f. 0. 1881, p. 72. 

Tallegallus bruijnii, Schi. Mus. Pays-Bas, viii. p. 82 (1880). 
Aepypodiusbruijnii,Oustal. Le Nat. no.41 p. 328 (18ö0); Sulvad. Ann. 
Mus. Civ. Genov. xviii. p. 8 (1882); id. Orn. Pap. iii. p. 253 (1882). 
Talegallus (Aepvpodius) bruijnii, Oustal. Ann. Sei. Nat. xi. p. 38, 
figs. 38 [adult], 34 [juv.] (1881). 

Adult. General colour above brownish black, darker on the 
mantle and upper back, browner on the lower back, and dark 
chestnut on the rump and upper tail-coverts : ehest and upper 
breast mostly chestnut, shading into dirty grey on the rest of the 
underparts, sorne of the feathers of the lower breast and belly being 
also washed with chestnut. Head and neck almost entirely naked, 
with the exception of a few hair-like feathers, which are most 
numerous along the superciliary stripe and on the nape. An 
elongate fleshy crest commences on the forehead at the base of the 
eulmen, elevated in front and spread out over the crown of the head 
to the nape, the whole being covered with close-set horny papilli; 
on either side of the nape there arises a large elongate wattle placed 
at right angles to the neck, and from the basal part of the fore neck 
there hangs down over the chest a Single long subeylindrical wattle : 
the colour of these wattles as well as the naked skin on the head 
and neck appears to have been red or orange; bin and feet dusky; 
iris black. Total length 9 inches, wing 11*5, tail 5*7, tarsus 4*2. 

(Brit. Mus.) 
Total length 18*5 inches, wing 12*4, tail 6-4, tarsus 3*8. {Omialet.)

2. Aepypodius arfaManus. 
Talegallus arfakianus *, Sakad. Ann. Mus. Civ. Genov. ix. pp. 333, 
334 (1877) [chicks from Arfak Mts.l: Oustal Ann. Sei. Nat. xi. 

p. 53(1881). 
* I hare allowecl this name to stand though I think the evidence that 
Talegallus arfakianub, Salvad., is the young of Aepypodius pyrrhopygius is by 
no means conclusive. No doubt the rounded nasal opening is suffioient to 
prove that these young birds really belong to the genus Aepypodius, and not to 
Talegallus ; but I am not prepared to consider them identical with A. pyrrhopygius 
from the evidence before me. The system of giving names to very young 
birds is most objeotionable, and such names really ought not to be retained, 
being only one degree better than names founded on eggs

Adult. General colour of the upper parts black, tinged with 
brown on the wings; rump and tipper tail-coverts dark ckestnut, 
underparts browner. Head and neck almost naked with ihe 
exception of the nape and the back of the head, which are thickly 
covered with black feathers ; top of the head sparingly covered with 
hair-like black feathers ; a fleshy crest from the base of the eulmen 
to the middle of the crown; an elongated wattle from the base of the 
fore neck (but the lateral wattles on the sides of the neck, so conspieuous 
in A. bruijni. are absent). Naked skin on the sides of the 
head and the wattlcs are apparently yellowibh; feet and bill dusky. 
Total length 17'5 inches, wing 10*5, tail 55 , tarsns 3*6. 

In a younger speeimen the chin and throat are covered with 
yellowish-white downy feathers.

Mountains.

Type.

Head naked, covered with a large round occipital casque; a 
rounded tubercle behind each nostril; neck, chin, and throat thinly 
covered with hair-like feathers. 
Nostril a rather large rounded oval. 
Tail composed of 18 feathers, 3rd pair being considerably longer 
than the middle pair, giving the tau a CO-shaped appearance when 
expanded. 
Upper tail-coverts much shorter than the tail-feathers. 
Ist primary much shorter than the 2nd, which is about equal to the 
lOth; 6th slightly the longest. 
Tarsi and feet rather long, the fore part of the tarsus reticulated 
with small hexagonal scales, 
Range. North Celebes and the Sanghir Islands.

Adult male and female. Head and neck naked with the exception 
of a few scattered hair-like feathers; top of the head covered with 
a large rounded casqne; plumage of the upper parts, ehest, fianks, 
thighs, and under tail-coverts daik brown, inclining to black on the 
tail, which is very slightly glossed with dark green ; breast and belly 
beautiful salnion-pink. Casque black ; bill at the base of the upper 
mandible reddish brown, the under mandible and middle of the 
npper mandible black, point of bill yellowish; skin of the neck 
blackish ; round the eyes of a fleshy yellowish colour; legs bluish 
black: feet and claws yellowish. Total length 22 inches, wing 11 11-
8, tail 5-7-6, tarsus 3*5. 

In a younger eccample with the casque less developed, the neck is 
covered with brown and the chin and throat with white downy 
feathers 

In a still younger eocamph the casque is entirely absent, and the 
top of the head is covered with brown feathers mixed on the side 

with white.

Peathers of the crest ourled forward. 
Base of the oulmen with or without a swollen knob. 
Base of the lower mandible with or without wattles. 
Tail composed of 12 feathers. 
Tarsus longer than the tuiddle toe and claw.

Adiät male. Plumage black glossed with dark green ; belly, 
nnder tail-coverts, and tips of the tail-feathers white; no wattle on 
the base of the eulmen, which is bright yellow * tip of the eulmen 
blackish hörn; lores and the space round the eye naked and 
black; legs and feet pale pink. Total length 30*5 inches, wing 
14*3, tail 13*6, tarsus 4. 

Aclult fema le. Crest white, tip and base of each feather black ; 
neck black; rest of Upper parts black, with narrow white crossbars, 
widest on the wing-coverts and quills; lower neck black, 
barred with buff; upper ehest and, in some speeimens, the sides of 
the breast buff, barred with black; the rest of the underparts pale 
rufous buff, palest on the belly and under tail-coverts; most speeimens 
have the tail black, barred with white, but in what appears to 
be the most mature speciraen the white bars are wanting and the 
whole of the barring on the upper parts is very narrow; it therefore 
seems probable that the barring decreases with age. Total 
length 29 inches, wing 13*2, tail 12*5, tarsus 3*8. 

In what appears to be the hast mature female the white bars on 
the upper parts and tail are very distinctly wider than in the other 
speeimens. 

Hab. South America, ranging north to Para, south to Paraguay, 
and east to Bolivia.

3. Crax pinima. 
Crax pinima, Natterer, MS., v. Pelz. Orn. Präs. pp. 287, 341 (1870) 
[District of Para]; Gray, Hand-L B. ii. p. 253 (1870;; Sclat. fy 
Sabin, P. Z. S. 1870, p. 518. 

Crax incommoda *, Sclat. P. Z. S. 1872, p. 690; id. Trans. Z. S. ix. 

p. 281, pl. xlix. (1875), x. p. 544, pl. xciii. (1879). 
Adult male. At present unknown. 

Adult female. Differs chiefly from the female of C. fasciolata in 
having the whole of the breast, sicles, and thighs black, narrowly 
barred with whitish buff, the belly whitish butf, and the tail-feathers 
uniform black, thotigh the middle pair are irregularly marked with 
white in a younger example. I have little doubt that the three 
speeimens before me all belong to one and the same species, but 
they ditTer considerably one from another in plumage, though the 
differences are probably due to age. In the type the feathers of 
the erest are black, with a narrow white band across the middle 
third; the primaries are black, irregularly and narrowly barred with 
white on both webs, and the fore part of the neck and ehest are 

uniform black. 
In a second and apparently less mature speeimen there are two 
white bands across the first and second third of each of the crest-
feathers; the primaries are equally barred with rufous buff and 
black ; the fore part of the neck is barred with white, and the ehest 
shows traces of the same colour; while the lower parts of the breast 
are bufT, barred with "black, and the middle tail-feathers are narrowly 
and irregularly barred with white. 
In the third examjde, whiehJived for more than four years in the 
Zoological Soeiety's Gardens, either the natural changes in plumage 
have not taken place in confmement, or the speeimen represents a 
distinet species; the feathers of the crest resemble those of C. fasciolata, 
being white, widely tipped with black, and black at the base ; 
the primaries (except the outer one) have the inner web uniform 
black ; the fore part of the neck and ehest are regularly barred with 
white, and the middle of the breast is buff barred with black, as in 
the second example described above. Total length 34*5 inches, 
wing 15-2, tau 13*5, tarsus 4-1. 
Hab. South America, District of Para and ? U.S. of Colombia. 

a. 
5 ad. sk. S. America, July. Salvin-Godman Coli. (Type 
of C. incommoda, Sei.)

1870, p. 518. Sclater afterwards consiJered this bird distinet, and described it 
under the name of G. incommoda; but after comparing it caref ully with the 
original description of G. jtrinwia, v. Pelz., I am convinced that the original 
identification was correct.

Adult male. Whole of the plumage black glossed with dark 
green, except the middle of the belly, flanks, and under tail-coverts, 
which are white; wattle on the basal part of the culmen pale yellow terminal 
part of both mandibles blackish hörn ; legs and feet greyish 
horn-colour. Total length 35 inehes, wing 15*7, tail 14, tarsus 4-6. 

An immature male has the wattle on the culmen Tudimentary; 
the feathers of the chin, throat, and thighs blackish brown barred 
with white; otherwise the plumage resembles that of the adult 
male. 

Adult female. Feathers of the top of the head and crest black, 
with a wide band of white across the middle third • rest of the head, 
chin, throat, and neck covered with short feathers barred with 
black and white; feathers of the back of the neck, mantle, and 

* The locality is no doubt erroneous. 
1 . CEA.X. 479 
cliest mostly Hack glossed with green, and washed or margined 
with rufous; lower back, rump, and lipper tail-coverts deep 
brownish chestnut, indistinctly mottled with black; scapulars and 
outer secondaries like the feathers of the mantle, but the extremities 
are brighter rufous and mottled with black; quills and wing-coverts 
chestnut, tbickly mottled -with black, especially on the inner 
webs of the primaries and on the secondaries and their coverts; 
the outer webs of the secondaries are usually more or le&s irregularly 
barred with white, though these markings disappear with age; 
breast dark chestnut, shading into cinnamon on the lower breast, 
belly, thighs, and under tail-coverts; tail entirely black, glossed 
with green in the most adult examples; in the majority of speeimens, 
however, the median tail-feathers are mottled with chestnut and 
retain traees of the yellowish-white markings of immaturity. Base 
of both mandibles dark greenish brown, terminal part yellowish ; legs 
and feet dull pinkish grey. Total length 29 inches, wing 14, 

tail 12, tarsus 4*4. 

In younger female speeimens the crest-feathers are black with 
several bars of white, while in the youngest examples the feathers 
are mostly white tipped with black; the wings and tail are largely 
marked with white lines and irregulär bands, while the ehest, breast, 
and thighs are barred with blackish or dark brown. 

Hab. Central America, ranging from Western Mexico to Honduras 
and to Cozumel Island.

Adult female. Dinners from tbe female of 0. gldbicera in having 
no white markings on tbe wings, and the feathers of tbe tail 
regularly barred with yellowisb white, these bars being equally 
eonspieuous on the under surface of the feathers; the back of the 
neck, mantle, and ehest are rufous-cbestnut, almost devoid of blaek 
in the oldest exarnple, while the wing-coverts and secondaries are

yoimger speeimens, and the pale bars on the tail are wide and welldehned.

A somewhat yoimger exarnple resembles the above, but the black 
markings on the outer secondaries are still present, although fewer in 
number, while the pale bars across the tail are rather less marked. 

In still yoimger examples, the back of the neck, mantle, and 
ehest are mostly black as in the male, the wing-coverts and secondaries 
are thickly mottled with black, and the pale bars on the tail-
feathers are narrower and less defined.

6. Crax grayi. 
Among the speeimens mentioned by Gray in his List of the 
Gallina3 in the Brit. Mus. (1867) are two females (c & d) from 

S. America, which he consiclered as doubtful varieties of his Crax 
sclateri ( = 0. fasciolata, Spix). These two speeimens closely resemble 
one another in plumage, but one has the lesser and median wing-
coverts almost devoid of black bars. Both speeimens differ from the 
female of G. fascidUtta in having the white bars on the wings and 
tail far wider, and about half the width of the black interspaces, 
while the quills are equally and widely barred with black and 
yellowish white ; the whole of the lower back, rump, and Upper 
1. CßAX. 
4SI 

tail-coverts are buff, somewhat indistinctly barred with black. 
Thebo specimens are so different from the females of ö. fasclolata 
that I have no hesitation in regarding thern as disfcinct, especially 
as in the genus Grcuc one looks to the fomales rathor than fco the 
malet, for distinctive specific characters. Total length 32 inches, 
wing l;J'ö, tail 12*7, tarsus 3-8.

* Under the name of Crax globidosa, Spix, Sclater and Salvin clistinguish 
the birds of the Upper Amazons from C. carunculata, Tenira., which is found 
in S.E. Brazil. The only difiference is, that in the male of the latter the 
swollen process on the base of the culrnen and the wattles on the base of the 
lower mandible are pale yellow instead of red. It appears from what Sclater 
says In his last remarks in the Trans. Zool. Soc. ix. p. 279 that he has never 
seen Uving specimens of G. globidosa, though several examples of C. camnmdata 
have been kept from time to time in the Zoological Gardens. I am inclined to 
believe that C. globidosa is merely a synonym of C. carunculata, and that the

barred with white, those of the breast and thighs are slightly 
vermicnlated and mottlcd with buff, and the outer webs of the 
wing-coverts and quills are irrcgularly marked with whitish buff.

supposed difference in the coloration of the soft parts is due to the former

after death, as in dried sküis of 0. canmeulata the wattles are always yellow. 
The fact that the females of these two supposed species are also identical in 
plumage is aclditional evidence in favour of considering them to be one and the

10. Crax alberti. 
Crax alberti, Fräser, P. Z. S. 1830, p. 246, pls. xxvii., xxviii. {nee $ ) • 
Reichenb. Tauben, p. 136 (186*2) ; Gray, List Gallinm Brit. Mus. 

p. 15 (18'J7) ; id. Himd-L B. ii. p. 233 (1870); Sclat. § Sabin, 
P. Z. S. 1870, p 517 [Ü.S. Colombia] ; Sclat. Trans. Z. S. ix. 
p. 280, pl. xlviii. (1875). 
? Crax mikani $> [nee tf], v. Feh. örn. Bras. p. 343 (1870). 
Crax ^ iridirotris, Srlat. Tr. Zool Soc. ix. p. 282 (1875), x. p. 544, 
pl. xcii. (1879) ; id. RZ. S. 1876, p. 463 |Oartagena]. 

Adult mcäe. Similar in plumage to the adult male of O. daubentoni 
• the lores are thickly eovered with feathers. The basal part 
of the eulmen, which is somewhafc swollen, and the wattles on 
either side of the mandible blue, the remainder of the bill horny 
yellow; legs and feet grey. Total length 35 inches, wing 16, 
tail 15, tarsus 4*6. 

Adult ßmale. Most nearly resembles the adult of O. fasciolata, but 
is easily distinguished by the nearly black feathers of the crest as 
well as by the rauch deeper colour of the underparts and the densely 
feathered lores. General colour of the head, neck, ehest, and upper 
parts black; each of the feathers of the crest with two white bars; 
lower part of the mantle, wing-coverts, seapulars, secondaries, and 
inner primaries, together with the lower back and tail, narrowly 
barred with white; the six outer primaries bright rufous chestnut, 
while the seventh and eighth are intermediate in colour beiween 
them and the innermost primaries and secondaries; breast ehestimt, 
shading into cinnamon on the bolly and under taü-coverts ; 
sides of the breast and thighs more or less barred with black ; and 
all the tail-feathers tipped with white. Total length 32*5 inches, 
wing 15*2, tail 13*3, tarsus 4*3. 

Hab. U.S. Colombia.

Adult male and female. Hcad, back, sides of the neck, chin 
and throat dark brown, each feather margined with pale greyj

6. PENEL0PE, 493 
and breast olive-brown, each feather margined all round with 
greyish white ; belly and rest of underparts rufous brown. Total 
length 22 inehes, wing 9*5, tail 10, tarsus 2*4, raiddlo too and 
claw 2-3. 

This speeies has the chin and throat, as a rule, moro or less 
covered with feathers, and thus differs somewhat from tho otlier 
members of the genus. It resembles P. argyrotis and P. sclateri in 
having the feathering on the legs extonding somc distance below 
the Joint. 

Some specimens in which the wattle on the foro part of the 
neck is developed have the throat mostly nakcd or only thinly clad 
with Hack feathers with elongate hair-like shafts. In specimens 
exhibiting the above characters, the belly and flanks are more or 
less distinctly barred with diisky : whether thcse difforenccs dcnote 
age, sex, or season, I am at present unable to say, but I am inclinod 
to believe that they may be characteristic of yonngcr examples.

3. Peaelope sclateri. 
Penelope sclateri, Gray, P. Z. 8. 1860, p. 270; Melchenb. Tauben, 
p. 151 (1862); Gray, List Gallinm Brit. Mus. p. 7 (1867) [Bolivia] • 
id. HamU. B. ii. p. 250 (1870); Sclat. § 8almn1 P. Z. 8. 1870,

Tacz. P. Z. 8. 1882, p. 48 [N.E. Peru]. 
Aclult. Easily recognized from P. montagnii by having the superciliary 
stripe and the feathers on the sides of the face whiter and 
more marked; the lower back, rump, and npper tail-coverts less 
rufous and browner; the pale edgings on the ehest and breast 
narrower and conflned to the sides of the feathers only; the chin 
and throat almost naked, as in the other speeies of Penelope, though 
in some specimens the chin and npper part of the throat are 
partially feathered. Total length 22 inches, wing 9*5 to 10*2, tail 
9*4, tarsus 2-4, middle toe and claw 2*3. 

A Peruvian bird from Huasampilla differs from typical specimens 
of P. sclateri from Bolivia in having the general colour of the npper 
parts browner, and the lower back, rump, and npper tail-coverts 
as well as the belly and underparts darker chestnut. One speeimen, 
however^ from Bolivia, very nearly approaches the Peruvian bird in

continued down the sides of the naked throat; it is readily distinguished 
from P. maraü by the rnuch lighter and greener colour 
of the upper parts as well as by the rufous-brown belly.

Adiät male and fmale. Feathers of the top of the head white 
with dark shaft-stripes, the longer ones rofous or chestnut at the

on the cheeks mostly black ; fore part of the neck, ehest, and breast 
dark chestnut, most of the feathers edged along both margins with 
white; belly and rest of underparts similar in colour, but without 
white margins.

? Hybrid betiveen Penelope pileata and P. jaeucaca. 

In the Salvin-Godman collection there is a speeimen obtained 
from the Zoological Gardens, which is stated on the label to have 
come originally from K. Brazil. It diiFers chiefiy from typical 

F. jaeucaea in having the underparts of a deep chestnut, much 
darker th%n in P. pileata. There can be little doubt that it is a 
hybrid between the two species.

13. Penelope jaeucaca. 
Penelope jaeucaea, Sjpix, Av. Bras. ii. p. 53, pl. 69 (1825) [Baliial-

Wagl. Isis, 1830, p. 1110; Sclat. $ Sah. P. Z. S 1870, p. 523;

Salpiza jaeucaca, 
Wagl. Isis, 1832, p. 1226; Cak in Schomb. Brit. 

Guian. iii. p. 745 (1848). 
Penelope superciliaris, J. E. Gray, Knowsl. Menag. ii. pl. viii. (1846). 
Penelope superciliosa, Cuv.ßde Gray, Hand-l. B. ii. p. 251 (1870). 

Adult male andfemale. The whole of the plumage brown ; the 
feathers of the middle of the head dark brown ; thosc of the forehead 
margined on the sides with white; a wide white band borders 
each side of the head; upper parts süghtly washed with dull green; 
most of the wing-coverts, scapulars, and feathers of the ehest and 
breast edged on the sides with white. 

From P. pileata and P. ochrogaster, to which it is most nearly 
allied, it is at once distinguibhed by having the general colour of 
the underparts brown ; it also differs from the former and resembles 
the latter species in having the back of the neck and upper mantle 
much the same colour as the rest of the upper parts. Total length 
28 inches, wing 11*8, tail 11*1, tarsus 3*2, middle toe and claw 3*2.

CEACIDJB. 

Penelope argyrotis, Gray, Iland-l B. ii. p. 251 (1870); Sclat. $ Sah. 

P. Z. S. 1870, p. 528 [Int. U.S. Columbia, Bogota]. 
Adiät. DifFcrs from all other species of Penelope in having the 
taikfeathers tipped with rufous; 1t differs chiefly from P. säateri, 
to which it is otherwise most nearly allied, in having the pale 
superciliary stripes, as well as those from the angle of the gape to 
the ear-coverts, whiter and more strongly defined; the edgings of 
the feathers on the ehest and breast, as well as those on the mantle 
and wing-coverts, pure white. Total length 24 inches, wing 10 to 
10-9, tail 10-5, tarsus 2*3, middle toe and claw 2*3. 

Two examples from San Lucas, in Ecuador, differ somewhat from 
the typical Venezuelan example in having the chin and upper part 
of the throat feathered, the feathers of the belly and underparts 
rather distinctly mottled. with blaekish, while the feathers of the 
mantle and wing-coverts are almost devoid of white margins ; these 
birds are probably younger speeimens.

15. Penelope albipeiniis. 
Penelope albipennis, Tacz. P. Z. 8.1877, p. 746 [N.W. Peru]. 
Adult male. Appears to be nearly allied to P. jaciijoeha, and 

P. ortoni, but is distingnished from these and all other species* of 
Penelope by having the first eight primaries white with the base 
and tip dusky, and the ninth whitish towards the middle. Wing 
13 inches, tail 13, tarsus 3*4, middle toe and claw 3*7. 
A single speeimen of this species was procured by M. J. Stolzmann 
near Tumbez, and he states that all the other speeimens 
observed on the wing in this locality had similar white primaries. It 
would thus appear that this birdis-not merely a semi-albino form of 

P. ortoni or some other allied species, as one might naturally be 
inclined to believe. 
Hab. Vicinity of Tumbez, "Western Peru.

Immature males have the plumage of the upper parts black, irregularly 
barred with wavy rufous lines, most strongly marked on the 
upper tail-coverts, and on these parts traces of rufous lines still 
remain when the rest of the plumage has become black. The underparts 
are brown, with wavy buff and rufous-buff bars.

In adopting Lesson's name for this bird I have followed Gray, and 

Sclater and Salvin, but it is exceedingly donbtful what bird he 

really referred to, and his description might equally apply to one 

of the other allied species.

tarsus 2-3, middle toe and claw 2-3. 

It seems to me exceedingly doubtful whether the present species 
is worthy of specific rank, as with a larger series from intermediate 
looalitios the two extremes will probably be found to eompletely 
intergrade.

11. Ortalis superciliaris. 
Ortalida 
superciliaris, Gray, List Gallina Brit. Mus. p. 10 (1867); 
id. Hand-l. B. ii. p. 252 (1870); Sclat. $ Sabin, P. Z. S. 1870, 

p. 537. 
Adidt. Closely allied to 0. guttata, but smaller, and differing in 
having a wide white superciliary stripe produced backwards along 
the sides of the neck above tbe ear-coverts ; lower back and rump 
dark olive-brown like the mantle, in which respect it resenables 

0. caracco ; the ehest and upper breast bave an indistinet whitish 
spot at the extremity of each feather; the four outer pairs of tail-
feathers are tipped with chestnut, the third pair being almost as 
widely tipped as the fourth, and in this respect differing from the 
other allied species, which rarely have any chestnut on the third 
pair, and then only a small patch at the extremity. This species is 
also very closely allied to 0. araueuan, and resembles it in size, bufc 
is distinguishable by its white eyebrows and indistinctly spotted 
breast. Total length about 17 inches, wing 6'8, tail 7*2, tarsus 1*8, 
middle toe and claw 1-8.

Ortalis 
vetula maccalli, Coues, Key to N. Am. B. p. 573 (1884); 
Herrera, La Naturalem, (2) i. p. 278 (1889); Bendire, N. Am. B. 

p. 119, pl. iii.fig. 16 (1892) [Vera Cruz north to Lower Itio Grande 
Valley}. 
Ortalis vetula pallidiventris, Ridyw. Man. N. Am. B. p. 209 (1887) 
[Yucatan]. 
DifFerent names have been applied to this species in different parts 
of its ränge, but from the series now before me it is quite clear 
that all these supposed species are merely slight elimatic varieties of 
one and the same bird. 

Gray has distinguished the birds from Guatemala and British 
Honduras under the name of 0. plumbiceps, and they are supposed 
to differ from typical 0, vetula from Mexico chiefly in having the 
tips of the flve outer pairs of tail-feathers fulvous instead of pure 
white; but among our series I find two speeimens from Teapa in 
the State of Guerrero, S. Mexico, which so closely approach the 
Guatemalan birds in this respect that it would be impossible to 
separate them, while several other Mexican birds have dirty 
whitish tips to the out er tail-feathers. 

Again, Sclater and Salvin have described a bird from the Valle 
Bupar, Sta. Marta, U.S.C., as 0. raficrissa, on aecount of its rufous 
vent and under tail-coverts, but it is exactly similar to a speeimen 
from La Antigua, Vera Cruz, W. Mexico, and many other Mexican 

8 . 0KTALIS. 
513 
specimens approacli it in the rufous colour of their under tail-
coverts. 
The Yucatan bird is a somewhat palcr form, and Bidgway has 
distinguished it as subspecifieally distinct under tho name of 

0. vetida jpaüidiventris; but a specimen from Brownsville, Texas, 
is quite as pale and perfectly similar to Yucatan birds. 
Lastly, the ISTorth-eastern Mexican bird has been named by 
Baird as 0. maccalli, but specimens from this locality are typical 

0. vetida, "Wagl. 
On the whole, I do not think it possible that any of the above 
forms can be considered even subspecifieally distinct from typical 

0. vetida. If any had a right to be so considered it would be the 
0. jolumhicejps, Gray. 
Adidt. Diifers from the adult of 0. jpoliocephala in its much 
smaller size and in having the head and neck less grey. Total 
length 20 inches, -wing 8, tail 9*6, tarsus 2-5, middle toe and 
claw 2'D. 

The coloration of the underparts of the body is subject to 
considerable Variation. 
Mab. Southern Texas, ranging through "Western Mexico and 
Central America to the United States of Colombia.

* In some speeimens, probably younger examples, the shafts of the feathers 
are dark. This is one of the characters used by Gray in distinguishing the 
Peruvian bircl (which he calhP.jacqmnü, Reiehenb.) from P. ctimmiensis from 
British Guiana. Bot two examples obtained by Whitely on 1lie Takutu River, 
Guiana, have a number of the crest-feathers with clark shafts, -white, on the 
other band, an example obtained by the same eollector at Oosnipata, Eastern 
Peru, has all the shafts white, so there can be little doubt the dark shafts are 
a character which disappears with age.

Adult. Whole of the plumage black glossed with dark green; 

fore part of the upper half of the neck mostly naked or thinly covered 

with feathers, and with a naked elongate vermiform wattle situated 

at the base. Total length 29 inches, wing 14 to 14*5, tail 12, 

tarsus 2*7, middle toe and claw 2*9. 

Young birds resemble the adult, but the plumage is browner and 

less glossy; the naked skin on the throat and elongate wattle well 

developed. 

In the young est example the outer secondarics (which are feathers 

of the first plumage) are brown, slightly glossed and mottled with 

pale rufous towards the extremity; and the outer primaries are much 

less excised at tho extremity.

Adult male and female. General colour above brownish glossed 
with bronze-green; feathers of the top of the head and neck more or

shading into rufous on the breast and into chestnut on the fianks,

tail 10, tarsus 2-6, middle toe and claw 2-7. 

Speciinens vary somewhat inter se, some having the nnderparts 
a good deal paler than others. I am inclined to think that these 
differences may be due to age—they are apparently not due to 
sex.

OPISTMOCOMI. 523 

Order VIII. OPISTIIOCOMI. 

Pakte schizognathous ; nasals holorhinal; no basyptcrygoid pro


cess; antepenultimate dorsal vertebrse free, tlie inferior faees of 

the centra of the dorsal vertebraB arc flattened and without crests; 

the sternum is unique—the lateral eclges are nearly parallel for two 

thirds of its length, tlien diverge &o that it is wider posteriorly Uran 

anteriorly; tbe posterior margin with two small notebes on each 

side, tbe outer being reduced to a forarnen; keel very small and cut 

away in front with a flattened-out and broadened surface at tbe 

posterior termination of tbe carina sterni. On tbis surface tbe 

greater part of tbe weight of the body is supported when tbe bird is 

at rest. Tbe coraeoids, clavicles, and furcula (wkich aie sbort) are 

oompletely anebylosed to each otber and to the sternum. 

The enormous crop distorts tbe furcula and stornum and oecupies 
tbe upper part of the ehest, being placed in a deep cayity in the 
Upper half of the pectoral muscles. 

Hallux very long. 

iNo bastard seeondary. 

Üil-gland tufted. 

ISro lateral bare tracts on the neck; the inferior feathered tracts 

heginning at the bottom of the neck run in two parallel bands wbich 
taper gradually towards the vent; dorsal tract bifurcates between 
the Shoulders. 

The young are hatched naked, and the pollex and index digit are 
provided with a claw wbich enables them to climb soon after tbey 
are hatcheel, the bill as well as the legs and wings being used for 
holding on to the twigs ; they are also able to swim and dive with 
facility when. cornpelled to do so. 

Eggs two or three in nurnber, double-spotted and Bail-like. 
Nest composed of sticks and placed on the tops of bushos near the 
water's edge.

HEMIPODIJ. 

Order IX. HEMIPODII. 

Maxülo-palatmes not coalesced with one another or vv-ith the 
vomer; nasals schizorliinal; dorsal vertebne heterocoelous; sternum 
wiili a'decp noteh on each sido of the posterior margin, abotit two-
thirds of the length of the entire sternum; episternam -well-developcd, 
incompletely perforated to reeoive the bases of the coraeoids, 
which are separated by a thhi bony septum. 

Bill liko that of the Gallinse, but often not so strongly developed. 
Eeet generally with three toes only, the hallux being abseilt 
except in Pedionomus. 
Oil-gland tufted. 

Tho spinal feather-tract does not reaeh the neck, but the three 
others do. 
No bastard secondary. Fifth cnbital remex present. 
Young born covered with down and able to run soon after they 
are hatched. 

Eggs double-spotted and three to fivo 'in number. 

Nest none. 

The female is arways larger and the plumage almost always more 
handsome than that of the male, and the latter in the majority of 
species, if not in all, ineubates the eggs and tends the young.

p. 5 [Western Malayanaj ; Oates, Str. F. x. p. 236 (1882) [Pegu]; 
id. B. Burmah, ii. p. 337 (1883); Hume, Str. F. xi. p. 310 (1888) 
[Manipur]. 
Turnix blakistoni, Stejneger, P. Tl. S. Nat. Mus. 1886, p. 635 ; id. 
'~~Zeii. ges. Orn. iv. p. 170 (1888) [Loo-choo Is.]. 

Adultfemale. General colour above rafous or greyish brown or any 
intermediate colour; a more or less distinet white stripe down the 
middle of the head. Eeathers on the forehead, lores, sides of the 
face, throat, and neck white, each with a subterminal black spot. 
Scapulars, back, rump, upper tail-coverts, and tail barred and 
vermicnlated with black; all the scapulars and some of the other 
feathers with the lateral part of the margin edged with whitish buff, 

2M2 

532 TURNlCIDiß. 

Primaries, priniary-eoverts, and secondaries blackish brown,narrowly 
inargined 011 the outer web with buff or white, the outer web of the 
outer secondaries being also toothed with the same eolour ; rest of 
the wing-coverts rufous or brown on the inner web and buff on the 
outer, and barred with black. Middle of the throat and ehest deep 
black; sides of the ehest and the breast buff barred with black; 
belly and rest of the underparts rusty buff, paler in the centre. Iris 
pale straw-white; bill, legs, and feet lavender-grey, slightly dusky 
towards the tip of the eulmen. Total length 6*7 inches, wing 3-6, 

tail 1-2, tarsus 0-95. 

Immature females differ from the adult only in lacking the black 
throat. 

Adult male, Differs from the female only in having the chin and 
tho centre of the throat white and the middle of the ehest barred Kke 
the sides, as well as by its smaller size. Iris pale whitish straw; 
bill plumbeous; legs and feet bluish flesh-colour. Total length 
5-6 inches, wing 3*1, tail 1*2, tarsus 0-85. 

Qaite young mccles differ from the adult in having rounded black 
spots on the ehest and breast insteadof bars; the wing-coverts have 
more buff, and the outer webs of the primaries and secondaries are 
more widely and irregularly edged with buff—nearly all the latter 
being sometimes also toothed with the same eolour. 

A nesiling is covered with down, and resembles a young Partridge 
or Quail. 

Note.—Like all birds of this genus there is a general tendency to 
uniformity of coloration in the plumage of the upper surface of very 
old speeimens, the bars, spots, and markings gradually disappearing. 

Hab. India and rj. Ceylon, ranging eastward of the Bay of 
Bengal through Burma and Tenasserim to the llalay Peninsula, 
Siam, China, Pormosa, and Loo-choo Islands.

2. Turnix fasciata. 
Hemipodius fasciatus, Temm. Pig. et Galt iii. pp. 684, 7hl (1815)

Turnix nigrescens, Tweeddale, P. Z. 8.1877, p. 765 [Zebu]; Ramsay, 
Orn. Works Ticeedd., App. p. 659 (1881)• Sharpe, Ibis, 1888, 

p. 203 [Palawan]; Whiteliead, Ibis, 1890, p. 58 [Palawan]. 
Turnix kaynaldi, Blasius, Ornis, iv. p. 817 (1888) [Palawan]. 
Adult female. Differs from the femalc adult of T. taigoor in 
having the feathers of tho top of the head black with dark grey 
margins; no white stripe down the centre of the head; a wide 
well-defined rufous nuchal collar; tho back, rump, uppertail-coverts, 
and scapulars nearly black vermiculated with grey, and here and 
there rufous towards the margins; the abdomen pale buff, the flanks 
and under tail-coverts more rufous. Iris white; bill yellow at the 
base, greenish as the tip ; legs yellow. Total length 6 inches, 
wing 34, tail 1*1, tarsus 1. 

Immature females. Besemble those of T. taigoor, but have a well-
developed rufous nuchal collar, and the belly pale whitish buff. Iris 
white; bill greenish chrome clouded with blackish green; legs 
greenish chrome. 

Adult male. Has the tipper surface like that of the female, but 
the rufous nuchal collar is entirely absent; the rest of the plumage 
resembles that of the male of T. taigoor^ but the bclly is somewhat 
paler. Total length 5-2 inches, wing 3, tail 1*1, tarsus 0-9, 

TTTKNICID^J. 

In immature males, like immature females, the rnfous nnchal 

collar is well developed at fest, trat as age increases lt gradually 

disappoars, together with the rufous bars in the plumage oi the 

uppor parte. Iris white ; bill blackish, base yellow; legs light 

greenish yellow. 

A qnite yoimg bird resembles T. taigoor of the same age, but the 

plumage of the upper parfcs is darker. 

Hdb. Philippino Islands, Palawan.

Adult female. General tone above warm brown, greyish ort the 
inantle, and inclining to rnfous on the rump, each feather vermieulated

with a subterminal black blotch. Feathers of the top of the head

with whitish buff. Bill and feet pale greenish yellow. Total length

538 TtTHNTCIDiE. 

Turnix gibraltariensis, v. Homeyer, J.f 0. 1802, p. 420. 
Turnix sylvatica, Brake, Ibis, 1867, p. 428 [Tangier and E. Morocco]; 
Smith, Ibis, 1808, p. 450 [Portugal]; Boderl Avifaun. Mod. § Sicü. 

p. 168 (1869-71); Gray, lland-l B. ii. p. 270; no. 9729 (1870); 
Saunders, Ibis, 1871, p. 224 [S. Spain]; Gurney, Bis, 1871, p. 296; 
Ileuql. Orn. KO.-Afr. ii. p. 909 (1873); Lilford,Ibis, 1875, pp. 21, 
24 [Sicilyl; Irhj, Orn. Gibraltar, p. 139 (1875); Dresser, B. JSurqpe. 
vii. p. 249, pl. 494 (1876) ; Giglioli, Bis, 1881, p. 207; Sauna. 
ed. Yarrell's Brit. B. iii. }>. 131 (1882-84); Chapman, Ibis, 1884, 
p. 93 [S. Spain]; Meid, Ibis, 1885, p. 251 [near Tangier]; Salvad. 
El. TJcc. Ital p. 202 (1887); Tait, Bis, 1887, p. 381 [S. Portugal]; 
Koenig, J.f O. 1888, p. 255 [Tunis]• Grant, Ibis, 1889, pp. 450, 
402. 
Adidt female, General colour above dull light red, the feathers of 
the top of the head, back, rump, upper tail-coverts, tail, and scapulars 
barred and margincd internally with black, externally with white or 
grey, giving the back a scaly appearance, which is often increased by 
tho pattern of black and dull light red following the shape of the 
feathers instead of erossing them transversely ; a white band down 
the middle of the head; lores, superciliary stripes, and sides of the 
head and neck white tipped with black. Primaries, prirnary-coverts, 
and secondaries brownish black, the outer web of all edged and in 
the outer secondaries also verrnicnlated with buff and spotted with 
white; rest of the wing-eoverts dull light red, obliquely barred on 
the outer or both webs with black and white. Chin and middle of 
throat white ; sides of the ehest and breast whitish buff, each 
feather with a heart-shaped subterminal black spot: centre of the 
ehest bright rust-colour, paler on the flanks and under tail-coverts ; 
rest of underparts whitish buff. Centre pair of tail-feathers 
elongate and pointed. Total length 7 inches, wing 3-7, tail 1*8, 
tarsus 0*9. 

Adidt male. Differs from the female only in being somewhat paler 

on the underparts and in the scale-like marking on the feathers of 

the upper parts extending right over the nape to the back of the 

head. In the female the nape is nearly uniform dull light red. 

Total length 6 inches, wing 3*1, tail 1*5, tarsus 0*85. 

An immature female has the general paler colour of the male, but 

difrers in having the wing-coverts pale rufous buff irregularly barred 

with black and spotted on the edge of the outer web with white. 

Hab. S. Europe and rJ. Africa. 

a, b. $ ad. sk. Malaga, Spain, June (H. Tweeddale Coli. 

Saunders).

7. Turnix nana. 
Heniipodius nanus, SundevalL (Efv, Vet.-Ahad. Förhandl. 1850. 
p. HO. 
Turnix hottentota, Shelley (nee Temm.), Ibis, 1875, p. 85 [Natal], 
Turnix hottentotta, Sharpe's ed. Layard's B. S. Afr. p. 607 Tpart.] 
(1884). 
Turnix nana, Gran% Ibis, 1889, pp. 450, 463. 


Adult female. G-eneral colour above black, barred and mottled 
with rufous, most of the feathers o£ tbe top of tbe head and back 
incompletely edged with white ; rump and upper tail-coverts nearly 
uniform black ; scapulars edged with golden buff; rest of the head, 
sides of tbe throat, ehest, and npper breast bright buff, the ends of 
the feathers along the sides of the neck and breast regularly barred 
with black and white. Primaries, primary-coverts, and secondaries 
brownish black, the outer primaries margined on the outer web 
with buff; rest of the wing-eoverts irregularly mixed with light 
red, buff, and white, with a more or less regulär subterminal black 
bar and white extremity. Chin and centre of throat whitish ; 
lower breast and belly white; flanks and under tail-coverts buff. 
Tau with the middle pair of feathers elongate and pointed and, like 
the scapulars and npper tail-eoverts, edged with golden buff. Total 
length 5*8 inches, wing 3*2, tail 1*5, tarsus 0"9. 

Adult male, ßesembles the female, but the forehead is like the 
top of the head, the superciliary stripes and sides of the head and 
throat are much paler than the ehest, and the black and white 
barring on the sides of the ehest and breast extends further on to 
the ehest: that is to say, two or three rows of feathers instead of 

OTRNICIDiß.

542 

one have tho tips black and white. Iris grey; upper mandible 
brown; lower one and the legs flesh-eolour. Total length 5 inches, 
wing 2*9, tail 1*2, tar&us 0-9. 

In a quite young specimen the whole of the nnderparts are white, 
exoopt on tho breast, where here and there the buff of the adult is 
just beginning to appear. The whole of the ehest and breast is 
barred with black. 

Hab. Africa south of about 10° S. lat. to the Great Earroo.

(1815). 
Ilottentot Quail, Lath. Gen. Ilist viii p. 345 (1823). 
Turnix hottentotus, Layard, B. Ä Afr. p. 276 (1807). 
Turnix koitentota, Layard, Ibis, 18*69, p. 375 [Swellendam; nests 

and eggs] ; Gray, Hand-L B. ii. p. 270, no. 9730 (1870). 
Turnix kottentotta, Sharpe's ed. LayarcPs B. 8. Afr. p. 007 [part.] 
(1884); Grmtj Ibis, 1889, pp. 451, 464. 

Adult female. Eesembles the female of T. nana in plumage, but 
most of the feathers of the middle of the breast and abdomen are 
ornamentod with a rounded subterniinal black spot. Total length 
6-6 inches, wing 3*4, tail 1*7, tarsus 0*95, 

Adult male is probably similar to the aboye, but the Museum 
does not possess a specimen in which the sex has been aseertained. 
Young birds resemble the young of T, nana, but the beliy as well 
as the breast is barred and spotted with black. 
Hab. Extreme south of the African continent south of the Great 
Karroo.

9. Turnix blanfordi. 
Turjii^maculatiis, Vieill (nee Hemipodius maculosus, Temm.)9 W. 
Biet, tf Mist Nat. xxxv. p. 47 (1810); David 8? OmtaleL Ois. 
Chine, p. 398 (1877). 

Turnix blanfordi, Blytli, J. As. 8oe. Beng. xxxii p. 80 (1863) 
[Thayetmyo]; id. fy Waiden Cat. Mamm. 8f B. Burma, p. 151 
(1875); Grata, Ibis, 1889, pp. 451, 452,466; Styan, Ibis, 1891,

de la Touche, Ibis, 1892, p. 494 [Foochow], 

Turnix maculosa, Gray, Hand4. B. ii. p. 270, no. 9734 (1870); Mume, 
Str. F. iii. p. 179 (1875) [Kolidoo] ; Swmhoe, Ibis, 1876, p. 508; 

1. TtTENIX. 548 
Hume fy Marshall, Game B. ii. p. 183, pl. (1879); Büigham, Str. 

F. ix. p. 196 (1880) [Meplay ß.]; Oates, Str. F. x. p. 236 (1882) 
[Pegu]; id. B. Burmali, ii. p. 338 (1883)• Hume, Str. F. xi. p. 312 
(1888) [Assam and Manipur]. 
Hemipodius maculatus, Swinhoe, Ibis, 1875, p. 127 [Ohefoo]. 

Hemipodius vieiarius, Siänboe, P. Z. S. 1871, p. 402 [<$ ad.] (1871) 
[Carrion to Pekin]; Tacz. J. f. 0. 1870, p. 201; id. Bull. Soc. 
Zool Fr. i. p. 245 (187G) [Ussiiri, Chanka]. 

Hemipodius chrysostonms, Stohikoe. Ann. Mag. N. E. (4) xii. p, 375 
[? ad.] (1873) [Chefoo]. 
Turnix maculosus, Hiime $ Davüon, Str. F. vi. p. 452 (1878) 

[Tenas&erim]; Sclat Voij. ChalL p. 115 (1880). 
Hemipodius catliareus, Swinhoe, MS. [ J iniin.]. 
Hemipodius variabilis, Prjev. Voy. dans Ussuri, no. 139. 

Adult female. General colour above greyish brown, witli a well-
defined rufous nuchal collar; lores and forehead, superciliary stripes 
and sides of the head buff, tipped with black*. top of the head black, 
edged with buff; in some specimens a line of buff feathers down 
the middle of the head. Back, rump, Upper taü-coverts, and 
scapnlars irregnlarly barred and vermiculated with black, mixed 
herc and Ihere •with traces of rufous; some still retaining traces of 
the whitish-buff lateral margins characteristic of immature birds. 
Primaries, primary-coverts, and secondaries blackish brown, narrowly 
margined on the outer web with buff; rest of the wing-
coverts buff, some of the outer secondary and most of the lesser 
and median coverts have a small subterminal black ocellus. Chili 
and middle of the throat whitish buff; sides of the throat, ehest, and 
breast rufous buff, becoming paler on the flanks and white on the 
belly ; most of the feathers of the sides of the ehest and breast are 
ornamented by a small subterminal round black spot. Iris straw-
yellow or white. Lower mandible, gape, and base of upper mandible 
chrome-yellow; rest of upper mandible reddish brown. Legs, 
feet, and claws chrome-yellow. Total length 6*5 inches, wing 3*8, 
tail 1*5, tarsus 1*05. 

Adult male. Differs from the female in having no rufous nuchal 
collar. Iris white; bill and feet yellow. Total length 5*8 inches, 
wing 3*5, tail 1*3, tarsus 0*95. 

Immature mdles and females resemble each other and differ from 
the adults in having all the feathers of the upper surface with a 
patch of rufous at the extremity, and narrowly margined laterally 
on one or both webs with buff; the round black spots on the wing-
coverts and sides of the ehest and breast are also more numerous. 

Hab. India, eastfof the Bay of Bengal to the S. of Tenasserim, 
Siam, and China as far north as Mantchuria.

Adult female. Eesembles T. blanforäi in general appearance, but 
may be at once distinguished by its smaller size and by having the

buff bar, and the rttfous nuchal collar wider. Iris white; bill, Iegs, 
and feet yellow. Total length 5*5 inches, wing 3*4, tail 1-1, tarsus 
0*85. 

Adult male. Eesembles the adult female, but has no rufous nuchal 
collar, and the transverse markings on the upper parts are coarser.

11. Tmnix albiventris. 
Turnix albiventris, Hume, Str. F. i. p. 310 (1873) [Andamans]; 
Hume Sf Marsh. Game B. ii. p. 199, pl. (1879): Grant, Ibis, 1889, 
pp. 451, 452, 467. 

Turnix -joudera, Hodgs. ?, albiventris, Himie, Str. F. ii. p.281 (1874) 
[NicoWs], iv. pp. 279, 293 (1876). 

Adult female. DifFers from both T. Uanfordi and T. tanlci in 
retaining the rufous in the featbers of the back and in having tbe 
nuehal collar much wider and of a deeper rufous. It resembles 
tbe former in baving tbe upper parts blotcbed and vermiculated 
with blaok, and tbe latter in its size and tbe markings of tbe top of 
tbe bead. Total lengtb 5-5 inebes, wing 3*2, tail 1*2, tarsus 0*9. 

Adult male. Scarcely differs in plumage from tbe male of T. blanfordi, 
tbe only apparont cbaracter being tbat some of tbe dorsal 
featbers are intermixed with rufous. Total lengtb 5*3 inebes, 
wing 3, tail 1*1, tarsus 0-85. 

Immature lirds of botb sexes resemble one another, and cannot 
be distinguisbed from tbe immature of T. tanlci. 

Quite young speeimens bave tbe plumage like tbat of tbe 
immature, but paler, and the sides of tbe neck and ehest and 
the lesser and median wing-coverts are tipped witb white. 

Hab. Andaman and Mcobar Islands.

14. Turnix ntfescens. 
Turnix rufescens, 
Wallace, P.Z.8.1863, p. 497 [Semao I, Timor]; 
Forhes, Ibis, 1882, p. 430; Grant, Ibis, 1889, pp. 451, 452, 408. 

The only repräsentative of this species is the type speeimen. It 
is not sexed, but appears to be a nearly adult male. It resembles 

T. maculosa in the lighter colour of the back and T. saturata in the 
colour of the under surface. It is impossible, without more speeimens 
and adult females, to say whether it really represents a distinet speeies 
or not. Total length 5-2 inches, wing 2*9, tail 1*1, tarsus 0*8.

Adult female. General colour above ashy brown ; top of the head 
black, caeli featlier margined with rufous brown ; a white band down 
the ruiddle of tho head and over each of the eyes ; sides of the head 
and throat black, irregiüarly spotted with white, almost uniform 
black in very old speeimens ; a fairly well-devcloped rufous nuchal 
collar; rest of the upper parts with irregulär, narrow, wavy bars 
and vormioulations of black; sonie of the feathers of the upper back 
and soapulars with subtemiinal black blotches edged or mixed with 
rufous. Primaries, secondaries, and primary-coverts blackish brown 
edged on the outer web with pale buff; secondary-eoverts bro wnish 
buff; rest of the wing-coverts the saine, but with a subterminal 
black spot on the outer web of mostof the feathers, edged externally 
with whitish buff. J^eck, ehest, and breast uniform rufous chestnut; 
rest of the underparts dirty buff, paler on the belly. Iris pale 
yellow or white; bill and legs light greenish yellow; nails grey. 
Total length 6*9 inches, wing 4*2, tail 1*8, tarsus 1*2. 

The nearly adult femafo differs from the above in havin«- the 
black subterminal blotches on the feathers of the upper back and 
soapulars margiued laterally with pale buff, the greater part of the 
chin and throat white, and the whole of the markings on the upper 
parts more distinet. 

Adult male. Differs from the nearly adult female in having the 
chin and middle of the throat white (spotted with black in younger 
examples); many of the feathers of the ehest with a subterminal 
black dot, which is abseilt in the most adult; no rufous nuchal 
collar; and the ocelli on the wing-coverts larger and more numerous. 
Iris yellowish white; bill greenish; legs greenish yellow; nails 
grey. Total length 6-4 inches, wing 3*8, tail 1*6, tarsus 1*1.

Turnix melanogaster,

scapulars and some of tho rump-feathers and upper tail-coverts with

edged laterally with white in the two former and whitish buff in the

socondary-coverts paler, finely mottled with buff and black on the

brown, with wavy transverse bars of black and lateral buff spots.

Adult male. Differs from the female in having the top of the 
head umber-brown like the back, the lores and sides of the head 
white tipped with black, the chin and rest of the throat pure 
white, the chest and breast whitish buff, irregularly barred and 
marked with blac^, and the rest of the underparts whiter. Total 
length 6*3 inches, Ving 4*1, tail 1*6, tarsus 0*95,

the underparts whitish; some of the feathers on the sides of the 
ehest and breast are irregularly barred with black and white at their 
extremity. Bill very strong. Total length 6 inches, wing 3*3, tail 
1-4, tarsus 0-8. 
Ad alt male. Eesembles the female, but is smaller, and the rusteoloured 
ehest is not so bright. Total length d'2 inches, wing 
2-9, tail 1-3, tarsus 0*75.

Adullfemale. General colour above brown, finely barred with black ; 
a black and white eollar surrounds the neck, each feather black with

the ehest mst-oolour. Most of the feathers of the top of the head, 
back, and scapulars are margined with whitish buff and have the 


2. PEDIONOMUS. 55 5 
Tanes free, giving tho upper plumagc a very Rhea-liko aspoct, 
Primaries, secondaries, and primary-coverts blackish brown, tho 
out er primaries margin ed and vermiciüated on the out er web with 
buff, the inner primaries and the secondaries with whitish-bufT encls 
and bases shading into the dark middlc part, and tho primary-
coverts tipped with buff; rest of tho wing-coverts buff, with wavy 
bars of black. Chin and eontro of throat white ; sidcs of face and 
throat whitish, spotted with blaek ; lower ehest and rest of underparts 
whitish buif; most of tho feathers on the breast and sidcs of 
the belly with one or two snbterminal black bars. Total length 0 3 
inches, wing 4, tail 1*6, tarsus 1. 

Adult male, DifTers from tho female in having no rust-colour on 
the nape; the collar round the neckis buff and brownish, not ncarly 
so clearly differentiated from the rest of the plnmage, and the upper 
ehest is washed with bright buff. Total length 5*8 inches, wing 
3*4, tail 1*2, tarsus 0-9.
